PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Schacht will be absent from question time today and tomorrow to enable him to have discussions with his Vietnamese customs counterparts and to attend a function marking the opening of BHP's Dai Hung exploration and drilling project at the conclusion of the Australian construction industry delegation to Vietnam that Senator Schacht has been leading. Senator Cook will answer questions relating to small business, customs and construction, and Senator Ray will represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and it concerns the government's policy of forcing up interest rates. The last time the current account deficit began registering monthly deficits of $2 billion, which was five years ago, home loan mortgage rates hit 17 per cent. Is it because the current account is again registering monthly deficits of $2 billion that Mr Keating has now said that the recent rises in housing interest rates are `the rises we had to have'? In view of this trend, will the minister categorically deny that home mortgage rates, which are now at 9.5 per cent, will not reach rates of 14 and 15 per cent, as they did last time? If that is not so, what is the government's expectation of housing interest rates in this cycle?

—Housing mortgage rates clearly directly relate to short-term cash rates, and it is the case that those shorter term rates have been going up. They have risen by 1.75 per cent since mid-August. It is clearly appropriate, in the light of the evidence that is rapidly accumulating about the pick-up in the economy, that we should be taking this action now. There are no signs of inflationary take-off. But with the economy as buoyant as it now is, it is only a matter of time before inflation breaks out unless we take action now to control it.

PARA.TAB: Moving now on monetary policy, as we have been doing, will result in the least increases in interest rates that could possibly occur over the course of the business cycle. Given the low inflation fundamentals that are now locked into the economy, interest rates simply will not need to rise to the same extent as they have in past cycles. We will certainly not have the same interest rate levels in housing or anywhere else as we had in the 1980s.

We are committed to keeping the underlying rate of inflation to around two or three per cent over the course of the economic cycle. Obviously, maintaining low inflation is absolutely critical to the sustainability of growth, which remains the central objective. So that is the reason for this action and let us not lose sight of it: it is because the economy is going like a train, which we all want it to do. Beyond that, I think the answer does not need to go into any more detail. I have pages and pages of detail, which I am happy to share with the honourable senator and the Senate, but I think Senator Hill would probably prefer to talk about something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The point that the minister does not seem to want to appreciate is that this is exactly the same pattern as occurred on the last occasion. The current account has started to blow out; it is back out to $2.1 billion and $1.8 billion—some of the worst figures on record. On the last occasion the minister said that the government had to force up interest rates to dampen demand, the result of which was that much of small business was crushed in this country and life was made so much more difficult for house owners. The same pattern is occurring. The government is deliberately forcing up interest rates; housing interest rates are following commercial interest rates.
—What would you do?

—Cut the deficit for a start. How about facing up to cutting the deficit. The people of Australia are entitled to have some idea as to what the government expects the housing interest rates to be in the next 12 months or so.

—It is obviously the case that the opposition has no alternative policy of its own. It has never had a policy that is remotely credible or, if it is halfway credible in terms of doing something on the fiscal policy front, the opposition is absolutely unwilling to spell out the details for the obvious reason that it does not know where to begin to cut further in a way that would go further than what the government has been able to achieve. We will continue to be responsible, as we already have been, on the fiscal front, and there is absolutely no reason to believe that we should, at this stage, be doing more on that fiscal front than we are at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The response on the monetary policy front always has to run hand in hand with what one is doing on the fiscal front. If we try to put all our eggs in one particular policy basket we are bound to fall flat on our faces and break that particular basket of eggs. The truth of the matter is that we have a deficit reduction strategy that makes perfect economic sense; a deficit reduction strategy that will take what is already a low proportion of GDP deficit down to a considerably lower one than has been able to be matched by any of the other OECD economies, within a tighter time frame than has been able to be matched by any one of those other economies.

We have a responsible policy. We are not saying it is the last word on the subject. We will be prepared to look at it further in the context of planning for the next budget. But there is no need and no justification for moving any faster on that front when we are being as responsible as we are across the board, and when the combination of fundamentals is so comprehensively attractive as it is at the moment—which is the contrast to what we had before.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I ask the minister to table all the papers he was referring to. He said he was happy to share them with the Senate.
—On my terms, not Senator Teague's, Mr President. I decline.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of the Chairman of the National People's Congress of China, His Excellency Mr Qiao Shi. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you and your delegation to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask the minister this question because of conflicting reports in recent weeks about the number of drought-stricken farming families who are seeking assistance under the federal government's drought relief payment scheme.

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Demonstrating in that fashion is, I remind people in the gallery, disorderly. If you put those away now nothing will be done about it; if you continue with that you will be forced to leave the Senate chamber.

PARA.TAB: A further incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Attendants, please remove those people from the Senate chamber.

—Mr President, I will start again. I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy,. I ask the minister this question because of conflicting reports in recent weeks about the number of drought-stricken farming families who are seeking assistance under the federal government's drought relief payment scheme. Can the minister advise the Senate of the extent to which the scheme has been taken up among those farming families in Queensland and New South Wales?

—The implementation of the scheme and, more importantly, its uptake have both been swift. I should remind the Senate that the drought relief payment scheme was given cabinet approval barely six weeks ago. The first payments in fact started to flow the day after the legislation was passed by this parliament. The scheme itself has basically been running for about four weeks. As of last Friday, the rural assistance authorities in Queensland and New South Wales had issued nearly 9,000 certificates to farming families in areas of exceptional drought. Following the issuing of those certificates, 3,796 applications have subsequently been received by DSS offices. In fact, I was told just before I came into question time that that figure is now closer to 4,000.

PARA.TAB: So far 1,514 have been approved for payment, with those payments, as I have just said, commencing the day after the legislation passed through this parliament. The approval rate on applications is currently running at 91 per cent. Given the huge administrative task involved, the speedy implementation of the scheme is a credit to all DPIE and DSS officers who have been involved in administering it. My ministerial colleague Peter Baldwin and I are closely monitoring the implementation of the scheme to ensure that any problems are resolved quickly and that assistance is kept flowing effectively.

Mr Baldwin visited drought affected areas last week to talk to farmers and DSS staff on how the package is being implemented on the ground. The government has also today released details of further support measures for families in areas of exceptional drought in Queensland and New South Wales. There is no question that the severity of the drought is placing enormous pressure on families. The government has committed an additional $445,000 to provide additional crisis counselling services. The social counsellors have been appointed in addition to the financial counsellors. DSS officers already on the ground will ensure that farmers can cut through any red tape in assessing these benefits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I draw the attention of the minister to the, at best, naive or, at worst, wilfully misleading comments made by Senator Gareth Evans on the Sunday program yesterday when he set out to downplay the dangerous military threat posed by the Khmer Rouge. For example, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the numbers of the Khmer Rouge are really not that large—
. . . our best intelligence estimate is . . . no more than 8,000 men under arms and maybe as few as 5,000—
. . . and the extent to which the Khmer Rouge strongholds have by and large proved vulnerable to assault.

I ask the minister: does he share Senator Evans's dismissive comments? What is his assessment of the military capabilities of the Khmer Rouge? Will he table a full, frank and realistic statement of that assessment in the parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already seen these views in Senator Newman's grubby and opportunistic press release put out yesterday. The fact is that I totally concur with Senator Evans's assessment of the Khmer Rouge, which was not dismissive of them but said that they number between 5,000 and 8,000 cadres and another 8,000 support people. All the evidence we have had from intelligence and other things has supported that position.

PARA.TAB: The same questions were asked during the election period in Cambodia, when Australia was criticised for putting forward the view that the Khmer Rouge did not have the capacity to totally disrupt those elections. We were criticised, not necessarily in this parliament, but by others saying, `Why would you send observers into such a dangerous position when the Khmer Rouge are so strong?' The fact is that the Khmer Rouge have weakened over the years.

It is also a factor that they remain a fundamental problem because of the incapacity of the Cambodian defence force to mount effective operations against them. And that is very much a function of the Cambodian defence force, consisting of three factional groups merged into one—inheriting some 2,000 generals, low pay, low morale and low discipline—and trying to reform and develop itself into a force that can effectively combat this terrorist regime that exists in parts of Cambodia. That is the situation.

Senator Evans's assessment is absolutely right, as was the now Lieutenant General John Sanderson's assessment two years ago when other countries believed he was wrong. It is not a question as to whether the Khmer Rouge are a large and dangerous group; it is the amount of countervailing force that can be brought against them. That is what the international community has to consider. It does not have to consider opportunistic scaremongering press releases implying that we are going to send peace enforcement operators to Cambodia, as Senator Newman's press release yesterday said. She should go back and read that press release—Senator Newman put her name to it—and withdraw it as a disgraceful document that adds nothing to the consideration of international affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In utterly rejecting the minister's claims, I ask him to consider another pearl that came from Senator Evans yesterday. Senator Evans said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the immediate need is just to sort of strengthen the competence and discipline and professionalism of those armed forces—
and of course of the government itself . . .
. . . you've got a manageable, containable situation and ultimately one that can ensure the destruction of this brutal residual terrorist force.
What does this pearl mean? I ask the minister, as Minister for Defence, very specifically: what does this pearl mean in terms of defence aid to Cambodia?

TALK.START.PARA: —You know nothing about the history of the region. Learn some history and then you might be more credible.

—I am not the one who needs to learn the history. I know how corrupt governments cannot deal with guerilla forces. I ask the minister: what are the intentions of Senator Evans and the government in regard to defence aid to Cambodia? Will the minister come clean to the parliament of Australia?

—On the matter of coming clean to the parliament, I have been notably silent on this for good reason for the last six or 10 weeks. I have been silent on this particular matter because if I had gone public with my views during the hostage situation, suggesting what I would like to see done in Cambodia, I would have further endangered the lives of those hostages, absolutely and categorically. And I note that at least the Australian press were extremely responsible: they did not seek information from me and publish information from me on what we may do in response to the weakness in the Cambodian defence force because that would have threatened the lives of those hostages. So, yes, we had to be quiet during the hostage crisis. We will now—
—I asked you a specific question. Will you answer it?

—We will now—if the honourable senator would bother to listen—take a submission to cabinet and, when it is through cabinet, we will announce our intention. That is, I know, a quaint process to the opposition—that it would go through policy formulations, it would go through policy formations and a formal process and then announce policy. That is what we intend to do.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to previous announcements he has made about extensions of stay for visitors from the former Yugoslavia and Sri Lanka, given the state of unrest which still exists in their homelands. Can the minister tell the Senate what arrangements have been made for visitors from these countries after the end of this month, when their temporary entry visas will expire?

—I must thank Senator Zakharov for this question. I know that the honourable senator has raised this issue with me on a number of occasions over the last 15 months or so, and the fact that she raises it again today is another reflection of her interest in what is, indeed, an important issue, particularly for the 1,000 or so people from Sri Lanka and former Yugoslavia who are in the situation to which she refers and who, because of that situation, remain uncertain about their futures.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Zakharov mentioned, on a number of occasions in the last year or so I have made statements about extending the stay of people who have arrived in Australia as visitors, and also for other temporary residence, from both Sri Lanka and the former Yugoslavia but who, of course, have not been able to return home because of continuing conflict in their homelands. In fact, on 10 June this year I announced an extension of their visas until 30 November.

This measure recognised, in the case of people from Sri Lanka, that while the standard of human rights there was improving, the situation was still sufficiently uncertain enough to warrant offering a further extension of stay. Similarly, in respect of people from the former Yugoslavia, it was clearly difficult, if not in fact impossible, for those people to return to their home countries while the fighting there continued. So we have extended the capacity for those people to stay in Australia until 30 November.

In the meantime, we have been closely monitoring the situation in both of those countries and, because of that monitoring, I have decided that it would still be unreasonable to expect these people to return home at the present time. They will therefore be offered a further extension of their visas until 31 March 1995. This will apply, of course, to all citizens of both countries who are normally resident there and who have held a valid entry permit at any time on or after 31 December 1991. This will include some 500 people from Sri Lanka and just over 500 from the former Yugoslavia—people who currently hold these extended temporary visas.

As well, I should mention that a number of these people have applied for permanent residence under the series of measures that the government announced on 1 November last year. Their applications are currently being processed and the present extension, the one I have just announced, will ensure that those who are not eligible for permanent residence under that visa category will not be required to return while the conflict persists. The next step is for all these people involved to approach the nearest immigration office for information after 30 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I refer the minister to photographs delivered to him today and I ask: can the minister confirm, firstly, that the photos are of recently harvested logs, some on Tasmanian railway wagons and others in a loading yard; and, secondly, that the photographs clearly show that not all the logs are eucalypts, with many minority species, such as white and red myrtle, sassafras and blackwood, represented? On 7 December 1993 the minister answered my question on notice by saying that all minor species sawlogs are sold to sawmills. With these photographs in mind, I ask the minister: on what basis can he assure me that there is no local market for these logs pictured and that this chip wood trade is not as incidental as he implied in that answer and not in contravention of national forest policy?
—I can confirm that I was given some photographs by Senator Bell.

TAB.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would you kindly remove that person from the gallery.
—We obviously have a coalition of interests here today.
—Order! I remind those people in the closed gallery that they are also being disorderly. If they want to be removed, they will also be if they keep that up.

—I can confirm that the photographs are of sawn logs and I can confirm that they were in Tasmania because it says `Tasrail' on the side of the wagon. Unfortunately, of course, the photographs themselves do not indicate any evidence for supporting the assertions that Senator Bell has made or otherwise because there is no evidence from the actual photographs as to where they were logged or where they were on their way to, as I am sure Senator Bell would accept. I know there is a script on the back, but I have not had time to read that, to be honest.

PARA.TAB: The senator was advised earlier this year that minor species wood surplus to domestic requirements is sometimes sold for woodchip. That is correct. The export of woodchips from minor species wood from Tasmanian forests is permitted under the Commonwealth export licences, which Senator Bell was advised. The wood is not specifically targeted for pulpwood and it is usually sold as part of a composite woodchip product. In other words, there is absolutely no indication simply from looking at the photos whether the particular logs Senator Bell has referred to ended up in a woodchip mill or were selected out, as is sometimes the case.

As with other wood sourced from native forests, sawlog and veneer logs are offered for sale to domestic suppliers where the sale of these logs produces a higher return than the pulpwood market. Logs that are unsuitable for sawing are available for pulpwood. If Senator Bell has specific concern over the use of minor species, I will ensure that further advice is provided to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not ask the minister to use his imagination; I ask him to look at the facts. These logs are sitting in the holding yard of the Burnie pulp mill—APPM's pulp mill. It does not need any great stretch of the imagination to see what they were using. I asked on what basis he can answer my question by saying that all minority species are sold to sawmills. I do not hear from the minister's answer any justification for that answer. I ask the minister to deny that small sawmillers and craft users in Tasmania are desperate for raw material while beautiful logs are being chipped and pulped and wasted. On what basis can he deny that?

—I simply repeat again that the photographs speak for themselves. No such evidence is provided by the photographs. The reason that Senator Bell provided the photographs, as I am audibly aware, is that he has an audience in the public gallery. That is the reason he provided the photographs. I say again—

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I rest my case, Mr President. I say again that the response to Senator Bell's question earlier this year stands, that pulpwood of minor species was first offered for sale on the local market, particularly with the craft industry in mind. Where there is no domestic demand for the logs, they are sold for chipping and may be exported under Commonwealth licence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the minister raised or is the minister intending to raise the issue of human rights in Tibet with His Excellency Mr Qiao Shi, the Chairman of the National People's Congress of China, during His Excellency's current visit to Australia? Can the minister clarify the terms of the United Nations request that China enter into meaningful dialogue and negotiations with His Holiness the Dalai Lama? What representations have been made by Australia in this regard?

—I have, in my discussions with Mr Qiao Shi this morning, raised the subject of human rights generally and more particularly our desire to continue the dialogue that we got into with the formal committee, group or delegation on human rights that has already made two visits, which group has had Tibet, of course, as one of its more substantial topics for that dialogue process. We do believe it is important—
—Did you raise Tibet with him?

—I did not raise Tibet specifically with him this morning because the opportunity for dialogue was extremely limited, not because of any degree of unwillingness on my part to do so. In fact, I will state quite clearly now on the public record—and I may well have another opportunity during the course of this visit to raise the issue more specifically—that we are concerned about the situation in Tibet. We have always been concerned about the overwhelming presence of Han Chinese and the concern—
—Why didn't you raise it?

—Because Mr Qiao Shi bears no current responsibility for security matters of this kind, whatever responsibility he may have had in the past, and there are a great many other matters on the human rights agenda, as well as the agenda more generally, which it was appropriate to cover and which there was not very much time to cover in the short meeting I had with him this morning.

PARA.TAB: Our position is perfectly clear, that we are concerned about the oppression of religious freedom, of cultural identity and of freedom of expression in Tibet. I have said that publicly on many occasions. I have said it privately on innumerable occasions in discussions I have had with the Chinese leadership, and will continue to do so. I am wholly in sympathy with the desire of the Dalai Lama and his followers to establish some resolution of this issue that is much more satisfactory than what has been the case hitherto.

I think it is extremely important that the dialogue should be entered into by the Chinese with the Dalai Lama, hopefully without any preconditions at all—and we have said that on many occasions. Beyond that, I do not think I can add anything sensibly to that answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has failed to answer the second part of my question, which was to clarify the terms of the United Nations request that China enter into meaningful dialogue and negotiations with His Holiness and desist from its continued refusals. I want to know where Australia stands on the protection and preservation of Tibet's spiritual and cultural rights? What has been our stance in relation to the United Nations request of China?

—I have just told Senator Chamarette that we support any dialogue between China and the Dalai Lama. We certainly support the call from the UN for that dialogue to be entered into. We certainly support anything which would guarantee a cessation of such repression as has occurred to religious freedom, cultural identity and freedom of expression in that country or in that area, and we unquestionably would wish to see some greater respect for the cultural autonomy of the Tibetan people with respect to those particular matters.

PARA.TAB: Australia's position on the question of sovereignty is well established and long established, and I am not going to resile from that. But there is an awful lot we can do within that framework to have a much greater respect for the cultural autonomy, cultural freedom, freedom of expression and political freedom of those people, and we believe those measures ought to be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the government's decision to repudiate its commitment to permit Air New Zealand to fly domestically within Australia from 1 November 1994. I refer also to the Prime Minister's comment on the John Laws program that in Australian terms it has been all give, give and New Zealand has been all take. I ask: if the terms of the memorandum of understanding were so one-sided, why did the government agree to them in the first place and why was the government prepared to continue negotiating with Air New Zealand right up to 24 October?
—It is not a question of whether—
—Is this the truth?

—Senator Macdonald would not know the truth if it jumped up and bit him on the bum. Australia remains firmly committed to the concept of a single aviation market. It is precisely because Air New Zealand has not been prepared to carry the concept as far as Australia has, that we have taken the decisions we have. Why does Senator Parer not look at some of the facts, instead of simply coming in here and running a line for Air New Zealand? Why does he not go and join the New Zealand parliament? At the moment, New Zealand is simply trying to use the single market for its own advantage.
—This is a bit of Northern Territory humour.
—Why would Senator Hill have any clout here? He does not even have any clout in his own branch in South Australia.
—I ask Senator Collins to address his comments through the chair.

—A true single market is one in which our aviation industries are properly integrated to the mutual—I stress `mutual'—benefit of both countries. New Zealand has not been prepared to pursue this concept or to cooperate in the implementation of passenger processing arrangements which Australia has been pressing for, and which, I might add, were always a central part of that proposal, to make travel across the Tasman faster and easier.

PARA.TAB: Far from reneging on the 1992 memorandum of understanding, Australia is trying to carry it through to its logical conclusion: a genuinely integrated single market in which the aviation industries of both countries effectively become one, which is the ultimate goal. Until we are satisfied that New Zealand shares this objective, we are not prepared to keep giving away rights that are benefiting only Air New Zealand at the expense of our own airlines. I am sorry that Senator Parer has a different view. In the meantime, we are taking nothing away from Air New Zealand that it is not already using. The single aviation market has been substantially progressed over the last two years with generous on-flying rights granted to Air New Zealand. But with all these arrangements, whether with New Zealand or with anyone else, the central part of these agreements is reciprocal rights.

Air New Zealand was recently given approval, from 1 November this year—something Senator Parer seems to have ignored—to operate 12 services a week, totalling 3,600 seats, beyond Australia to Taipei, Osaka, Seoul, Bangkok and Los Angeles. These services are in direct competition to flights operated by Qantas and Australia's new international entrant, Ansett—and far exceed the benefits of access to New Zealand's much smaller international market. To grant domestic access now would only add to the disparity. It is quite clear, I might also add, from advice received from Air New Zealand—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order.
—that it had no plans to operate domestic services—
—Order! Senator Collins, take your seat please.

—I hope I did not miss the pearl, but I thought the nub of the question was that if the terms of the memorandum of understanding were so one-sided, why did the government agree to them in the first place? It is a pretty simple proposition, Senator Collins is a pretty simple minister, and I would have thought he would be able to recognise relevance when he sees it.
—There is no point of order but I ask Senator Collins that when in future I ask him to be seated, he will be seated.

—I have just been explaining precisely that point about reciprocal arrangements. I pointed out to Senator Parer something of which he was obviously completely ignorant—namely, that on 1 November this year we granted significant additional rights in competition to Qantas and Ansett. Australia remains committed to a single aviation market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Obviously Richo rides again! I refer the minister to the claim by Qantas that the float would be adversely affected by the continued implementation of the memorandum of understanding. I refer the minister to the government's February 1992 policy statement entitled Australian Aviation: Towards the 21st Century, which was issued over his signature as the then minister. The minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: The announced changes will facilitate the privatisation process for Australian Airlines and Qantas by reducing uncertainty and removing the barrier between international and domestic aviation.
Why has the government now changed its mind about the effects of the single aviation market?

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate that Australia remains firmly committed to the concept of a single aviation market between our two countries. What I am disappointed at is that the federal coalition wants to give significantly more advantage to New Zealand than it does to its own country.
—Before calling the next question, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a distinguished former senator, the Hon. Don Chipp, and his family. I wish them well.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, relates to provisions to allow consumers to choose cheaper generic drugs. I ask: what is the government doing to ensure that that is able to happen, and how are we going to provide consumers with an increased choice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator West for her question. The Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, has announced that as from 1 December consumers will have a greater say when it comes to the drugs they use and the price they pay for them. Under the changes that were passed in this parliament in August, consumers will be able to ask their pharmacist to substitute a cheaper generic brand of drug than the name brand prescribed by their doctor. There are about 120 listed drugs in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which have a cheaper generic substitute.

PARA.TAB: The federal government estimates that this will result in significant savings to consumers—this is especially important for those on low incomes—and it will not in any way compromise the quality or safety of the care provided. Indeed, many of these generic drugs are currently being used in hospital pharmacies across the country.

The legislation allows doctors to write `not for substitution' across the prescription if they have a reason to indicate that they feel a patient needs a particular brand of a particular drug and none other. An example of that may be patients who are allergic to some brands of medication and not to others.

There are some good reasons why GPs should choose one brand over another. However, there is no justification at all for so many doctors, as well as the AMA, wanting to oppose the move to generic substitution. I suppose in some ways it is clearly evident that this will blow apart a very cosy arrangement between some providers of pharmaceuticals and some parts of the medical profession.
Let me quote Bob Allan, the vice-president of the Australian Association of General Practitioners, who gave this description of how doctors choose which drug to prescribe:

ANSWER.PARA: You prescribe a particular product because of the relationship which the professional develops with the pharmaceutical manufacturer's representative. They provide a lot of educational support.
Dr Allan said that by prescribing cheaper drugs he would be discouraging the development of new drugs.

PARA.TAB: Colin Johns, the retiring federal president of the Australian Pharmacy Guild, said it much more directly and much more clearly when picking up on the AMA's decision to oppose generic substitution. Colin Johns described the response of the AMA as `blatant, arrogant self-interest on behalf of the doctors who enjoy fringe benefits from drug companies in the form of substantial free samples, free accommodation, travel to seminars and other bonuses.'

Why on earth would the AMA be opposing this proposal? Even Mrs Bishop supports the substitution of generic drugs. She has now come to that view; she has made it clear. So what on earth is the reason for the AMA opposing it? It will be better for consumers; it will be cheaper for the consumers; in no way is it going to interfere with the quality or safety of medication; and it will give consumers more choice and more information. Many doctors are prepared to support it, but the AMA has come out and opposed it. One can only say in the end that it is afraid of losing the cosy deals, arrangements and support which have been given to so many doctors over the years.

I would like to see the opposition give very clear support to its spokesperson on health, who is supporting the substitution of generic brands. How on earth can the AMA justify its position? I suggest it cannot; and that is the embarrassment that it is facing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I preface it by expressing the deep concern of all Australians at the kidnapping of Australian citizens travelling or living abroad and the need to bring the perpetrators to account. Can the minister confirm whether in 1985 two Australians were kidnapped near Quetta in Pakistan and taken over the border into Afghanistan, and that members of the former Afghan regime's military organisation, the DRA, and its intelligence service, the Khad, were heavily involved in this exercise? Is the minister aware of reports that his government has admitted to permanent resettlement in Australia up to 10 senior members of the DRA and Khad, including a Khad officer, a Mr Timurani, who, it is alleged, was directly involved in the 1985 kidnapping? If so, are these reports correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that I stand by the statement I made in the Senate on 21 June in a different context. I quote:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . it is my own clear view that no Australian security agency ever has or ever would knowingly assist the entry to Australia of any individual who had been involved in terrorist or war crime activity of this kind.

In the specific context that Senator Short mentioned here, I am advised that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is conducting an investigation into the presence of a number of former DRA officials in Australia, including through reports from relevant Australian security authorities. That investigation, I am advised, is not yet complete, but some procedures have already been introduced designed to reduce the chances that former officials of questionable background could be admitted. Further questions on these issues should, of course, be addressed to my colleague Senator Bolkus rather than to me.

PARA.TAB: As to the kidnapping case that Senator Short mentioned, I am only aware of the broad details of that 1985 kidnapping case because I asked for advice as to what on earth Mr Reith's press release a couple of days ago on this particular subject was all about. I am certainly not able to confirm that anyone that we know about was involved specifically in that case. Certainly, the government would not knowingly admit to Australia someone who was known to be directly involved in kidnapping innocent parties, any more than we would knowingly admit anyone involved in any other form of terrorist activity.

If the opposition or any member of the opposition has any proof, any evidence, any information of a specific rather than simply speculative kind that would assist us in further investigating this matter, we would be only too delighted to receive it. I am sure I can say that on behalf of Senator Bolkus. Beyond that, I have no further information that I can usefully add.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Would he agree that, if the reports are correct, these immigration decisions by the government stand in stark contrast to the need for it to take all possible measures to deter potential kidnappers of Australian citizens abroad and, when they do perpetrate their crimes, to bring them to account?

—I have nothing to add to my previous answer. The point I made speaks for itself. Of course we are not in the business of encouraging anybody kidnapping Australians anywhere. That speaks for itself. Of course we would act in all appropriate ways not only to deal with those situations if they do arise but also to deter them arising in the future. I have no disagreement with those propositions. Senator Bolkus has responsibility for applying the immigration rules—very often, mind you, applying them in a situation where he is subject to blandishments and representations from members of parliament on behalf of people whom they are subsequently embarrassed about. I am sure that, bearing those realities in mind, Senator Bolkus will do the best possible job that he can to avoid these situations arising in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Will the government be pursuing agreement on minimum environmental standards, work safety and labour rights generally at the APEC summit meeting in Bogor? If not, why not? Will the government be proposing the establishment of an APEC working group to examine the need for side agreements on these issues similar to the environmental side agreement in NAFTA? If not, why not? Is the minister aware of Amnesty International reports that, in honour of the visit by our Prime Minister and other APEC leaders, the Indonesian government is killing local activists who might have raised such labour and environmental issues?

—With regard to the first two parts of the question, I make it very clear that APEC is not NAFTA; it is not the European Union. It is a long way from anything remotely resembling either of those agreements. Arbitrarily adding a list of extra issues before the question of whether an agreement to head in the broad direction of free trade in the region has been agreed is, I think, decidedly premature.

PARA.TAB: APEC is a consensus-based organisation. None of its members has suggested this is an appropriate forum for pursuing these matters, not even those members of APEC who are actively pursuing these issues in other international fora, such as the WTO. There is the opportunity, of course, through other international organisations to take up social and environmental issues of relevance to APEC. On the existing work programs, some APEC work takes place on economic issues that have a social dimension under the broad heading of human resource development.

APEC environment ministers and experts have been hard at work on integrating environmental considerations into APEC's activities. They met in Vancouver in March, and APEC environment experts met recently in Taiwan to put together a list of environment integration recommendations for other APEC bodies to consider. If the Bogor meeting goes as we would wish and some discussion takes place subsequently about the advance into free trade in the region, it would be open to the environment ministers to make any suggestions they might wish from that continuing consultative process about how they should be integrated with the free trade agenda.

With regard to the third question, the government is concerned about reports of human rights abuses in Indonesia in the lead up to the APEC leaders' meeting in Bogor. There have been signs that the Indonesian authorities have been clamping down to avoid any possible disruption at the time of the meeting. Australia has made recent diplomatic representations at a senior level outlining its concerns to the Indonesian government specifically regarding the police questioning of Dr Aditjondro, an academic activist, and on the possible effect that a draft presidential decree regulating NGOs may have on human rights activists. We have also made known our concerns about labour rights issues, including the arrest and trial of the trade union leader Pakpahan, and the media bans. We are monitoring closely these and a number of other human rights issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the minister says it is premature to raise these issues, will he undertake to indicate the Australian government's concern about these issues at Bogor and give notice that the government will pursue them in the future?

—I have raised issues—and Senator Gareth Evans has much more frequently raised issues because it is principally his responsibility—about our concerns with human rights matters in Indonesia and some of the environmental and other issues to which Senator Spindler referred. The continuing process of close bilateral relations with countries in our region will continue to make Australia's position on environmental and human rights issues very clear.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to today's Sydney Morning Herald article where the New South Wales Premier, John Fahey, has supported calls for the armed forces to truck water to 12 townships in the Hunter, north coast and central west areas of New South Wales as well as to drought stricken farmers. As the drought is worsening, will the minister give sympathetic consideration to the use of defence manpower, facilities and equipment to assist regional and rural New South Wales in the distribution of water if and when the need arises?

—I understand that Premier Fahey has written directly to Prime Minister Keating on this subject, and I have not yet been privy to that correspondence. It is the normal process, of course, to call on defence resources when all state resources are expended and no more are available. Of course, there is a secondary factor that, whilst it is often a popularistic approach to advocate the use of Defence Force equipment for civilian purposes, more often than not that far more expensive equipment can be degraded far more easily than what is available already in the civilian infrastructure.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I will certainly look sympathetically at Premier Fahey's request. I cannot give guarantees at this stage but, if it is possible for the Defence Force to play a role, I will be quite happy to sanction that, provided all other possible avenues of resources—it may well be cheaper—have been explored first.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand that an important connection has recently been established between two internationally significant wetlands, one being in Japan and one in Australia. Can the minister provide some details and explain the significance of this linkage?

—I had the pleasure this morning of being involved in a ceremony held at the Shortlands Wetlands Centre where two very significant Ramsar wetland sites were formally linked—one on the island of Hokkaido in Japan and the other in Newcastle. Senators would be aware that the Ramsar convention is an intergovernmental treaty which provides the framework for international cooperation on the conservation of internationally significant wetlands.

PARA.TAB: The Japanese site includes the Kushiro Marsh, which is a unique breeding ground for migratory birds. The other Ramsar site is the Kooragang Nature Reserve and associated wetlands in the Hunter Valley. It is where these birds, particularly the latham snipe, migrate to during the northern winter. Protection of this bird, the latham snipe, relies on the preservation of wetland habitats in Japan and Australia. The two countries, specifically the wetlands which were linked this morning, provide the critical habitat for this particular bird.

The linking of these two Ramsar sites highlights the importance for both countries of protecting internationally valuable wetland sites. Japan and Australia are both very active players in the Ramsar convention. In 1993 Kushiro hosted the fifth conference of the contracting parties to the Ramsar convention. The next contracting parties convention will be held in Brisbane in early 1996.

Australia has not historically had a good record in protecting our wetlands. Since European settlement more than 50 per cent of our wetlands have been either degraded or destroyed. Declining water quality is an increasing problem. It is in part caused by the destruction of so many of our wetlands which have acted as a filtering system for our water. Over the next two years in the lead-up to the 1996 Ramsar conference, the Commonwealth will be working cooperatively with state and local governments to improve the management of our internationally important wetlands and to list more of our internationally significant wetlands in the Ramsar convention.

Last month I announced a special allocation of funds to improve the management of Australia's 42 listed Ramsar sites. The Kooragang site received $30,000 of that funding. Today I was also pleased to announce a new federal grant of $23,000 for research on the latham snipe's breeding and feeding habits and also its wetland habitats. This grant will allow an exchange between Japanese and Australian scientists.

The attendance of a very impressive visiting party of mayors from Kushiro indicates the importance that the Japanese have placed on this new connection between Australia and Japan. I see it as a very positive development that Newcastle and Kushiro—two cities obviously very far away from each other—are working together to foster an international awareness for the protection of significant wetlands.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Why did the minister announce the closure of the North Perth Migrant Resource Centre without consultation with the management committee, without any demographic evidence of the need for closure, without consultation with the local members of parliament, without consideration of transport logistics of alternative locations, and without providing any source of decision making information? On whose advice did the minister act, and will he make that advice public? Given the overwhelming objections of the migrant communities, will the minister overturn his decision and retain the centre and, prior to any further moves, undertake a full and comprehensive feasibility study with the North Perth Migrant Resource Centre and the Ethnic Communities Council?

—I can understand why Senator Knowles asks this question in the way she does because it is very easy to become captive of the debate in Western Australia. What I have said in respect of the centre is that I have made a decision but I am prepared to entertain submissions on it by the end of this week. A mechanism has been put in place whereby Senator McKiernan and Mr Steve Smith will put those submissions to me.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important to keep in mind that the decision was taken to set up a new MRC to replace the North Perth MRC and to set up the new one in the northern corridor eight or so kilometres further north than the North Perth MRC in perhaps one of the fastest population growth areas, in terms of local government areas, anywhere in Australia. It is for me a decision based on the best use of resources, and it is a decision that, I must say, has already been welcomed by communities representing the Vietnamese, the Burmese, the Indians, the Sri Lankans and so on. So there is some recognition of a need for the MRC to go further out. There is also recognition by communities involved that needs are not being met.

There have been some reviews. For instance, the Bentley-Kehoe review recommended that consideration be given to relocating the MRC some seven or eight kilometres further north. The North Perth MRC did not agree with that or with recommendations on location, management and so on.

I say to Senator Knowles that there is one very difficult aspect about that evaluation, that is, the evaluation was finally presented to government under threat of defamation proceedings by those who were being evaluated. What we finally got was a sanitised report under threat of defamation. That is not the way that I would like to conduct my assessment of the use of my resources in this area—when a person being evaluated does not allow the evaluation to continue and takes the consultants to defamation lawyers.

It has been part of an ongoing saga with the North Perth MRC. It is not something that I am new to; I have known about it for some time now. It is something of which other people in Western Australia are also aware.

It is the government's intention to set up a new MRC, and my intention is to set it up before the North Perth MRC closes down. It is also the government's intention to set up transitional arrangements to facilitate the continuation of services, if the final decision is taken following discussions with Stephen Smith and Jim McKiernan on representations.

Senator Knowles asked me to make public the information involved with this decision. I am informed that on Friday night the offices of the department were broken into and the files on this matter were stolen. So the information is probably already public. Obviously, I do not condone that sort of action, but I do say to Senator Knowles that when we come to this particular issue it is best for all of us to look at it in the broad context as to where resources would be best used. In my estimation, the best use of these resources is in those areas of fastest growth some eight or so kilometres from the North Perth MRC. However, as I said, I am open to hearing representations over the next few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that Mr Smith, the federal Labor member for Perth, and three Labor state members said at a public meeting the other night, when talking about no closure, that there was a need to retain North Perth and to establish an additional centre about eight kilometres further north, why is the minister now shillyshallying around and saying `maybe' and `maybe not', but at the same time saying that North Perth is going to close anyway? Why is the minister having consultations with these members of parliament—one of whom is Senator McKiernan—when he is saying that the centre is going to close? I ask the minister again: on whose advice did he act and will he make that advice public? It is not good enough to simply say that the offices of the department were broken into and people possibly have access to the information. When did the minister consult with the North Perth MRC? Why is the minister allowing a couple of members of parliament to run this whole thing when he is not prepared to say where he got his advice from?

—I think it is easier for me to go back over the answer I gave in terms of evaluations, growth areas and the best use of resources. At the outset, though, let me say that I am not presuming guilt on the part of anyone. I am not saying that they now have access to the report. I did not say that at all. I am not saying that. What I am saying is that the report is now accessible to someone because that report, amongst other documents, has been stolen from the department's headquarters in Perth.
—Are you accusing the people from North Perth Migrant Resource Centre of stealing them?

—I am accusing nobody. I did not accuse anyone before, nor am I now. Steve Smith is the local member; Steve has made very strong representations to me; and on the basis of those representations and those from Senator McKiernan I am prepared to consider this decision.
—Has Carolyn Jakobsen made any representations?

—Is it not interesting? This is the degree of pessimism on the other side, and I can understand it. Has Carolyn Jakobsen made representations to me? What we are talking about here is an MRC going from a Labor electorate to a Liberal electorate. It is a Liberal electorate. I am being condemned for making a decision based on where the resource needs are and where the needs of the community are and for overriding party interest. I should not be condemned for that.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CROWLEY

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October Senator Herron asked Senator Faulkner, acting Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question on blood imports. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE, SENATOR HERRON, 20 OCTOBER 1994
BLOOD PRODUCTS

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Faulkner, the following questions without notice, on 20 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: There is a critical shortage of blood products to treat people with haemophilia in Australia, and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories has already warned of an impending national severe shortage of blood products by December this year. In view of the immediate and current crisis, why did the Minister for Human Services and Health refer this matter to a working party to report some time next year? Further, as the Therapeutic Goods Authority has approved a recombinant factor VIII product which will substantially overcome the severe shortage, can the Minister assure the Senate that people with haemophilia will have access to blood products by December 1994 to provide for a level of adequate treatment?

Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Surely the Minister could answer yes or no to the second part of my question, which was: can the Minister assure the Senate that people with haemophilia will have access to blood products by December? Can he or can he not assure them?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: A distinction has to be made between provision of Factor VIII for emergency treatment on the one hand and the provision of Factor VIII for prophylactic treatment and elective surgery on the other hand.
CSL has advised the Red Cross of the proposed deliveries of Factor VIII for the next three months. CSL has highlighted that there will be a reduced level of Factor VIlI available in December 1994.

CSL have advised that the reduced level of Factor VIII is due to a reduced level of plasma made available to CSL for fractionation by the Blood Transfusion Services. This was the result of a reduction in the number of blood donations for the period May to July 1994.
The Government will monitor the situation closely and will import additional product at short notice should lives be at risk.

The AHMAC working party was established to consider the long-term provision of Factor VIII for both emergency and prophylactic use and both the cost-effectiveness of non-emergency use of Factor VIII and future funding of any additional provision of Factor VIII.
People with Haemophilia can be assured that sufficient Factor VIII will continue to be available for emergency use.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CROWLEY

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October Senator Woods asked Senator Faulkner, acting Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question on smoking. I seek leave to incorporate that answer.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE, SENATOR WOODS, 20 OCTOBER 1994
SMOKING

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Faulkner, the following questions without notice, on 20 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Is it correct that the Government has rejected the advice of its own Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, which recommended that the aids to quitting smoking, nicotine patches, be placed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme?

(b) Is it true that these patches will potentially help thousands of smokers quit smoking and that, with Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) subsidisation, they will be out of the reach of many lower income earners, who will then be more likely to die of heart disease and cancer?

(c) Is it true that the real cost of the restrictive listing recommended is around $20 million, not the wildly inaccurate $100 million, and that there are potential savings in the health and financial areas which are enormous?
(d) Is it not another case of Labor ignoring the interests of lower income earners, except that in this case they face not only poverty but death?
(2) (a) Mr President, let me ask a supplementary question which even Senator Faulkner can answer. Is it not true that smoking costs the Australian community $9 billion per year and some 20,000 lives?
(b) Is it not true, therefore, that a 10 per cent reduction will save $900 million a year and around 2,000 lives?
(c) Does that not constitute an unanswerable, cast-iron case for subsidising these patches?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Yes. The Government did not accept the recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) as it is concerned about the high potential for inappropriate use and waste if nicotine patches are available on a general community program such as the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) rather than through a structured smoking cessation program.

Although the PBAC recommended listing it was nevertheless concerned about the potential for waste through patients using patches without being properly motivated to give up smoking. The Committee noted that nicotine patches are more successful in a structured smoking reduction program with success rates falling by over 25% in less structured programs. It recognised that the Government may decide that the PBS is not the most appropriate means of support.
Structured anti-smoking programs are implemented by the States and Territories.
(b) Yes, it is correct that nicotine patches have the potential to help many smokers quit smoking.

Samples of trial data indicate that nicotine patches, when compared to other methods, will help an additional 6-7% of smokers to quit smoking while participating in structured smoking cessation programs.

The price of purchasing nicotine patches would not be out of the reach of many low income earners. This is based on the premise that the purchase price of nicotine patches would be equivalent to the average expense for cigarettes incurred by heavy smokers.

Both State and Territory Governments administer structured smoking cessation programs which promote anti-smoking practices. In these programs, smoking is contraindicated and should stop when a patient is using nicotine patches. Patients are motivated to maintain anti-smoking practices on completion of these programs.

(c) The PBAC's Economics Subcommittee calculated that the cost to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme of a restricted listing of nicotine patches could be up to $100 million per annum based on doctors treating 22% of the 3.04 million smokers.

It is important to note that experience has demonstrated that once a drug is subsidised through the PBS, volume increases significantly thus adding considerably to Government expenditure. The drug company does not appear to take this into account.

(d) No, this is not the case. The Labor Government is very committed to the interests and health of low income earners. It is also committed to taxpayers as a whole and funding nicotine patches through the PBS is not the most cost effective method.
2. (a) Yes, this is true.
(b) Yes, this is true.
(c) No, it does not.
The Federal Government remains committed to reducing the harmful effects of tobacco which inflicts an enormous financial and social cost on the Australian community.
Under the arrangements to deal with the effects of licit and illicit drugs, the State and Territory Governments are responsible for smoking cessation or reduction programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to a memorandum of understanding between the Australian and New Zealand Governments on aviation.

SPEECH.PARA: The saga of the current Air New Zealand debacle, whereby this government has repudiated a memorandum of understanding, goes back to February 1992 when a major feature of the One Nation package was to have a single aviation market between Australia and New Zealand. In fact, the One Nation statement made great play of this. There were stories abounding at the time that probably a reason for it was that the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating) felt no allegiance to the old management of Ansett, therefore did not have any loyalties to Ansett and was not in there to protect it, hence, the single aviation market. The single aviation market made sense from a lot of angles because it meant more competition on the domestic market, more international competition, more tourists being brought into Australia and so on.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, the then minister, Senator Collins, issued a statement which outlined in great detail the government's position. He made the point in his document entitled Australian aviation: toward the 21st century that this was a major step forward for Australia. He said that the new aviation policy would allow competition for Qantas on international services and new domestic competition from Qantas and New Zealand operators, and provide for the integration of the Australian and New Zealand aviation markets. The new policy would provide benefits for travellers and encourage the development of a more robust, integrated, internationally competitive economy.

Subsequently, the minister signed a memorandum of understanding with the Minister for Transport from New Zealand, Mr Rob Storey, on 1 August 1992. The basis of that agreement carried forward the One Nation statement so that it picked up a slow build-up of the services being able to be offered by New Zealand carriers and subsequently by Australian carriers. It had a phased program allowing this to occur by 1 November 1994.

Out of the blue, the minister responsible for aviation, Mr Brereton, only some four or five days before the due date of 1 November 1994, sent a letter to the minister for transport in New Zealand, saying that the Australian government had decided, in the light of developments, that it could not agree to amend the air service agreement to allow domestic access in terms of paragraph 3G of the memorandum of understanding. That in itself was a dishonest statement because it says that the government could not agree to amend the air service agreement. That agreement specifically stated that Air New Zealand would be able to operate domestically from 1 November 1994.

I am interested to see Senator Gareth Evans here. This was a memorandum of understanding. Certainly, it did not have the force of a legal agreement but a memorandum of understanding is a very important document. I wonder whether the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or Minister Brereton consulted Senator Evans when they repudiated the memorandum of understanding, which is what they did. Excuses were given. Everyone in the industry knows that the excuses are just red herrings.

One reason given was that the agreements in respect of ownership and control had not been expanded.The ownership and control clause in the memorandum of understanding was introduced by the New Zealand government because it did not want an agreement between two countries that could get it into difficulties if one of the airlines, either Australian or New Zealand, was taken over by another international airline. That was to be the basis of the discussion, not some forced marriage.

A lot of questions need to be answered. Why did the Prime Minister go to bat to force a marriage between Air New Zealand and Ansett? Who asked him to do it? What were the benefits in doing so? Why should a Prime Minister get involved in commercial negotiations when he had nothing whatsoever to do with them? This matter is a disgrace. I would be interested in Senator Evans advising us sometime whether he was aware that an agreement of this magnitude, which relates to the whole of the CER agreement, was ever referred to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising, of course, that this memorandum of understanding was organised while Senator Collins was the Minister for Transport. He has been an abject failure in every portfolio he has touched in the last four years, and so that does not come as a surprise to me.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise a couple of other issues very briefly. One is the number of jobs that have been lost as a result of the last minute decision by the government to renege on this particular agreement. Hundreds of young people in Brisbane lined up for jobs with Air New Zealand because Brisbane was going to be the hub of the proposed arrangement. Many of these young people were unemployed and were looking forward to having a job in the tourism-aviation industry. That all fell to pieces when the government pulled the rug on the agreement at the very last minute.

The other matter relates to my disappointment that there will not be another airline competing in the domestic market. I look back with some wistfulness at the tremendous strides taken by Australian aviation when Compass flew. I know in particular that Cairns and the Cairns tourism industry just boomed in the period when Compass was flying. I was looking forward to another boom in tourism and in domestic air travel around our country with the greater competition that a third domestic airline would have brought. All of that now seems to be to no avail. We are left with the two airlines again with very little competition between them. What could have been a great step forward for tourism and very moderately priced airline travel around Australia has gone wanting because this government simply cannot make a decision. It is dictated to by others outside this parliament and, again, it is the Australian people who suffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In quick response to the New Zealand matter that is generating so much excitement from the opposition benches, it needs to be appreciated that there were two quite specific provisions in the memorandum of understanding in paragraphs (G) and (H) respectively that did quite explicitly make the question of full access to domestic markets:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . subject to the outcome of consultations . . . on questions relating to the ownership and control of Australian and New Zealand airlines . . .

The memorandum does not spell out what the desired outcome of such consultations were. The truth of the matter is that Prime Ministers Keating and Bolger discussed the issue as recently as July of this year. Both sides agreed that the desired outcome was a rationalisation with the two-airline aviation policy. Mr Bolger, of course, wanted one of those two airlines to be the New Zealand national carrier. There have been no formal discussions on the issue since that time and certainly no resolution of the question in a way that is satisfactory to the Australian side. For those reasons alone, quite apart from any other consideration—a number of them have been canvassed—it is quite inappropriate to suggest that there has been any walking away from the terms of the MOU. The Australian government does not do that.

PARA.TAB: There are many other policy considerations that came into play. Some of them have been canvassed by Minister Brereton, and by Minister Collins today. But on the specific question that has been raised about reneging on the terms of the MOU, that is the situation as I understand it at least so far as that particular clause is concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray), to a question without notice asked by Senator Newman this day, relating to Cambodia and the Khmer Rouge.

SPEECH.PARA: I am absolutely amazed at the outburst from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) over a very legitimate question that I asked and a press release that I issued yesterday. I was described as being opportunistic by Senator Ray in a rush of blood to the head that is quite incomprehensible.

PARA.TAB: It is not a question of whether Cambodia should be supported in trying to defeat the Khmer Rouge and to establish effective government in the country, but it is all about what that support should be. We in the opposition support defence aid and we support other help but, as with the rest of Australians, we have a legitimate claim to want to know what the government's assessment of the military position is so that our response can be assessed and, if possible, agreed to on a bipartisan basis.

In my press statement yesterday I asked Senator Ray to make a statement about what the government intended. I did not suggest we were sending peacekeepers. I asked whether we would end up sending peace enforcers—a reasonable question, I would have thought. I seek leave to table that press statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arrogance of the minister in telling the Senate that the government would decide what it was going to do and then would inform us all in due course when it saw fit is pretty breathtaking, in my view. It is not acceptable. Both Senators Gareth Evans and Ray should make full statements to the Senate now.

PARA.TAB: I understand Senator Ray is intending to respond to what I have to say, but we are looking for specific detail of assessments, not the sort of airy-fairy stuff that we got yesterday morning on the Sunday program. Whatever Senator Ray said today, it does not diminish the transparent attempt of Senator Evans to downplay the military position. The only reason that he has done this has to be that he cannot bring himself to accept the reality that when the UN left Cambodia after the elections the Khmer Rouge may have been smaller in number but its influence and fighting capability was still very dangerous.

My interest in this does not stem just from my action yesterday in criticising Senator Evans for being muddled in his explanations and soft on the capacity of the Khmer Rouge in his interview on the Sunday show. My interest in this comes from a long interest in the Cambodian situation. I seek leave to table a report I made on the Cambodian situation after I visited it just before the elections in 1992.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I furnished a copy of this to the then Minister for Administrative Services, but I did not make it public because of its sensitivity and because of my wish to do nothing to disturb the election process. Senator Evans can make faces, but that was the reality of it. I spoke privately to individuals concerned and I gave the government a copy of my report. I stated in my summing up:

SPEECH.PARA: I am somewhat pessimistic about the outcome in Cambodia. The continued intransigence of the Khmer Rouge and the importance of the strategic areas they occupy, the serious, almost complete deficiency of civilian infrastructure in the country, the lack of controls on the Thai border, the increasing banditry and corruption, the fierce hatred of the Vietnamese and the passive non-intervention policy of UNTAC to date make the long term outcomes very doubtful and at the best extremely difficult. I acknowledge however, that Untac appears to be treading a stronger line since I left the country.
I ended up saying:
I fear that the final outcome will see either a country dominated by the Khmer Rouge or a return to fighting and a divided country, whether an election takes place or not.

I do not like pointing out that that was right. But Senator Ray bothers me because he bridles at being asked to be accountable to the parliament. I simply asked a number of specific questions. I asked for a statement of an assessment of the military capabilities of the Khmer Rouge. I asked for a full, frank and realistic statement of the assessment in the parliament. I asked what Senator Evans's statements on the Sunday program implied in terms of defence aid to Cambodia. And I asked: does this mean a commitment of our forces to a peace enforcing role in a guerilla war?

PARA.TAB: I hope that Minister Ray does not live to rue the day that he ignored the warnings of the opposition about being sucked into a guerilla war. We do not know what he is intending because he is keeping us all in the dark. The big lesson of guerilla warfare is that small numbers of guerillas supported by the local population can hold a large force down for many years, dislocating all life in the countryside.

The opposition does recognise the importance of regional security, but we expect the government to be up-front about the true situation, not to call the opposition spokesman opportunistic for telling it as it is. The fact is that it is not so very different from 1992, and that gave me cause for concern then. The government should at least be open with the parliament of Australia before it starts making plans for what aid, or military aid in particular, it is preparing to give to Cambodia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman really did deserve all the walloping she got from Senator Ray during question time today because it was a remarkably silly press release, as well as being a misconceived one, that was put out yesterday. Let me give just one example. She says early on in the release:

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator Evans to claim that the Cambodian Government has scored a significant victory over the Khmer Rouge mountain stronghold, and to dismiss the number of Khmer Rouge fighting men as a mere handful of 5000 or 8000, displays an unbelievable optimism, or ignorance of the realities of a guerilla war.

Can I draw attention to a couple of things—first of all, as to what I actually said yesterday. I fully acknowledged the impact that even a quite small fighting force of guerillas can have on the country. I will read, for example, one relevant quote:
It's amazing what kind of results you can achieve with guerilla operations if they're tightly, professionally run and controlled—how much havoc you can wreak, even with relatively small numbers.
I went on to say:

If at the same time the government personnel—military personnel—out in the countryside is creating a reputation for itself for corruption, incompetence and worse, then in that kind of environment clearly even very small numbers can do damage beyond what one might think possible.

I went on from that to talk about the need for reconsideration of military assistance. That is the general point to make. Of course we acknowledge the force of the argument. We all watched, we all witnessed, the Vietnam war being carried on for so many years by a numerically smaller body. But also in the particular context of the Vine mountain assault, it just happens to be the case, whatever reservations or worries we might have about the accompanying course of events as they possibly impacted upon the hostages, that the military action there embarked upon, which involved an encirclement and ultimately assault upon the mountain combined with a strategy of offering amnesty and encouraging defection, did produce a situation where that particular stronghold was wiped out, with some hundreds of soldiers and, I think, close to a thousand people overall—we still have not seen the final figures—back under government control as a result of that particular exercise.

PARA.TAB: That is at least a start, and an indication of the kind of operation that might sensibly be mounted in the future. It is one thing just to have a guerilla operation which simply leaves a spot and regroups to fight again another day, but to have people actually changing sides and coming into the government ambit as a result of an operation of that kind is to have an indication of the sort of thing which can happen in the future and which will, I believe, be able to happen in the future when the military gets its act together.
