Senator Newman, for the opposition, has been yelping for further information from the government. Let me say firstly that quite a lot of information is already on the public record about the nature of our response to the Wilson case in particular and our general assessment of the situation.

I would like to take the opportunity to seek leave not only to table but to incorporate in Hansard my press release expressing the government's profound and sincere condolences to the Wilson family on 2 November for the appalling death of David, and the detailed documents and accompanying transcript that were released at the media conference the following day. I seek leave to have the documents incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: CAMBODIA: AN INTERNATIONAL RESPONSIBILITY

1.However fragile and vulnerable Cambodia may continue to be, the country is in infinitely better shape now, just one year into the life of its new government, than it was just a few short years ago when there was a full-scale civil war raging supported on each side by major external powers, no internationally recognised government, no constitution, no infrastructure, no financial assistance from the international community and no hope.

2.We will have to give Cambodia time, certainly some years, before it is really off the danger list. But I firmly believe that, through its own efforts and international assistance, Cambodia will cross that threshold and emerge with real prospects for long term stability and economic prosperity.

3.It is suggested in some quarters that I have painted too glowing a picture of the Cambodia which emerged last year from the peace process. In the period between September last year, when the new government took office, and early April this year, there was good evidence that, with numerous defections occurring from the Khmer Rouge, with a coalition government in place that had worked out a modus vivendi and seemed, against all the odds, to be putting behind it the bitter enmities that had characterised its members' past dealings with each other, that Cambodia, while faced with absolutely enormous problems of reconstruction and lack of infrastructure which were the legacy of the twenty or so years of conflict, was on the road to permanent peace and development.

4.When I visited Cambodia in early April 1994, things seemed to me, and to every international observer with whom I spoke, to be very much on the right track—at least within the limitations of what might be expected from a country emerging from twenty years of war, civil war, genocide, invasion, and civil war again. I also saw it as important, then as now, not to unnecessarily or gratuitously undermine the tentatively emerging self-confidence of the new Cambodian leadership that it could in fact cope with the massive challenges it was facing: I had some words of warning, as well as encouragement, but they were uttered privately.

5.My optimism, and that of many in the international community, was severely challenged by the military debacle of the fall of Pailin which occurred on 19 April. These events were of course major psychological setbacks for the government itself. After that time, we started to hear more of stagnation and inactivity in government; of disarray in the armed forces which had been responsible for the military disasters; of a resurgence of corruption; and of the Khmer Rouge making inroads again—not because they were numerically strong or were winning vast numbers of Cambodians to their policies, but because the armed forces were performing badly, were untrained and were incapable of earning the respect of the people they were supposed to be protecting.

6.It became clear after April, to a much greater extent than before, that not only did the country need massive amounts of development assistance for the purposes of reconstruction, but that in order to provide for the security of the country—without which economic development could not take place—some form of assistance was needed to help the armed forces do their job. Major reconstruction of the RCAF had to take place; its leadership had to become more professional; and its members had to be better trained—at a basic level, with elementary military skills, and at a more sophisticated level, in how to wage effective counter-insurgency warfare.

7.A great deal depends on the Cambodian people themselves, and in particular on their political leaders, to deliver good government to the country, particularly in the rural areas. I have put those views to the Cambodian Government quite bluntly, and with increasing force and directness in recent months. Its members know that they can only expect continuing international assistance if they do the right thing by their own people.

8.Nonetheless, in judging the way Cambodia is dealing with its problems today, we have to remember that the government, the bureaucracy and the army are just one year old. There is no judicial system to speak of, though we and others are trying to help rectify this. Most of those with an education were wiped out during the Khmer Rouge period. We cannot begin to imagine here in Australia the dimensions of the obstacles faced: the comparison would be some 2 to 4 million Australians being killed, including nearly all the country's best qualified administrators and professionals.

9.There is hope. The coalition has survived, and the two Prime Ministers whose factions were previously literally at each other's throats are working together reasonably well. An attempted coup came nowhere near succeeding. An economic program which the IMF and the World Bank have applauded has now been introduced and is regarded as one of the most liberal and forward-looking in the region. Certainly a greater level of stability than Cambodia now enjoys will be needed if the economy is to realise its potential, but the fundamentals are there. Many of the country's political and administrative leaders are committed and talented people who have given up lucrative jobs overseas—in countries like Australia, France and the US to which they fled in the early 1970s—to come and work for a pittance, or for nothing, to rescue their country from its depths of poverty and misery. There are numerous non-government people, among whom are many dedicated Australians, who are working hard to get Cambodia back on its feet.

10.The population of Cambodia—now some eight and a half million people—has suffered beyond measure. We must not give up on people who depend so much on us and others in the international community. Can we really in all conscience even consider reducing the programs Australia has in place to help rid the country of the estimated ten million mines which are still waiting to be activated by innocent farmers and children wandering in the fields? Can we even think of abandoning programs for bringing schools, health care (eradicating polio and controlling malaria in children for example), expert advice, help with rebuilding bridges that have been destroyed, and so on—programs which amount to $92 million over four years—because the Khmer Rouge have cold-bloodedly murdered two of our citizens? This would be the glorious victory the Khmer Rouge are looking for; it would hurt the very people whose misery we wept over in the late 1970s when the depths of the Khmer Rouge atrocities were revealed. Now is the time to help Cambodia—not five years down the track. There is a humanitarian imperative.

11.We must also resist the temptation to turn our backs on Cambodia for another reason: there are important security interests for Australia and the region at stake. If Cambodia were to return to the battleground it was, there is the grim possibility of other players in the region being slowly but surely sucked into supporting one side or the other. The very real gains brought about by the end of the Cold War, where countries of the region such as China, Vietnam, Thailand and Laos are moving gradually but inexorably towards fruitful economic partnerships, would be undermined. There would be refugee outflows; tensions; regional suspicions would again be aroused; and there would be a loss of confidence in the region about the ability of this part of the world to live peacefully together. Cambodia is not an isolated country which can be ignored, quarantined or put in the too-hard basket. There is a ripple effect from whatever happens there which may not be obvious immediately but which could eventually corrode the sense of regional stability and the prospects for regional prosperity on which Australia depends for its own security.

12.We should need no reminder of how cheap life is to the Khmer Rouge, and of what they are capable: the between one and two million Cambodians who died at their hands in the 1970s, the numerous Vietnamese and Cambodians who have been killed in the period since, and now the murdering of foreign hostages. Their aim is to drive a wedge between the Cambodian Government and some of its strongest supporters in the rest of the world, and to turn away foreign tourists and potential investors, thereby dampening hopes for an economic upturn in Cambodia which might give the Cambodian people some prospect of a decent livelihood.

13.The international community must help Cambodia, and not only by continuing the excellent program of development assistance now in place, one particularly designed to improve living standards in rural areas. It must now help the country to organise the kind of competent, professional and disciplined army that will be capable of containing, and ultimately destroying or completely neutralising, the Khmer Rouge—of which there are presently estimated to be no more than 8000 men under arms.

14.There have been discussions between a number of countries about coordinated military assistance, involving in particular training and institutional support (for which there is a much greater immediate need than for lethal materiel). The Defence Minister and I will be taking a joint submission on this subject to Cabinet as soon as possible.
Gareth Evans
3 November 1994
QUESTION AND ANSWER SESSION AT MEDIA CONFERENCE ON CAMBODIA BY SENATOR GARETH EVANS, SYDNEY, 3 NOVEMBER 1994
Q:You say the media problem over there was a factor—did it exacerbate the situation?

GE:It was a problem for the reasons that I have described. The media invaded in force and were desperately keen to get stories and that's perfectly understandable—that's what the media exists for. But in the process, it was made clear by the nature of the international coverage that was given to the issue, that the Khmer Rouge really did have a prize on their hands; a group of people in which the international community was intensely interested, about which they were intensely concerned. That unquestionably itself served to raise the price, not only in the first instance in terms of the kind of ransoms that were being demanded but also I think, moved the situation from being one of merely a monetary kind of ransom being demanded to a political ransom being demanded: it upped the ante to that extent. There had been a history for a long time of people being captured and ransoms being demanded and negotiations of one kind or another being held, including with the Westerner Melissa Himes just a few months earlier. But all of that took place out of any media spotlight and I think it just has to be frankly acknowledged—I say this just in the spirit of objective description—that the media was a factor.

The other dimension of it was the sheer level of confusion I think that was generated by multiple channels of communication being opened up with the media offering various inducements for people to give information which was then in dramatically short supply; that in turn leading I think to a lot more crossed wires in terms of reports and conflicting reports and channels of access to the hostages than would otherwise have been the case if it hadn't had that kind of spotlight. I made these points to the media at the National Press Club speech and question time session I made some weeks ago. I don't want to particularly emphasise the matter; that's history now and a story is a story and I suppose you people have just got to chase them. But I did ask at the National Press Club a long time ago for restraint to be exercised. I think there was a little bit of restraint, at least after that, but really the damage had been done.
Q:What confusion are you talking about; which quarters; the Cambodian Government or the Australian Government or. . . ?

GE:Well fairly universal confusion. It has been very, very difficult to keep lines of communication running in straight lines throughout this. Part of the problem is the incomplete relationship, if I could put it gently, that the Cambodian civilian government has with the military leadership and the incomplete relationship that the military leadership in Phnom Penh has with its own commanders on the ground. We are talking, remember, about a fledgling government; only one year old, still in the process of getting itself together and we're talking about a situation which is enormously difficult to manage even for governments of vastly greater stability, longevity and experience as we know from other cases around the world. So the business of communication—who had access to what information and how it was being received and how it was being circulated—was really one of the big problems running throughout this, and having a whole heap of additional players in the act all wanting lines of communication of their own, preferably exclusively, preferably before anyone else had them, it did lead to a very, very difficult situation.
Q:Given your much publicised role in the Cambodian peace process, do you now accept this as a personal failure?

GE:I wouldn't put it in personal terms at all, any more than there is any foundation at all for suggesting that my personal or political ego was somehow at stake at any stage of this whole affair. The reason I and the Australian Government got involved in this was essentially for two reasons: a gigantic humanitarian imperative, to try and do something to lift a country that had suffered so much and people that had suffered so much for two decades out of that misery; and a security imperative—this was one of the great continuing, destabilising conflicts in the region that involved not only internal players but the external ones as well—China, Vietnam, Russia.
Q:But you had no influence?

GE:Well we had a very considerable influence in bringing the original peace plan to fruition and I am describing why it was that I got involved in that. Why it was that I was involved in the hostage crisis is by virtue of my ministerial responsibility and at the end of the day we failed, of course we failed. And that is a matter of tragedy for all of us but it's not a matter that I would want to characterise in personal terms. I think it is really rather tacky for anyone to do so.
Q:Jeff Kennett is saying that the Government made no real attempt to save David Wilson. What would you say to Jeff Kennett?

GE:Well I will send him a copy of the statements I have just made this morning and hope that he will be better informed in the future. Obviously we had to be very careful about what we were saying publicly to the media, throughout the whole course of the crisis, because we didn't want to say or do anything that would inflame it. These sorts of situations, if they are ever going to be resolved, essentially do depend for their resolution on quiet, behind-the-scenes negotiation. That failed at the end of the day, for reasons that I think are pretty clear to us all. But there is nothing more the Australian Government could have done and as I think back over the whole of that last three months as I did in preparing this statement over the last 48 hours or so, tracking back through every step along the way, I genuinely don't believe there were any other options available to us at any step along the way than those that we very actively pursued. We had a team of 10 or 12 people effectively engaged full-time—and by full-time I mean seven days a week in most instances, most of the time—on the ground in Kampot; on the ground in Phnom Penh; back here in Canberra; in my office. The notion that we were somehow sitting and twiddling our thumbs watching the world go by and somehow callous or indifferent to the fate of an Australian citizen is so far from the truth that it is ludicrous.
Q:What happened to the idea of using Australian troops?

GE:I don't want to talk in detail about that but there were both intelligence reasons (ie a shortage thereof), and security reasons: inability to maintain any secrecy about an operation of that kind. Quite apart from any other consideration, that idea didn't really get to first base for that reason.

Q:Since the murder of Kellie Wilkinson we have heard nothing about her murderers being brought to justice. What moves will the Australian Government be making to ensure the follow up in of General Paet in this case?

GE:Well we are very concerned about the Kellie Wilkinson case obviously, that hasn't just passed into history. The difficulty is that the Khmer Rouge commander that is responsible for that killing is and always has been headquartered in a very difficult and inaccessible part of the country—the foothills of the mountains to the north of the Phnom Penh/Sihanoukville Road. Although they mounted a raid on the road and intercepted the convoy and took them there they disappeared up into the mountains very quickly. The Phnom Vor area by contrast where this recent case occurred was at least surroundable by the military and capable of assault. Whether that was a sensible thing or not—it was certainly capable of encirclement and the kind of pressure that was maintained. I am just describing why it is that it has not been possible so far for a major campaign to be mounted against the perpetrators of the Wilkinson abduction. That is exactly the kind of thing that in due course we are hoping that a sufficiently competent, disciplined, professional army will be able to do: bit by bit, work its way around the country and do the job of cleaning out those areas that are held by these sorts of people. Under those circumstances the hope of bringing that particular person to justice is not an unreal one in the longer term.

As to the situation with respect to Paet who was clearly responsible for the murders here, I can't do any more than repeat what I said a little earlier on: the first thing was to make it absolutely clear that there could be no question of an amnesty, whatever virtue in general terms the amnesty strategy might have in encouraging defectors and of course we understand the policy considerations which lie behind that in general terms. But my first concern, and this was one of the reasons I spoke as I did in Ulaan Bataar, was to get very firmly on the record very early that that was not an option so far as we or anyone else in the international community would be concerned, for Paet. Now there is the problem of actually apprehending him and bringing him to justice and that in practical terms is a very real problem. I guess the answer to that, unless there are any further developments soon, will be the same answer I've given in relation to the perpetrators of the Wilkinson murder, it's just going to have to wait until the Khmer Rouge problem itself can be resolved.
Q:But do you think it's acceptable to the Australian public that the General responsible for the kidnapping has been granted an amnesty?

GE:The abduction?—Well that's General Rin. I have answered the question about General Rin. What I have said and please listen carefully to what I said because I will say it again. It was a defensible strategy to grant Rin an amnesty if his defection was obtained for the purpose of securing his cooperation in getting Paet and in particular, of course, the hostages out. The kidnapping, the abductions were horrendous enough and people died in the course of them, but as a strategy, and it was a strategy that was pursued at the end, to use Rin for the purpose of extracting the hostages, who were believed at that stage to be alive, the amnesty can be seen I think as defensible in that context. But that depends in turn on it being clear that Rin did in good faith enter into those discussions in the knowledge, belief, that the hostages were still alive and that good faith remains to be established. And what I have said and what I say again is that the attitude of Australia and the international community will clearly depend on what the outcome of that assessment is.
Q:What's the difference between a goodwill gesture and paying a ransom?
GE:Well I will let you work that out.

Q:The execution of six Western hostages this year in Cambodia, despite the fact the Khmer Rouge still control a lot of the country, does that mean we are going to have a new phase in the reconstruction of the Cambodia which requires the international community to be much tougher. You mentioned military assistance. Should the ASEAN countries in particular increase their pressure on Thailand to close its border with Cambodia?

GE:As far as the Thai border issue is concerned I think it is very clear that the present Thai Government is giving no encouragement to the continuation of the Khmer Rouge's role and that certainly there is no element that we can discern of central engagement with the Khmer Rouge of a kind that frankly did exist in the past. That is not to say of course that freelance activity by some individual personnel doesn't occur still in that border area We have made it absolutely clear that it was impossible to justify and to the extent that it's within the capacity of the Thai Government to control we hope very much they will do something about it. The ASEAN countries I know have also made their similar position clear on this. I think probably the Thai Government is doing the best it possibly can in very difficult circumstances in that respect.

But you talk in terms of the general situation; I don't think anyone should be alarmist about the general situation. The truth of the matter is after the Peace Process last year the Khmer Rouge were a pretty diminished force, with estimates of not much more than six, eight, ten thousand at most personnel, at the time of the Peace Plan, ie armed personnel, and with those numbers being reduced in the months thereafter by a steady trickle of defections and the situation was certainly looking—the latter part of last year, the first part of this year—extremely containable. There was still a bit of a leopard spots phenomenon with the Khmer Rouge concentrations not only up in the northern and north-western border areas but also in odd pockets of the country including in the Kampot area which we know all too much about. But nonetheless the situation was containable. I think what happened is the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces just got over-confident about their capacity to deal once and for all with the Khmer Rouge problem, mounted this utterly misguided exercise in Anlong Veng

and Pailin which when it was reversed a few weeks later, a few days later, did constitute a terrible blow in circumstances that I have described, and really the months since have involved a process of sort of recovery from that. Now I think that whatever we feel about the implications of the Phnom Vor exercise in the south so far as the hostages were concerned, there is no doubt that the Cambodian military has got its act together sufficiently to be able to mount an encirclement operation and an effective containment operation which has resulted in defections and in effect the defeat of the Khmer Rouge involving some hundreds of Khmer Rouge who are really either surrendering or defecting to the Government, and that exercise I think is capable of repetition in the future provided that the military does further get its act together and become the kind of force we would like to see it. We have got plenty of democratic justification; it's got plenty of justification under the Paris Peace Accords; but it will need international assistance for that to occur.
Q:Are we talking weeks or months for Australian military assistance?

GE:I have said already, you've heard me, that Robert Ray and I will be taking a submission to Cabinet as soon as possible. Now whether that will be possible next week or it will have to wait for the week after I don't know. What the lead time will be thereafter for any assistance, if so decided upon from us or anyone else, is again not something I want to speculate about at this stage but we will tell you some more as soon as a decision has been made.
Q:What kind of military assistance..?

GE:I've described the nature of military assistance. We're not talking about guns or ammunition; we're not talking about lethal materiel. What we are talking about is training and other forms of institutional support to build a constant, disciplined, professional army which regrettably doesn't satisfy those descriptions at the moment.
Q:Have you decided to keep up military assistance because of what's happened in the past few months?

GE:No, the whole question of military assistance was discussed, you may recall, you probably don't, at the Bangkok ASEAN PMC and Regional Forum and was a subject of some publicity at the time. It was in response, this was in July, to what we all perceived to be a deteriorating situation after the debacle in Pailin in April and ourselves, the United States, France, Indonesia, one or two others, discussed then the possibility of some coordinated approach. Obviously things haven't moved quite as fast as we would have like them. Equally obviously this hostage case has had a bit to do with that but hopefully now some of that will be able to be put back on track.
Q:Given your status as a peace maker in Cambodia, did you ever try personally to meet General Paet?

GE:No I didn't try personally to meet with General Paet and there is no particular, useful role I think I could have played. I did consider going personally to Cambodia to discuss the issue with Prime Ministers Ranariddh and Hun Sen and my colleague, Prince Sirivudh and the others on the ground but the judgment was really made that to do so would inevitably just give the whole thing a major new injection of international media and related profile and that given that the nature of the strategy was always one best pursued through keeping the temperature off the situation and quiet, back-stage negotiations, it just didn't seem to be helpful. Never at any stage did we doubt the good intentions of the Cambodian Government; there was ample communication with them. As well as endless communications through Ambassadors and representatives on the ground, I personally had, as I said earlier on today, some six direct contact, either face-to-face at the UN and elsewhere plus the exchange of correspondence and messages from me were going backwards and forwards all the time. We calculated the other day there were some fifty high-level contacts, that's at ambassadorial or ministerial level during the three months with the Cambodian Government and hundreds, probably thousands, of lower level contacts over that period.
Q:What have you learnt from this?

GE:What have we all learnt from this. Hostage situations are very, very difficult to resolve; that there are limitations on what any government can do for one of its citizens when they are caught up in these situations abroad. That is not an experience unique to Australia. It's been well known to be the case in many other situations around the place. We learnt again that the Khmer Rouge are brutal, sadistic, beyond belief; that they will, it appears, stop at nothing in destabilising the country and ultimately destroying it if they are given half a chance. We created the conditions I think with the UN Peace Plan for bringing that situation under control; there has been some deterioration since but the situation is manageable, containable, redressable for it to be contained and redressed though it will need continual strong support from the international community.
Q:Do you think David Wilson's family accept that you did do all you could do?

GE:Well I can only speak on the basis of quite a number of conversations now, including very recent ones with his mother Wendy and his father Peter and I think they do understand and accept that we've done everything we possibly can. David's mother, Wendy, has said as much on the public record, other members of the family of course lashed out; I understand that, I'm not critical of what is a cry of pain, a cry of pain from the heart and it's just something we've got to expect to happen and just ride with it.
Q:Did the Australian Government meet with those who negotiated the release of Melissa Himes?

GE:Oh yes. The NGO concerned and of course the government officials and so on. That was one of the options that was pursued very early on, to look at the possibility of using a non-governmental intermediary to try and resolve the situation. We really did cover the field. We covered the field absolutely; I don't think anyone can suggest anything that could or should have been done that we didn't look at very, very carefully indeed.
Q:(Inaudible)?

GE:I've already said we wouldn't do anything differently. I think in retrospect, I mean I may amend that judgment with further thought in the days ahead but I mean reviewing as we have, you are very, very limited in your options in these situations. I think we did everything we possibly could.
Q:Senator Evans, what do you say to Dr Michael McKinley?
GE:I give Dr McKinley the usual credence which is nil. What has he said this morning?
Q:That the Government should have paid ransom, secondly that General Sanderson should have been an intermediary. . .

GE:Well I've answered the ransom question. Yes I did see that piece this morning. He said "it's nonsense, the bit about encouraging further exercises of this kind, no further tourists are going to go to Cambodia in the light of this"—utterly ignoring the fact that as I have already said to you there are some 300 plus—between 300 and 400 from a rough assessment the other day Australians in the country, and of course there are many other Westerners apart from Australians. So it's a nonsensical proposition and it's not one that would be accepted by any government in the world.

On the question of using General Sanderson. We did use General Sanderson certainly as a sounding board and a source of information intelligence and he made a number of contributions in strategy discussions about how best to advance the situation. We also used, for example, BillKirk. He was on the ground at one stage and he was, people who were following the UN exercise in Cambodia will know, he is an Australian Federal Police officer. He did such an absolutely brilliant job in various parts of the country in creating confidence, including with the Khmer Rouge in handling some very difficult situations, so I think we used every one that was possibly helpful .
Q:Would you warn young Australians going there?

GE:Well there is a revised consular warning that has been out since early August which is even stronger in its terms than the one that was in place at the time David Wilson went there. And I think in short the warning has to be this: it's a very dangerous place to be outside Phnom Penh. Maybe you can fly up to Siem Reap to get into the Angkor complex but don't go by road and really if you want to go anywhere else in the country, by road, make sure it's daylight and that there's properly protected circumstances. I mean it pains me to say this because I would like very much in the interest of the tourist economy, and all the rest of it, to say go for your life, to help the Cambodians but obviously in the present circumstances we can't be that confident and it's going to take some little time yet for security to be fully restored.
Q:You blame the Khmer Rouge. You don't think you have some responsibility?

GE:Well if you'd like to tell me how we could have acted otherwise than we did and what kind of responsibility it is that we ought to be prepared to bear I'd certainly consider that but I'm afraid I can't think of any way that we could have done other than we did.
Q:Are you satisfied with Tony Kevin's role in this?
GE:Yes. What makes you suggest otherwise.
Q:As your ambassador there he was the man on the ground, does he have your complete confidence?

GE:Absolutely. I mean people cannot work miracles. He did his best to work miracles but they didn't happen. It was no fault of his or no fault of any other Australian official. They are an absolutely fine and dedicated and committed bunch and I've got nothing but the highest respect and praise for them.
Q:Was he experienced enough to handle this crisis?

GE:He was fresh to Cambodia, he had only just arrived on the scene but there were plenty of people there who knew the situation very well on the ground and he is a very, very experienced diplomat, negotiator. There are not many people around the world that have had hands-on experience in handling a crisis like this but there's absolutely no foundation for any suggestion that his performance was anything other than first rate.
Q:Was it wise to bring him in in the middle of this case given that he had no experience in that situation?

GE:Well there were plenty of people around who did have experience including the previous ambassador who physically remained in Phnom Penh as a source of advice and continued assistance with this for the duration of his stay there. So I'm sorry, you're off on a frolic that I can't see any point in pursuing.

Q:At one stage you said that you appealed for assistance with countries that formerly had links with the Khmer Rouge. Were you referring to China and do you have any details of what response came back from the China source?

GE:Well since you ask I was referring both to China and to Thailand and we did again pursue those avenues because we knew that there were people there that did have in the past some authority as well as some lines of communication. But we were persuaded that neither the authority nor the lines of communication really continued and it was not something that could usefully be pursued. But I mention it simply to indicate that every possible avenue that you could think of was pursued and thought about, wrestled with, and followed up on the ground in many cases.
Q:Do you stick by the policy of not paying ransoms?
GE:I have nothing more to say on the subject of ransoms. I've said it today and that's it.
Q:Do you want to make a comment on Peter Wilenski?
GE:Yes I would. I was going to do that at the end of the session.

You may not know but Peter Wilenski died this morning after a protracted, prolonged battle with cancer. He was a very close colleague of mine as head of my Department of Foreign Affairs, also Transport and Communications before that and a very close friend for many years.

I will put out a more detailed statement later in the day when I have had time to absorb this and reflect more upon it. But let me say this for your benefit now: Peter Wilenski was a remarkable combination of compassion and intellect and vision and effectiveness. He was a very fine public servant; he was a very great Australian and we will all mourn his passing.
THE ABDUCTION AND MURDER OF DAVID WILSON

1.David Wilson and his French and British companions were among about two hundred people abducted by the Khmer Rouge following an attack on a train travelling from Phnom Penh to the beach resort of Sihanoukville on 26 July. There had been several previous Khmer Rouge attacks on this route. The consular warning then current for Australian travellers in Cambodia urged caution, particularly with travel by road, and recommended that travellers exercise due care and maintain a very high level of security awareness at all times. It urged travellers to contact the Embassy for specific security information. (A German travelling companion of David Wilson in fact declined to take the train trip because he believed that conditions were too dangerous.)

2.When reports reached Phnom Penh of the attack, the Australian Embassy immediately began to investigate and on 28 July, a consular official went to Kampot with British and French officials to establish the facts. The Australia, British and French Embassies reached agreement on a common approach to the Cambodian government and sent diplomatic notes urging a prompt response to the abduction. This set the pattern of future close and cooperative relations between the Embassies and of repeated high level approaches to the Cambodian Government to press for information, including details of what plans the Cambodian Government had to obtain the safe release of the hostages, and to register our concerns that no military action be taken to endanger the hostages' safety.

3.Throughout the crisis we have worked in close cooperation with the British and French governments both in Phnom Penh and in Paris and London. Our approach from the start was that the Cambodian Government was responsible for the conduct of negotiations and for the safety and ultimately the safe release of the hostages: no other approach was possible given Cambodia's status as a sovereign nation. We could make representations, offer advice, warn and encourage, but we were never in a position to direct or control operations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Contacts with the Hostages and Ransom Demands

SPEECH.PARA: 4.It was quickly established that the hostages were on Phnom Vor (Vine Mountain), a long time Khmer Rouge stronghold about 20kms to the north-east of Kampot. On 30 July an Australian Embassy officer sent a message to the hostages which received a reply. On 31 July the Foreign Minister Prince Sirivudh received the first letter from David Wilson which included a demand from Paet the KR commander, for a ransom of $50,000 in gold for each hostage.
5.A trilateral Australian, French and UK team was quickly established in Kampot, which included consular officers and members of the Australian Federal Police and New Scotland Yard.

6.The Australian Government's policy on the paying of ransoms is well known. To concede any willingness to pay ransoms is simply an invitation to abduct other citizens for the same criminal purpose. The Cambodian government was advised of Australian Government policy on this issue on several occasions. Our position is shared unequivocally by the French and British Governments.

7.The initial hope, nonetheless, was that negotiations between the Cambodian Government and General Paet would eventually secure the hostages' release, perhaps on a similar basis to the Melissa Himes case where, after 41 days captivity, Ms Himes was released on the basis of a `goodwill gesture' involving the provision of some building materials, food and medicines and an undertaking by her NGO employer to complete a local village well project.

8.During August, we were confident of the hostages' well-being as numerous messages were received and food and medicine were passed to them. The difficulties surrounding negotiations were, however, significantly increased by a large and intense media presence (much exceeding that in the Himes case) which served to raise the perceived value of the hostages in the eyes of the Khmer Rouge and tended to undermine channels of communication between official Cambodian government negotiators and Paet. At one stage, the difficulties became so great that the Cambodian government barred the media from Kampot—and at the same time demanded the withdrawal of the consular team. The three governments made vigorous representations for the return of their representatives to Kampot, which occurred on 5 September.

9.The Khmer Rouge leadership soon realised the value of exploiting the hostages for political purposes and demanded that the involved governments cease to provide military assistance to Cambodia. They set a date of 31 August after which they claimed that they would not be responsible for the safety of the hostages. The Australian Government did not accede to (nor did it reply to) these demands: we were not prepared, and no government ever could be, to capitulate to this crude blackmail. We did nonetheless, in order to avoid any further possible provocation, decide to make no further public reference to the provision of military assistance for the duration of the crisis.

10.When this ploy failed, the Khmer Rouge leadership switched their attention to the Royal Cambodian Government, demanding the repeal of the National Assembly law of 7 July outlawing the Khmer Rouge. The Australian Government was in full agreement with the Cambodian government that it was impossible for the latter to accept such blackmail. It was yet another attempt by the Khmer Rouge to shift the responsibility for their criminal acts on to someone else.

11.The Australian Government considered all options for the release of the hostages including the use of Australian forces, and the involvement of an NGO or individual or representative of another country to act as an independent mediator or in some other way to facilitate a solution. For one reason or another these options were unavailable or ruled out, and together with Britain and France we concluded that the only way to resolve the affair was through the efforts of the Cambodian Government and military acting with the close involvement of our respective diplomatic representatives in Phnom Penh and the trilateral consular team in Kampot.

12.The Cambodian armed forces began military activity around Phnom Vor in mid-August which consisted mainly of periodic shelling and of drawing the military cordon tighter around the Khmer Rouge-held area. There was never, as portrayed in the press, a big battle at Phnom Vor: there were a series of skirmishes and fairly erratic artillery attacks, which involved a strategy of gradually eroding the amount of territory held by Paet and his group and reducing their access to supplies. This was an understandable strategy, combined as it was with the parallel approach of negotiations.

13.It needs to be appreciated that the Cambodian Government had dual objectives in this operation: not only to secure the release of the Western hostages, but also to achieve the destruction or neutralisation of the Khmer Rouge presence in the area, which had long constituted both a menace to travellers and an obstacle to the economic development of the region. These were both entirely legitimate objectives, but had the potential to be in tension with each other.

14.On 24 occasions during the crisis, Australian representatives, acutely conscious of the problem of potential military overreach, discussed or received assurances from the Cambodian political and military authorities that no military action would be taken which would endanger the hostages or cut off the option of negotiation. I made six representations at Prime Ministerial and Foreign Ministerial level which covered the military as well as other aspects of the hostage case.

15.On the assumption that the most likely date of the execution of the hostages was around 28 September, the reports presently available to us suggest that only relatively low levels of military activity were then occurring, although a minor ground offensive by RCAF Special Forces had commenced a week or so earlier with the intention of moving encirclement forward while also improving the effectiveness of the restriction of Khmer Rouge movement and resupply.

16.The most substantial military action against Paet's stronghold was that commenced on or about 19 October, which culminated in the RCAF fully occupying the territory: this offensive appears to have commenced at least three weeks after the hostages' death. Paet himself, with a group of some ten people, including his family, appears to have escaped the cordon on or about 27 October. Whether he achieved that with or without the assistance of elements of the RCAF remains to be established.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Loss of Contact and Defection Strategy

SPEECH.PARA: 17.The last letter from the hostages was dated 29 August, and on 2 September a video made by Indochine television became available. As time wore on after loss of contact with the hostages, we became increasingly worried about their health and circumstances. We continued to press the Cambodian authorities to obtain proof of life and continue with negotiations. This took the form of countless meetings with political and military figures both at the central and local levels in which various options were discussed and information requested. The Cambodian government continued to be responsible for the conduct of the crisis, but the representatives of the three governments had an active input.

18.By the latter part of September, the Cambodian Government was pursuing a strategy that combined military pressure with persuading members of the Khmer Rouge group with Paet to defect. Our representatives continually urged that the negotiations continue, but it now seems doubtful whether Paet ever had any intention of entering into serious negotiations for the release of the hostages.

19.The defection strategy succeeded to the extent that many hundreds of Khmer Rouge soldiers and associated civilians (family members etc) eventually left the mountain. The most important defector, on 15 October, was General Choeuk Rin, self-confessedly the person leading the original train assault and responsible for the abduction, who in turn became involved in negotiations for Paet's own defection accompanied by the hostages. Whether Rin's involvement in such negotiations was in good faith (with him genuinely believing at the time that the hostages were alive) and such as to justify his amnesty in the eyes of the international community, remains to be established.

20.The weeks from early September to mid-October, when there was no news of the hostages, were intensely worrying for the family and deeply frustrating for the government teams in Kampot, Phnom Penh and Canberra trying to assist in the resolution of the crisis. We tried all possible avenues, including appealing for assistance to countries which formerly had links with the Khmer Rouge. King Sihanouk was approached by ourselves through the Governor-General and the French, and the good offices of the UN Secretary-General were invoked. But all to no avail.

21.During almost the entire crisis, the trilateral consular team was on the ground in Kampot in very close daily contact with the local officials and military. When defectors and Cambodians released from Paet's camp emerged, they began to debrief them. On 18 October they received a detailed and credible account from a civilian, himself a former prisoner of Paet, stating that he had witnessed events that led him to conclude that the hostages had been killed in early September. The Kampot trilateral team (which included senior and experienced police officers) was inclined to accept the substance of this witness's account, and David Wilson's parents and the French and British families were informed. On 26 October the Kampot team received a briefing from a senior Cambodian officer, General Meak May, based on defector statements, that the hostages had been killed on or about 27 September: this account gave a specific grid reference for the location of the hostages' graves, and generally was even more detailed and credible than the first report. I was informed shortly after officials in Canberra received this report, and on the strength of this combined evidence (taking into account a mass of other surrounding information), and in the knowledge that the family had been informed, I made my statement in Ulaan Bataar.

22.The confusing and often conflicting reports that followed were highly regrettable and, of course, only increased the agony of the Wilson family. So far as possible these reports were followed up by the Embassy in Phnom Penh and the Kampot team. Tragically, no proof of life emerged, and on the evening of 31 October, after I appealed to Prime Minister Hun Sen for his personal intervention in the case, news emerged that a grave site had been discovered. The bodies were exhumed and identified on 2 November.

23.I have made the Australian Government stand on this perfectly clear, both publicly and directly to the Cambodian Government. We want the Cambodian authorities to take every step within their power to bring those responsible for the murders to justice. Second Prime Minister Hun Sen replied to me, on 2 November, in reassuring terms on this matter, saying `I share with you the idea that Mr Paet who orchestrated the abduction be found and brought to trial as a murderer'. Whether, in all the circumstances now prevailing in Cambodia, the apprehension of Paet and any others believed responsible is a practical possibility, remains to be seen.

24.I have also made clear that we want those responsible for the original abduction brought to justice as well. As indicated above, a particular question arises about the status of General Rin in this respect: if his defection was secured on the basis that he, in good faith, would seek to ensure the defection of Paet himself, with the hostages, then an amnesty might be regarded as an unpalatable but not unreasonable measure, one familiar enough in law enforcement elsewhere. But the attitude of Australia and the international community will be affected by whether that good faith is established.

25.Many Australian officials have worked on this tragic case from the outset, and I would like to single out for special thanks those most closely involved, who have worked in the most gruelling and harrowing circumstances seven days a week nearly every week for the past three months. In Phnom Penh they include our Ambassador, Tony Kevin and Counsellor, Paul Grigson; members of the rotating Consular/Australian Federal Police team in Kampot, George Fraser, Alastair Adams, Col Rowley and Dale Small; in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra, Robert Hamilton, Stephanie Shwabsky, Anna Kalas, John Oliver and Elizabeth Wetherell; from the AFP, John Ireland; and working both in the Kampot team and in Canberra, Wayne Fulton (DFAT) and Chris Eaton (AFP).
Gareth Evans
3 November 1994
NEWS RELEASE
Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans
2 November 1994
David Wilson

On behalf of the Australian Government, I wish to express my sincere condolences and deepest sympathy to the family of David Wilson who, it is now confirmed beyond reasonable doubt, has been murdered by the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.

I wish also to extend the Government's condolences to the families of Mr Wilson's two travelling companions, Mark Slater of Great Britain and Jean-Michel Braquet of France, who have also been killed by the Khmer Rouge.

Mr Wilson and his companions were kidnapped from a train travelling from Phnom Penh to the coastal town of Sihanoukville on 26 July. Many Cambodians and several Vietnamese people were kidnapped at the same time and some of them have also been killed, equally distressingly for their families.

The hearts of the Australian public have gone out to David Wilson's family over the months that they have waited and hoped for his release. I know that they will find it difficult to understand why their son and brother has been killed so senselessly. I share their grief and outrage at this barbaric and pointless act.

Responsibility for these deaths rests squarely with the Khmer Rouge. Their continued pursuit of power through terrorist tactics and their policy of kidnapping innocent travellers for ransom, or for attempted political gain, has caused the death of David Wilson and his friends, as it did those of Kellie Wilkinson and hers. The Cambodian people have, for years, suffered at the hands of the Khmer Rouge. It is regrettable that it has taken the recent tragic deaths of young foreign tourists in Cambodia to bring home to many outside Cambodia the brutal lengths to which the Khmer Rouge will go in their attempts to destabilise the country, with no regard for the individual, human rights or the rule of law.

There is little comfort that I can give to David Wilson's family in these circumstances. I can only express my sincere admiration for the courage that they have shown, and their understanding of and sensitivity to the real difficulties that surrounded the efforts to secure David Wilson's safe release.
I am sure that all Australians join me in extending their deepest sympathy to the family on their tragic loss.
CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the government is giving further consideration to the question of military assistance. I imagine that we will be in a position within two or three weeks at the outside to announce some decision in that respect. It may well be appropriate at that time to go into some further detail about the military situation and the nature of the government's response to it. For the record now, I will add a little more detail to indicate that we are not wholly unaware of the nature of the situation.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that the Khmer Rouge does not pose a direct military threat to the viability of the whole Cambodian government and system but it does pose a serious security problem. It presently controls less than 10 per cent of Cambodian territory, in our estimate, in which probably only three per cent of the population is located.

Traditional areas of control are mainly in the west and north-west of the country, in the Thai and Lao border areas. However, there are a number of other rather smaller so-called leopard spots across the country which have formed the base areas for small roving bands of Khmer Rouge to carry out guerilla and bandit activities in surrounding areas. One such base was the Vine Mountain area.

Our current assessment of Khmer Rouge strength is that there are not more than around 6,000 front-line fighting men. Some estimates put it as low as 5,000. With an accompanying group of other personnel, such as porters and so on, the number of people who are usable in a battle situation, albeit not all as soldiers, is something like 10,000. That represents a very considerable drop in KR strength from the situation estimated in 1991 at the time the Paris agreements were signed, when the figure for fighting men was of the order of 25,000-plus, and the situation last year when the figure was around 10,000. I think it would be appropriate to go into more detail about this, but on a later occasion. On that basis, and since I have run out of time, I will leave it at that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette this day, relating to human rights in Tibet.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chamarette asked Senator Gareth Evans whether he had spoken to Mr Qiao Shi about the Tibetan situation, whether he had complained about it and whether he had drawn to the attention of Mr Qiao Shi the gross violations of human rights in Tibet—not that Mr Qiao would need to have that drawn to his attention. The Senate should know that Mr Qiao Shi is the former head of the Communist Party secret police security organisation. This is the man who in June 1988 called for `merciless repression' of the Tibetans who showed any sign of opposition to PRC control in that country.

PARA.TAB: This is the man who established a secret unit of the Chinese People's Army, an organisation responsible for the many deaths that occurred in March 1989 in the peaceful demonstration in Lhasa. Did Senator Gareth Evans ask questions of this man? He had the opportunity to do so today and he did not. I am not one to suggest that governments should not talk to governments but, as a member of parliament, I was very concerned today. I did not know that Mr Qiao Shi and his delegation were going to be in the President's gallery. I had been invited by the Presiding Officers to attend a particular function but, when I heard that members of the press were to be present, I decided not to go.

Today we have been confronted with this situation. I do not know how many people knew that these people would be in this chamber. I did not. I felt in conscience that the only thing I could do was to walk out of this place for a short time. That is not necessarily a matter for the minister; it is, of course, a matter that I will need to discuss with the Presiding Officer.

But the government has encouraged this parliament and the Presiding Officers to fete this man, Qiao Shi. Obviously, people can change their minds. It should have been up to the minister today to ask this man whether he had changed his mind about Tibet—whether anything is going to happen to resolve the situation in Tibet; to resolve the situation of the Dalai Lama; to overcome the critical violations of human rights that have been exerted on the Tibetan population by the PRC government. Here was a golden opportunity.

The minister said, `Oh, you will be able to raise that at some other stage.' Well, he had the opportunity. Often, the best opportunity is during the first visit. That then impresses upon the mind of that person the priority that is given by the interlocutor about the particular issues that he wants to raise.

Clearly this was not a matter of the highest priority for Senator Evans, our foreign affairs minister. Otherwise, Senator Evans would have raised it and made it perfectly clear to this man, who was responsible for so much suffering in Tibet, that it was a matter of high priority for him and for his government. I felt Senator Evans's response to Senator Chamarette was disappointing indeed and something that should certainly be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say one more word on this subject, although I did respond at question time as best I could. This was my first meeting with Mr Qiao Shi. Time was limited. I had unfortunately, as a result of various meteorological accidents, missed the opportunity to meet him both in Beijing and last night on arrival in Australia, both of which would have been opportunities to establish contact and at least to cover a number of the agenda items which had to be squeezed into a very tight time frame this morning.

PARA.TAB: One of the particular agenda items which I did spend a great deal of time on this morning, which nobody asked me about today, was the case of James Peng, the Australian citizen, and his treatment by the Chinese court system. In the context of the time available and the amount of attention that was given to that particular human rights/due process issue, it was simply not possible to get into a more extended discussion of human rights more generally, other than for me to say that we wanted to have the opportunity to keep alive the human rights dialogue.

It is perfectly possible for me in these contexts to throw in a one-word or a one-phrase reference and thereafter come out beating my chest and proclaiming that I have raised an issue. I do not regard myself as having raised an issue unless I do so in proper and substantive terms, in such a way as to make clear the nature of the concern and what we think ought to be done about it. It is not a ritualistic or formulaic business, but enough was said for me to make the point that human rights issues remain very much on our agenda. I think for me to get as much in as I did about human rights issues in that particular case, in the context of a discussion which was basically about GATT and APEC and a number of other current economic policy issues and which did take place in the context of—given the amount of time that is involved in translation and so on—a very short meeting, I do not think I quite deserve the vituperation that has been hurled upon me.

I look forward to the opportunity on some subsequent occasion—maybe during the course of the remainder of this visit, maybe subsequently—to raise this issue, as I have, quite directly and without any hesitation at all, with Qian Qichen, Li Peng and other senior leaders in the Chinese system. It is not a matter of being reluctant to do so; it is a matter of being effective when one does so. One picks one's moment in order to be effective.

I suppose the other point that ought to be made for the public record is that Mr Qiao Shi is someone whose reputation, whatever it might have been at the time of the Tibet situation, at the time of Tiananmen was that of someone who was unquestionably on the side of the moderates, on the side of those who were very cautious indeed about going down any more of an oppressive path. It is a very complex situation—the evolution of these human rights issues, values and principles in China. I simply do not think we ought to be too quick to rush to judgment about the contribution that any particular individual might have made in these situations.

While the record in Tibet is a deeply unhappy one so far as the Chinese government as a whole is concerned, I do not leap, without further evidence, to conclusions, either about the personal role of this particular visitor or about his present attitudes. I think it would be more helpful in terms of looking for a constructive solution to the problems in Tibet if some others did not leap quite so quickly to conclusions, either.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 1 November 1994 of former senator Alexander Elliot Davidson Lillico, a senator for the state of Tasmania from 1959 to 1974.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 1 November 1994, of Alexander Elliot Davidson Lillico, Senator for the State of Tasmania from 1959 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Alexander Lillico was born on 5 September—in fact, we shared a birthday; probably the only thing we did have in common—1905 at Penguin District, Tasmania. He was educated at Devonport state and high schools and at Scotch College, Melbourne. He devoted around 40 years of his life to the public, serving in local, state and federal government.

PARA.TAB: From 1934 to 1960 he was a councillor of the Kentish Municipal Council. In 1943 he was elected to the Tasmanian State Legislative Council, representing Meander, and in 1958 he was elected to this place as a senator for Tasmania. He began his first term in 1959 and served until 1974. In fact, he left before even our longest serving member, the father of the house, Senator Harradine, arrived. So Senator Lillico would not have been known, otherwise than personally, to any member of this chamber in his or her senatorial capacity. Nonetheless, of course, it is a matter of profound regret whenever any one of our former members passes away.

Former Senator Lillico served on a number of committees, among them the Senate Committee on Primary and Secondary Industry and Trade. As a farmer and grazier he fully appreciated the difficulties experienced by people on the land and often spoke on those subjects in this place. On behalf of the government, I extend to his daughter, Barbara, and sons, Elliot and Graeme, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition I wish to support the motion and add my personal condolences to the family of the late Alexander Elliot Davidson Lillico. Mr Lillico was a Liberal senator for Tasmania between 1959 and 1974. He passed away last Tuesday after a long fight with illness. He lived to the ripe old age of 89 and his death marked the end of a remarkable and diverse political career.

PARA.TAB: Alexander Lillico was born in the small north-west Tasmanian town of Penguin in September 1905. He attended the Devonport primary and high schools and Scotch College in Melbourne before moving to a farming property at Wilmot, south of Devonport. His first move into a political career came in 1934 when he was elected as a councillor to his local council of Kentish. His service as a councillor was to extend over 27 years and included at various times a period of eight years as warden.

In 1943, Mr Lillico entered state parliament by winning the Legislative Council seat of Meander in northern Tasmania. As is not unusual in Tasmanian politics, Alex Lillico was continuing a family tradition of community service. In fact, when he entered the Legislative Council, it was to sit alongside his father, Sir Alex Lillico, who was already a member of the state upper house. They were one of the first father and son combinations in the same house in an Australian parliament.

After 16 years in the Tasmanian Legislative Council, Mr Lillico was approached by the Liberal Party to head the Liberal Senate ticket at the next Senate election. He was duly elected and took his seat in July 1959. He was re-elected in 1964 and 1970 and finally retired from political life in 1974.

A strong states' rights advocate, Alex Lillico concentrated mainly on primary industry and trade issues. During 1967 and 1968, he played a significant part in the Senate Select Committee on the Container Method of Handling Cargoes. He was also an active member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade from 1970 to 1974. It was noticeable that during the debate in the early 1970s over the establishment of the New Zealand-Australia free trade agreement, Mr Lillico fought hard to protect the interests of primary producers and processors, especially his fellow Tasmanian pea and bean growers.

Former Senator Lillico, like so many Tasmanian senators over the years, was a rebel. Like one of his contemporaries, Tasmanian Liberal Senator Sir Reginald Wright, Alexander Lillico was prepared to oppose his party's dictates if he saw the need. In 1965, for example, he was prepared to vote against the party's wish to pass a bill for a referendum to break the nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate.
Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Boswell—he stood up for Tasmania very proudly and very well. He could see no justification for more members of the House of Representatives at that time. In one of his speeches during the 1969 budget debate, Senator Lillico praised the strength and fairness of the Australian constitution, which he believed gave a fair balance of powers between the central government and the states. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hasten to add that I believe in the states. I believe that one of the worst fates that could befall the Commonwealth would be the centralisation of all government power here in Canberra. I say without any hesitation that the states should continue to function as independently as is possible.
Although never a minister, Mr Lillico was an extremely hardworking backbencher. He was also a worthy representative of his constituents, whether at a state, local or federal level.

PARA.TAB: Alexander Lillico followed his retirement with 13 years of nursing his wife, Gladys, until her death in 1987—such was the devotion of that married couple. His own health started to deteriorate about 10 years ago, and he spent his final years living in a hostel close to his devoted daughter, Barbara. To my friends Barbara McLennan and her husband, Geoff, I offer my deepest sympathy, as I do to other members of Mr Lillico's family and friends. Alexander Lillico served the people of Tasmania well at all levels of government. I sincerely support the motion of condolence at his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Liberal senators, I wish to join with Senator Watson in expressing regret at the death of former Tasmanian Liberal Senator Alexander Lillico. Senator Watson has covered most of the matters that I wished to touch upon. Nevertheless, I want to record my recognition of what appears to have been an incredible life of public service.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lillico served the local community as a member of the Kentish Municipal Council from 1934 to 1960. He served in the Legislative Council of his state parliament from 1943 to 1958, and he then served as a senator for Tasmania in the federal parliament from 1959 to 1974. It was a lifetime commitment to public service that deserves recognition and appreciation.

I note that in his maiden speech in this place, like all good Tasmanians, he spoke of the importance of the Senate as a vehicle to protect the interests of the smaller states, Tasmania in particular. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if it so happened that this chamber were abolished or its powers so reduced as to render it of little legislative value, the smaller States of the Commonwealth would have little more than token representation in another place.
Alexander Lillico was quite right: this chamber has a major responsibility in ensuring the protection of the interests of those in smaller states, the smallest of which, of course, is Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to recognise his contribution whilst in this place to matters concerning the rural community. Issues such as the price of wool, the financial returns of rural properties and the difficulties faced by rural producers in Tasmania are issues that remain current today. Nevertheless, during his time here he was a great advocate for the interests of the rural community, the Tasmanian rural community in particular.

I also place on record our recognition of his service on various committees in this place: the Standing Committee on Primary and Secondary Industry and Trade, in particular, where again, as I understand it, he fought for the cause of rural producers in Tasmania; also, the Senate Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications; and the Senate Select Committee on the Container Method of Handling Cargoes.
As I said, it was a lifetime of public service that we should recognise with great appreciation. With that sentiment, I send our deepest sympathy to Alexander Lillico's family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the government. Sixteen years as a Liberal senator for Tasmania, 15 years as a member of the Tasmanian Legislative Council and 27 years in local government—Alexander Lillico's remarkable contribution to public life spanned well over half a century. Born in Penguin, Tasmania, in 1905, Alexander Lillico initially attended Devonport primary and high schools. He completed his education at Scotch College, Melbourne, and then embarked on a farming career.

PARA.TAB: In a career that was to closely parallel that of his distinguished father, Sir Alexander Lillico, Alexander Lillico commenced his political career by becoming a councillor in the Kentish municipality. This involvement lasted 27 years, eight of which were served as mayor. In 1943 Alexander Lillico won the Legislative Council seat of Meander. For the first time in Tasmania's history there was a father and son team in the same house of parliament.

After 15 years involvement in Tasmanian state politics, Alexander Lillico entered the federal sphere with his election to the Senate in 1958. During his 16 years in the Senate, he was a hardworking committee member, serving on the Senate Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications for 12 years, the Senate Standing Committee on Primary and Secondary Industry and Trade, which later changed its name to the industry and trade committee, and the Senate Select Committee on the Container Method of Handling Cargoes. He was also a member of the Australian delegation to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in 1966.

Through his work on the industry and trade committee, Senator Lillico was a tireless champion of Tasmanian industry, raising such issues as foreign ownership and unfair trading practices. After 16 years of service in the Senate to the people of Tasmania, Alexander Lillico retired in 1974 and stepped down from public life. Alexander Lillico will be remembered for his many years of service to the people of Tasmania through his long and tireless involvement in local, state and federal politics. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to Alexander Lillico's family and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the Australian Democrats with the condolences being expressed on the death of former Senator Lillico. As a member of a farming family and a proud Tasmanian citizen, Senator Lillico was known as somewhat of a north-west identity. He could hardly have been anything else, having been a member of the Kentish council for 26 or 27 years, depending on the source; mayor of that area for eight years; a member of the Legislative Council, representing the area again; and then a senator for Tasmania with a particular interest in agricultural matters, which are of such importance to that part of the north-west coast of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lillico observed in his first speech in 1959 that `overall we cannot have enduring prosperity in Australia unless the primary industries are prosperous and expanding'.

SPEECH.PARA: In that regard he recommended orientation towards the markets to our north. But I do not think that at that time he would have recommended the style of market expansion which the government is pursuing these days. At the time, Senator Lillico was not a subscriber to the theories of economic rationalism or the concept of a level playing field, elusive as that may be even these days. He was, I believe rightly, concerned about foreign-controlled food processing plants operating here but with little loyalty to Australian growers. As far back as 1972, he warned that the inclusion of peas and beans in the New Zealand-Australia free trade agreement was `an act of lunacy'. We can only guess what he thought of the Arnott and Campbell soups affair. He would have noticed it happening, but we did not think to consult him. If we had, we may have had a different impression of it.

PARA.TAB: Through his career in the Senate, Senator Lillico maintained his position, representing the north-west farmers with determination against the US meat lobby, multinational canners, freezers and processors, and those he saw as selling out Australia's hard-won food markets. I think the Senate misses the sort of input that he would have had in the debates that we have on those very same topics. I express sincere sympathy to former Senator Lillico's family and surviving friends and, again, associate the party with the condolences being expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Gareth Evans said, although none of us were here when Alexander Lillico retired in 1974—some of us came in 1975—his reputation was quite widespread throughout the Commonwealth. Senator Watson mentioned the nexus referendum. The fight that was put up by a handful of people at that time in this chamber carried the day right throughout Australia. The nexus referendum was defeated. It was the logic of those people that devised that case—the understanding that they had, not only of the parliamentary structure but also of human nature—that was important. That was important so far as Alexander Lillico was concerned. He not only understood human nature but, more importantly, served human beings. He served the people in his locality. He served not only the people in his area of the north-west coast but people throughout the whole of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Alexander Lillico was one who was concerned about the small states and the rights of the smaller states. He said, as Senator Watson observed, that he felt that the constitution was a fair balance in our system of federalism between the central power in Canberra and the states. He said that prior to the case in the High Court which appeared to clothe the external affairs power with a far more resplendent raiment than that which was envisaged by the founders of federation.

I wonder what he would be saying now about the use by the Commonwealth government of the external affairs power over recent years. Alexander Lillico was very much admired by his constituents and, in particular, very much appreciated by the people on the north-west coast. I wish to join with my parliamentary colleagues in the Senate in conveying my deepest sympathy and condolences to his family and friends and, by standing here, to acknowledge the passing of a great representative of the state of Tasmania and a great human being.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.
