DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 20 October 1994.
Clause 3.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—The committee is considering the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 and the Greens (WA) amendments Nos F1 to F8, moved together by Senator Chamarette. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Chamarette was to speak to her amendments. We had finished amendments to section 191C and were moving on to consider section 191D, which deals with grants to individuals and trustees as well as corporations. If it is convenient, I can speak to the opposition's proposed amendments to this section. The relevant opposition amendments are Nos 4, 8, 15, 16, 21, 26, 28, 29, 43—
—Perhaps I might interrupt, Senator Ellison, so that there is no confusion. We are dealing with Senator Chamarette's amendments Nos F1 to F8.

—There is no confusion. Might I say that if we are going to have this proposition rammed down our throats, as I sincerely hope we will not, we would prefer it to be in the form to be moved by the opposition, rather than that by the Greens. It would be helpful if Senator Ellison, without formally moving the amendments at this stage, were to continue describing the terms of the opposition's amendments and giving his reasons for them. It would be convenient to debate them together on that basis.
—Senator Ellison, is that acceptable?

—That is acceptable. The opposition's and Greens' amendments deal with much the same issue. Amendment No. 4 deals with section 191D(1). It relates to the grant of interests in land not only to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations, but also to Aboriginal persons, Torres Strait Islanders or trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts. This expands the ability to make grants not just to corporations but to individuals as well, and also to the various trusts that we find from state to state.

PARA.TAB: This principle is most important. It came up during the native title debate, when there was a great deal of debate on whether native title should be able to be afforded just to corporations or to individuals as well. During the course of the hearing by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, evidence was given that there were sectors of the Aboriginal community which definitely were in favour of the ability for individuals—and by that I include groups—to be granted land as well. There is an ongoing debate about whether individuals or groups can be included rather than just corporations.

In relation to my home state of Western Australia, for instance, there are a lot of groups which are quite small—made up of family members—and which are not necessarily incorporated. The legislation might well force groups which do not want to be become incorporated to do so. I fully respect their wishes to remain as individuals. Forcing some false corporate entity on them is not within the spirit of this legislation. Therefore, there is great merit in including grants to individuals.

Similarly, opposition amendment No. 8 deals with the priority that the Indigenous Land Corporation must give to making a grant within a reasonable time after the acquisition. That is merely a flow-on from the principle I have just enunciated, that individuals be granted the land within a reasonable time of the acquisition being made. Amendment No. 15, too, is simply consequential on including individuals and groups. That is where the Indigenous Land Corporation, or its subsidiary as the case requires, considers that it no longer needs to hold the interest for the purpose of making a grant of interest to corporations, individuals or the trusts that I have mentioned.

Amendment 16 again deals with acquiring land for the purpose of making grants to individuals and trusts as well. Amendment 21 is also consequential. It deals with the acquisition of interests in land in the regional area for the purpose of making grants to the individuals and the trusts that I have mentioned. The remaining amendments are consequential, but I will touch on them for the record because they deal with discrete areas and should be mentioned. Amendment No. 28 deals with section 191T and is designed to omit the words `body corporate'. This provision currently limits the land holding to a corporation only. Amendment No. 29 is tied in with this and again deals with the words `body corporate' and substitutes the word `person'.

We are advised by the clerk that in this context the word `person' can include both a corporation and an individual. We are simply dropping the words `body corporate' and replacing them with the word `person'. That is an all-inclusive definition. Amendments 43, 44 and 45 deal with section 193R, again dropping the words `body corporate' and replacing them with the word `person'. The word `person' includes the body corporate.

Amendment No. 50 deals with the definition of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust, including the sort of trust that I mentioned earlier. Since trusts are referred to in the legislation, we need to touch on the definition. Our definition refers to trusts in which a majority of the beneficial interests are held by Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander persons, an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation, or a combination of any of those.

This amendment broadens the eligibility for receipt of assistance under this bill. Various trusts are involved in a number of states and while persons do not need any definition, trusts do. We have also referred to trusts in our other amendments and that is another reason for this amendment.

Honourable senators will notice that the amendment uses the words `a majority of the beneficial interests are held'. It is therefore possible to have a situation where Aboriginal people have a beneficial interest in a trust in which other people, members of the wider community, also have a beneficial interest. With this bill, that trust could be the recipient of assistance.

Another amendment relates to the granting of a benefit to Aboriginal people where they might not be the sole owners of the land; that is, where they could venture into a partnership with other members of the community. More and more these days, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are exploring joint ventures and partnerships. In some of the more remote areas of Australia a good deal of eco-tourism is going on. Where an Aboriginal group wants to establish a station for tourism purposes, and other members of the community are in partnership with them, they would not be precluded from receiving benefits under this legislation. So the thrust of this bag of amendments is to include individual Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders so that grants are not simply made to a corporation—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the main reason?

—The reason is to be inclusive not exclusive. Some Aboriginal people do not want to run their affairs in the style of a corporation. They run their affairs in remote areas by way of their family or tribe—
—A trust arrangement.

—Some have a trust arrangement and some do not. This amendment allows some choice in how they run their affairs before they are eligible to receive assistance. Under the proposed legislation, if they do not have a corporation they cannot receive assistance.

PARA.TAB: The legislation was intended to assist those who have been dispossessed, not artificial corporations. I make no criticism of the inclusion of corporations because they have their place. All we are saying is that it should not be mandatory to incorporate before benefits can be received.

Evidence was received last year when the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee took evidence on the Native Title Bill and more recently when there was an inquiry into this bill to the effect that there are Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who want this amendment. They want a facility through which individuals and groups can receive the assistance intended for them. That is straightforward and commonsense.

We can still have the same level of accountability and the same controls over spending and over the criteria for making grants. This does not take away from the working of the legislation. Indeed, I think this sits better with the preamble to the Native Title Act. That preamble did not talk about dispossessed Aboriginal corporations; it talked about dispossessed Aboriginal people, human beings. That is why this is so important.

I think it was Noel Pearson of the Cape York Land Council who said that he found it unfortunate that this notion of corporation was being forced on the Aboriginal community more and more. It is very much an Anglo-Saxon common law creation, not one that is known in Aboriginal law. Those are the reasons for the amendments. I do not think I can advance them further.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I introduced the Greens' amendments F1 to F8, as recorded in the Hansard, I said that the Greens agreed with the opposition amendments, except for No. 50 and I think I might have said that we would go with the entire F series of Greens' amendments. I am now happy to move away from that position and support the opposition amendments, with the exception of No. 50. But I seek some clarification.

PARA.TAB: Providing amendment No. 50 is put to a separate vote and our amendment F9 is then put, the Greens will totally agree with the opposition's position on the basis that it should be a matter of self-determination whether the land acquired under this fund is available to corporations, persons or trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts. We believe that that allows for an important degree of flexibility and freedom. I therefore indicate our support for the opposition amendments, except for No. 50, if that is what we are debating at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to untangle the questions of process before getting on to the substance of this debate. As a matter of drafting, there is no basic difference between the Greens' and the coalition's amendments, but there is in terms of what they are trying to achieve. I am advised that, in terms of drafting style, consistency and completeness, the coalition's draft does its mischief rather more effectively than the Greens'. Under those circumstances, we would prefer the coalition's amendments to be tested, save and except for the particular point that Senator Chamarette has raised about amendment No. 50.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, if we are to have a reference to trusts, we would much prefer the Greens' amendment F9 to the opposition's No. 50 because there is a significant difference between the Green's proposal whereby, for a trust to be a beneficiary, each individual beneficiary must be an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander. That is to be much preferred to the opposition's position, which merely requires a majority. That is a classic recipe for further dilution of the land base, which some of us at least are trying to preserve.

Procedurally, the best way through this might be for Senator Chamarette to withdraw her amendments, to the extent that she has already moved them, except for amendment F9, to the extent that she has already moved that. If she has not moved it, she might do so. We could then vote on that particular issue. If that vote gets up, the opposition can move its amendment with its version of the trust definition included in it. We can then move to a vote on the substance of the issue without these drafting complications.

Moving to the substance of the issue, might I say that the only good thing about this particular amendment is that it is moved in a fashion that enables the land corporation to make grants to individuals rather than requiring it to do so. It is only discretionary. It extends the range of options it has. It does not force it to give land to individuals.

We would argue very strongly that the principle of group ownership of land—or in the context of a loan or whatever—should be maintained. The intention of the land fund is and always has been, in relation to its acquisition functions, to provide community benefits. Ownership by corporations, which is the legal device to reflect that principle of community ownership, does strengthen accountability through the statutory requirements which are placed on such bodies, including the need for them to publicly report on their activities. So quite apart from anything else, the particular principle of accountability which the opposition is anxious for us to maintain would be much weakened if the options are opened up in the non-corporate directions which the opposition and the Greens are urging upon us.

Moreover, a further point, and a really very crucial one, is that vesting of ownership in corporations ensures that land purchased remains part of the Aboriginal land base. I hope that Senator Chamarette and anyone else who might be minded to go down this other path takes very good notice of this. Vesting in corporations ensures that land purchased remains part of the Aboriginal land base for use by future generations of indigenous people. It is, of course, the case that Aboriginal people traditionally invariably held a communal form of title—moreover, an inalienable communal form of title. They are totally familiar with operating on a corporate basis. It is totally consistent with Aboriginal custom and tradition so far as land ownership is concerned. Anyone who purports to be sensitive to Aboriginal concerns and responsive to those concerns in this legislation ought to be prepared to accept that.

I make the further point that it has been the longstanding policy not only of the Labor government but also of the former coalition government that grants of land should not be made to individuals. The Aboriginal Development Commission Act, passed back in 1980 by the Fraser government, provided for land acquisitions to be for corporations and trusts only, not for individuals. It is a longstanding policy. We have not had any articulate argument from opposition senators, apart from the fact that they have had a few representations from some people and they would rather like to have that option available to them individually. That is not a good reason, given the long policy tradition that has existed here.

The basis of that long policy tradition on both sides of the parliament was a concern, of course, to ensure that the widest number of people benefited, to maintain the social and cultural basis of communal land holding, and also for the accountability reasons that I have mentioned. So there are three specific reasons: to ensure that a wider number of people benefit, which ipso facto follows if you have some group ownership system rather than individual; to maintain that social and cultural basis of communal land holding; and also accountability because of the corporate structure and all the statutory obligations that flow from that.

If we have grants being made to trustees which, as I have acknowledged, has been part of the Fraser repertoire in the past, there is a problem. We would argue that we prefer to keep it to corporations. Grants to trustees would mean that non-indigenous individuals and corporations, if this particular provision is not changed, could acquire legal ownership of land under the bill. I suppose if one were to define those trusts very precisely in the way that is intended by F9, that particular problem would not arise. But if one does not, and one accepts the opposition amendment on its own terms, one does have that problem of dilution that I referred to there.

We could go around the traps on this many more times. I think the issues are starkly clear on this matter, as was the case when it was debated in the context of the Native Title Bill. The concepts of the arguments are essentially the same. I simply hope that some good sense will prevail on this matter and, in whatever form it now comes before us, it will be voted down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note with interest the comment by the minister that there has been no articulate argument advanced to justify the approach that would allow in certain circumstances individuals rather than corporations to hold land. Therefore, I think it is important that we look at what we are trying to achieve in this whole area. I would have thought the object of the exercise was to reflect the issues of the actual community and members of that community rather than our deciding that somehow the best structure for them is a corporation, a trust or some collective vehicle. I think that is at the heart of what we are seeking to achieve here.

PARA.TAB: We believe that more than lip service should be paid to notions of self-reliance and individual responsibility. There should be a gaining of experience in actually working the land, rather than being remote from the process—for example, by being a director, the corporation then bringing in a manager and, to all intents and purposes, that director being sidelined. If someone else is actually taking the risks, making the day-to-day decisions, actually benefiting from the whole process and in due course making the actual decision about what happens with the land thereafter, we should not paternalistically pretend that we are the ones who ought to say who holds the land, on what terms and conditions, and what ought to happen to it in the future.

I suppose the analogy that I could draw is that of a housing commission building where no one actually has individual ownership rights; there is not a corporate structure in place. As a result, no-one actually feels personally responsible for maintaining the external walls, let alone quite often the internal areas. We find there is not the same sense of pride, the same sense of ownership, the same sense of belonging and attachment that can come from individual ownership.

Therefore, I think it is very important to have that philosophical component in this discussion. We are not simply doing it because we are somehow reflecting the views of mindless outsiders; we are doing it because they are saying to us that they want that particular right. After all, it is supposed to be for their benefit. Why should we be telling them what is in their best interests? That is, I would have thought, an outmoded approach. Therefore, I would hope that, consistent with that much more enlightened attitude, Senator Chamarette might reconsider in relation to amendment No. 50.

What we have in mind is that, as part and parcel of the experience that you gain from being in control of the land, you can also find it is very helpful and productive for the use of that land to operate in conjunction with others who would not necessarily be Aboriginal members of the community. Given that you still retain a majority interest, you can actually insist on arrangements that are win-win. In other words, you finally call the shots but you draw on their expertise, their involvement, maybe their provision of funds. In all sorts of ways you can have a much broader commercial arrangement. It does not mean that you give away any of your rights. It does not mean that you forgo your involvement with the land. It simply broadens the dimensions and allows the Aboriginal members to retain responsibility, at the same time giving them more flexibility to achieve the most desirable outcome.

Therefore, I think it is very important that we allow people to take risks, not just to simply encourage dependency upon a corporate structure but, in circumstances where it is appropriate, for individuals themselves to feel that hands-on responsibility that can only make them feel much more involved in the whole process than some cold, corporate, distant structure which the government might think is in people's best interests but which the locals clearly do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask opposition senators whether they accept, as some Aboriginal representatives have pointed out, that this style of amendment actually cuts across their cultural values, because they are not obsessed with notions of individualism. I do not think the government suddenly said one day, `Incorporation seems like a good way to go.' The basis of Aboriginal people's organisation, through their very kinship system, is communal. We have found that extremely difficult to understand in the past. I think it is passing strange, to use Senator Cook's language, that suddenly the opposition seeks to impose something of our values on something which is traditionally quite different for them. The basis of their society is really communal; it is collective and not individual. For Senator Alston to say that maybe a focus on individualism would be a remedy for the way they look after their houses, I think is drawing a bit of a long bow. In the past we have been unable to understand the way in which they want to share their resources.

PARA.TAB: The second question I ask Senator Alston which flows on from that is: does he accept then that incorporated bodies can end up assisting more Aboriginal people? The third question is: if his amendments are successful, does he worry that there is the risk of some land being lost through private sales? Does he think, therefore, that somewhere in his amendment there ought to be a proviso that prevents a so-called second bite of the cherry? Do we want the stock of land to be depleted over time? That is not the purpose of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The critical aspect of this amendment to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Fund and Land Corporation) Bill, I think, is that we are injecting flexibility into the process. In other words, we are not saying we believe all Aboriginals, individually and collectively, prefer individual land holding any more than we accept Senator Kernot's proposition that they all prefer a collective form of responsibility. We are simply giving the ILC the power to do either. If that discretion is exercised responsibly, then where the local preference is for collective land holding, presumably, that is what they will do. Similarly, where there are individuals—and there are because we have had the same representations the Australian Democrats have had presumably on the matter—we will accommodate their local wishes and preferences. So it seems to me that that gives us the outcome that best suits the actual wishes of the locals without being prescriptive and without saying, `They ought to have this'—
—Not if you lose land as a result.

—Maybe Senator Ellison is more of an expert on this matter, but if we are simply giving the same powers to individuals that we give to corporations then the ability to alienate title is the same whether it is held by an individual or a corporation. We still run the same risk in their terms of a diminished land base as they might with a series of individual holdings. In fact, a decision by a corporation to alienate a large portion of land may achieve much more in terms of the loss of the land base than a few individuals.
—Much less likely to happen because so many people have a say in the decision.

—Again, Senator Kernot is making assumptions that these people are not able to make decisions in their own interest and somehow they will be so silly as to not take advice and not think ahead in terms of the future and may be so silly as to not reinvest elsewhere in land. I would have thought there would be community pressures, even if we have individual holdings and people get advice—there is no shortage of experts in this field. Senator Kernot can go out and give them gratuitous advice herself. I think we had this debate in superannuation at one stage.
—I won that one.

—Therefore, Senator Kernot should be consistent on this. I think we can, in fact, proceed on the basis that people will not capriciously alienate land. They will do it with a sense of family obligation and responsibility. To the extent that they do not, presumably, others will step in and say, `We want to make sure this does not happen again.' So I think we will find a fair bit of peer group pressure.
—But they lose the land.

—One piece of land here or there is not fatal to a whole system. It may well be in their interests in the longer term. They may wish to swap land or convert it to other forms of activity. Again, I think we ought to be aiming to reflect their wishes as much as possible. Senator Kernot asked whether the incorporation of bodies could assist more Aboriginal people. Again, I do not know that there is necessarily one answer to all that.
—It's more or less arithmetical.
—If that is the best Senator Evans can do, that is really no answer.

—The key point on the amendments which the opposition seeks to make is this: it is wrong to say that across Australia one system will meet the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal groups in different parts of the country with different cultural backgrounds. That is the key behind what the opposition seeks to achieve with this amendment.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate that there be different methods of land holding. A corporate structure is one of a number of possible outcomes, but there are other ways in which aspirations can be met. In some areas it may be appropriate for the land to be held by individuals. In other areas, because of the particular tribal relations, it may be appropriate for the land to be held by trustees upon a trust. That is just a simple statement of fact. But to say that corporate ownership is synonymous with communal ownership is, I think, a rather large leap of faith because the rules of the corporate world are not rules which readily translate into the rules of tribal custom. If one is to say that any structure represents the interests of Aboriginal groups, for example, in Queensland it may well be that it is better to say that it be held by trustees upon a trust rather than upon a corporation. For those reasons it is important that all of the possible means of land holding be available.

The next matter is one of aspiration. Those who oppose individual land holding are basically saying, `This land must always be held on a tribal basis,' notwithstanding the fact that at some future point in time it is in the better interests of the individuals who compose that tribal grouping to hold the land individually. That is a question of economic self-determination. If land is forever locked up into corporate structures, then individuals themselves lack economic self-determination. A tribal group may have economic self-determination but not the individuals. If this bill is to really meet the aspirations of not only tribal groupings of Aborigines but also individual Aborigines, then all of the forms of land holding which I have discussed must be available and that is why the opposition's amendment must be accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments, partly in answer to some of the questions by Senator Kernot and partly to reiterate some of the points behind this package of amendments. Firstly, I want to revisit the argument about imposing something upon Aboriginal people.
—You did on ATSIC. I wish you would be consistent.

—I was not here. I did not debate ATSIC, nor did Senator Kernot. The crucial thing about this bill is that it has been structured in such a way that it ensures it does not impose anything on anybody. All it does is support the retention of the word `corporation', the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporation. It then includes the word `or', which gives the ILC the discretion to choose, then `Aboriginal persons'. They may choose never to use that discretion. So we are certainly not imposing that on anybody or the corporation. Then it goes on to talk about trusts. We are actually giving the ILC more discretion. We are giving it flexibility.

PARA.TAB: We have been accused in this debate of fettering the ILC and trying to make its job harder. In fact, it is impossible to point to any of our amendments that actually seek to do that because what we do in virtually all of them is ensure that the ILC has more discretion and that the aspirations and hopes of the Aboriginals we seek to assist, particularly the most severely dispossessed Aboriginals, are indeed able to be assisted flexibly.

I think it is grossly paternalistic to say that the Anglo-Saxon, Anglo-Celtic and Anglo-American style corporate entity is, as Senator Gareth Evans said, reflective of the communal nature and spirit of Aboriginals. I think it is quite obscene to say that the corporation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do the Aborigine people prefer this amendment?

—I listened very quietly to Senator Kernot, and I am quite happy for her to stand up in a couple of minutes time and ask me another question. I will be happy to answer it. I will be happy to stay here all night and answer her questions. I think it is obscene to say that this corporation—which is a legal invention of white Australians, white Englishmen and white Europeans—reflects most accurately the communal and tribal nature of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very wrong for us, as Noel Pearson said in the Australian on, I think, 26 August, to impose white structures on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We need to ensure, wherever possible, that the laws we pass here reflect their hopes and aspirations quite genuinely. I think the flexibility in the drafting process that we have been through in the last few weeks is encapsulated in this series of amendments and will ensure that that happens in the future more than it has in the past.

It is very paternalistic to seek to say that we understand better than others the family structures, the clan structures and the tribal structures of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and then to impose this corporate structure on top of them. Senator Kernot said that she has had some consultations with Aboriginals and that they have told her that what the coalition and the Greens are doing here today is wrong. We have had many Aboriginal groups tell us quite the opposite—that they support these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's be honest about who they all are.

—I do not need to be dishonest. Senator Chamarette and I wanted to have more consultation during the native title debate. We asked Senator Kernot whom she had spoken to. We knew whom she had spoken to. She spoke to what was called the A-team, the negotiating team. There are a lot of other people out there as well. There are a hell of a lot of other Aboriginal people out there as well.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Kernot did; I am sure we all did, too. We do not want to get into a debate about who is the best Aboriginal to negotiate or consult with. We should really be listening to people. A couple of weeks ago Senator Ellison and I, in a car park out the back of the Meekatharra race club, consulted for hours with a bunch of very genuine Aboriginals whose families had lived in that area for probably hundreds, if not thousands, of years. They were severely dispossessed people from around Meekatharra. Quite frankly, I have as much faith in the views that I pick up when leaning on a utility at the back of the Meekatharra race course and talking to them about their problems of incarceration, alcoholism and dispossession from the land as I do when meeting some bureaucrat from ATSIC here in Parliament House. In fact, I give a lot more credence to those people I met that afternoon. So let us not get into a discussion about whom we have consulted. There are an enormous number of Aboriginal people and Aboriginal groups in Australia who want this flexibility put into this bill. That is why the coalition, with the support of the Greens and, I think, Senator Harradine, will see this amendment made. We think it is a very important amendment.

PARA.TAB: The other point that needs to be covered and which has been an issue of debate between Senator Kernot and Senator Alston is whether, if we have a corporate structure, we include more people. I think Senator Evans might have said that it is a matter of arithmetic. Senator Evans has come in here after a couple of weeks, refocused his mind on the debate, as we are all doing, and been handed a cute little point by some of his advisers, saying, `Look, it's simple arithmetic. If you have a corporation getting some land, you'll get more.'

TALK.START.PARA: —No; I invented that one myself, actually.

—Well done. I will knock it over as quickly as he invented it, then. The reality is that, if we have the flexibility to give assistance to individuals, trusts or corporations, we have the flexibility to arithmetically assist more Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islander people. Just because we have a corporation does not mean arithmetically that there are more people in it; it just means we have created a legal entity to incorporate those individuals in it. There is no reason why, if the government allows our amendment to have trusts, trustees and individuals, we could not have thousands more Aboriginals assisted. Quite frankly, arithmetically, three different potential methods of assisting people are better than one.

PARA.TAB: The last point I want to address in this contribution relates to amendment 50, which we are debating cognately. We seek, in another one of our amendments, to ensure that the assistance goes to not only Aboriginal groups, trusts or corporations that have in excess of 50 per cent ownership by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. We think that is again an unnecessary fettering of the ILC. In amendment 50 we have, firstly, defined trusts in part (a) and, secondly, in part (b), we have quite specifically ensured that the ILC has the flexibility once again to be able to assist Aboriginals where they may be entering a joint venture arrangement or some other arrangement where they may not, at the time of the purchase, have 50 per cent plus one equity.

We believe it is most important to do that. We have had representations and seen examples on the ground of proposals for developments, as Senator Ellison said, particularly in the tourism field, where it would be very sensible for indigenous Australians, if they so chose, to enter into agreements with other people who may wish to develop something but where it is just not economically feasible to do so with this 50 per cent plus one type of requirement. So we want to again build in the flexibility that ensures that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can get assistance but in a minority area.

Again, the ILC may not choose to assist people in that way. It may say, `No, we really should assist corporations or trusts that have more than 50 per cent indigenous ownership.' That, of course, will be its decision. But we are saying that there may well be in the future, and even around the corner, situations where people point out to the ILC an eco-tourism development, as Senator Ellison said—it may be any other sort of tourism development or possibly even a mine or a pastoral lease—where the indigenous people could enter into an agreement with other people or another corporation but where the attainment of 50 per cent equity was not at the outset available.

We believe that ensuring there is not this arbitrary 50 per cent cut-off limit is sensible so as not to disadvantage people who could enter into those sorts of agreements. That is one of the effects of amendment 50. I ask Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine to think very carefully about the intention behind it. It is a very honest one which we think adds again to the ILC's flexibility.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Before calling Senator Panizza, I note that much of the debate has been about the foreshadowed opposition amendments that bear upon the same points. I hope the committee will soon allow me to call Senator Chamarette as I believe that in addressing, as we are at the moment, the motion that amendments one to eight be adopted she may have some summary remarks and maybe even seek leave to withdraw them. If that were the case, we would then move on to the opposition moving amendments four to 45, and the debate could be more disciplined by being actually addressed to amendments before the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold up the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), who jumped to his feet a minute ago. I would like to make a few comments about ownership, whether by community or by individuals. I am not as expert as those around me who have talked to communities around the place, but I do observe practicalities. I have watched for at least 15 years some of the Aboriginal land trusts of Western Australia—particularly the former mission at a place called Mogumber. Honourable senators have probably never heard of it, but quite a big land holding is owned by that trust and the community. All I have seen over those 15 years is it going backwards. When this happens to those sorts of places, it gets to a stage where they are simply run by an Australian white manager and employees, and the odd young Aboriginal may come there for training and so on. In other words, their involvement is minimal—it has gone backwards. Senator Evans says, and I heard Senator Kernot say, that we do not appreciate what land is to the Aboriginals. I think I do.
—I didn't say that.

—I think Senator Kernot said that. If she reads the Hansard, she will find she said something like `the coalition does not appreciate it'. If we want to treat indigenous people as equals, why not give them the same opportunity to hold land as we do? We can choose whether we hold it in a family partnership, whether we hold it in a corporation or whether we hold it individually. Why not give them the same opportunities? I could go on for a long time on this point. There is nothing wrong with individuals wanting to sell and buy other properties. We could build in safeguards about other ground and that sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: But the point I want to talk about is this: if land is owned by a massive community—unless there is a good corporation running it military style—no-one can get the best out of the ground. But if the community were to break down into individual lots—when I say `individual', I include an individual family—there would be a good chance of improving the situation. I have seen a partnership which was going nowhere but which made progress when broken down into individuals—and there may be cases where one individual will go, even though he may have only a third of the property.

If we have Aboriginals with individual holdings—and `individual' to me covers an ordinary family as we know it—they can be an example to others. I have seen this with my own eyes over the last 15 years, particularly in regard to what is happening with Mogumber. I am not necessarily saying that a big corporation style will fail, but one needs a lot more discipline to make it go. When no-one has individual responsibility for anything, things tend to fail. If we have a big disciplined organisation—military style or whatever—we can get it to go. That system will work better with smaller holdings and will be an example to others.

If the Australian government is putting $1.4 billion into a land fund, I want to see it work. We see $1.3 billion going into ATSIC annually, and I want to see that work. One gets no pleasure from seeing an enterprise fail. If an enterprise is going to work, why not give it the best chance? I cannot see any objection whatsoever to getting down to individual ownership. If the Aboriginals want to trade their ground and buy other land, they should be able to do so. I said that previously during the second reading debate, but the minister did not place much importance on it; he believed there was a difference. Why should there be a difference? Aboriginals can sell some ground and pick up something else. As we know, priorities change. A priority for one year may be quite different in 10 years' time. I cannot see why we cannot go down the line as proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I make the point again that there are three basic arguments why we are arguing for the bill as it is without extending the options as proposed. The first argument goes to accountability. The corporate form introduces a whole new set of obligations upon the holders of the land in question which are not evident in the law as it stands at the moment so far as individuals are concerned. For those on the other side—and perhaps not elsewhere—who are purported to be concerned about accountability, I believe that ought to be a relevant consideration.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I repeat the argument—and I am not moved to waive it or abandon it by what has been said by the opposition—that a corporate form ipso facto necessarily involves a wider sharing of the benefits of the land fund than is available at the moment. Three options might be more than one option, yes, but any time we choose the option of giving land to an individual rather than being required to give the land to a corporation, ipso facto we are sharing the available funds less widely than would be the case if we went for the corporate form which requires, by definition, more than one member of the body corporate in order to constitute the—

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends entirely on the size of the holding.

—Nonetheless, in terms of the members of the body corporate it is to be assumed—and reasonably assumed—that that would be more widespread. Thirdly, there is the argument that the corporate form of ownership is the best way of maintaining the social and cultural basis of communal land holding. We had the proposition from Senator Campbell that it was an obscenity to suggest that this particular bit of white man's law could possibly approximate Aboriginal communal traditions. I have to say that of all the crocodile tears I have seen shed in this place, those have to be the saltiest—
—What about freshwater crocodiles?
—The most liquid perhaps. Obviously the corporate form is what communal ownership is all about. It is a very close approximation indeed, and I think that particular argument just does not hold water.

PARA.TAB: In addition to those three positive arguments of accountability, wider benefits and maintaining a closer legal approximation to traditional communal forms, there are two negative arguments that I think need to be made. The first is that any move away from requiring corporate status would in practice serve to dilute the Aboriginal land base that this is all about preserving. Senator O'Chee says that it is a form of economic self-determination to enable individuals to have a go at the pie in this respect. All I can say is that economic self-determination is just a flash way of saying that this is a recipe for diluting the Aboriginal land base.

Let us take, for example, some land that is vested in an individual by the ILC in a case where that individual is married to a non-Aboriginal person. What happens when that Aboriginal person dies and bequeaths, in the normal course of events, the land in question to his spouse? The opposition has not addressed that particular issue. Section 191S says that any form of disposal has to be subject to the approval—

TALK.START.PARA: —We wouldn't address that because it is a fairly racist concept.

—Hang on! Let me finish. I am talking about the implications of this for diluting the Aboriginal land base. What we are talking about is building and maintaining an Aboriginal land base. If one is married to a non-Aboriginal person and one dies, bequeathing the land in question to that non-Aboriginal person, one might say that by virtue of this argument—
—What do you call their children, then?
—Let us assume for the sake of this argument that they do not have any children—
—Let's assume they don't have any children, yes.

—I am delighted to hear that Senator Campbell's sensitivity factor has gone up a few notches. This is a big change of heart for the Western Australian Liberals. I am making a technical argument, so shut up and listen! Section 191S at the present time does not provide for that circumstance. One might say that substituting the word `person' for the words `body corporate' would mean that some form of consent would be required in order to govern the disposal by way of succession law as well as any form of disposal. Maybe so, but what happens if the ILC withholds consent in that situation? We would have a nullity situation. The land could not go anywhere if there is no provision made for where it would go because there is no provision for reversion back to the stock of the ILC. So we are stuck with that situation.

PARA.TAB: In the absence of any other amendment, one would assume that the intention of the opposition is that the land, under those circumstances, goes to the surviving non-Aboriginal spouse. That is fair enough as a matter of ordinary practice, but it means a dilution of what would otherwise be an Aboriginal land base. The whole point of this legislation is to try to give Aboriginal people a stake in the land that exists in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's about the worst argument I have ever heard you put.

—There is nothing racist about that. That is the whole premise, the whole foundation of this legislation. If the opposition is creating the capacity to dilute that particular policy intent over time simply through the natural operation of the legislation, then we believe it is making a policy mistake. The opposition might not say it is a mistake; it might say it is a deliberate matter of intent, and I suspect that is right. What those on the other side of the chamber are really trying to do, with the utmost respect, is to introduce as many amendments as they possibly can to either make this particular legislation unworkable in practice—dragged along by the naivety of the Greens, as they were the other day, with that business about dispossession—or in principle to make it a different piece of legislation from that which it is intended to be.

PARA.TAB: If that is what those opposite want to do, and if they can gather the numbers in this place, that is fair enough, they will have it their way, but it will be on their consciences. However, at the end of the day those opposite may not have a bill. If we end up with a bill which does not serve the policy purposes that the government is intending, and which is the product of so much consultation with Aboriginal people around this country, those opposite will not have a bill being passed into law as a result. They need to be aware of that.

The other negative reason for not accepting this amendment is that it involves yet another divisive new equation being brought into the situation. In his previous contribution on 20 October—at page 2131 of Hansard—Senator O'Chee made much of the potentially divisive implications of having a couple of different Aboriginal groups making competing claims. He made that contribution in the context of claims between native title based aspirants and those who were just seeking land under this particular legislative format. I quote Senator O'Chee:

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is where different Aboriginal groups have competing claims to land. On Cape York Peninsula, an area with which I am very familiar, there are claims from different Aboriginal groups competing with the existing Wik claim. If one Aboriginal group in one part of the country makes a native title claim and another group seeks to access the fund to purchase some of that land subject to that claim, the result will be outright warfare between the two groups.

Just extend that kind of argument to a situation where, instead of the group as a whole seeking access communally through a corporate title response to particular land, we have different individuals claiming a piece of the action. Ipso facto necessarily we are going to be caught up in many more potentially internecine disputes between individual Aboriginal people who might otherwise have all their interests accommodated under a more communal, traditional and, in this context, corporate form of title. So there are those positive reasons for supporting the government's basic drafting and there are those negative reasons for opposing what is proposed by the opposition and the Greens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a couple of points made by Senator Gareth Evans. Corporations, of themselves, do not offer any magic as to accountability or the fact that things will be run correctly. We merely have to look at the running of some Aboriginal corporations in Australia today. The registrar of those corporations puts out a report. If we look at that report we will see that a good number of those corporations are being investigated. A good number of them are being independently audited by accountants. That is living proof of the fact that some of these corporations ain't doing what they are supposed to be doing. I suggest to Senator Evans that a corporation is just as capable of misappropriating funds and is just as capable of doing the wrong thing as any individual or any group of people. Therefore, that argument in the first instance must fail.

PARA.TAB: The question of how we bring those people to account is another matter. I still do not see any difference. When we bring a corporation to account, we still have to go through that mechanism. We have a whole piece of legislation dealing with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations. We still have to go through the hurdles. Built into this bill are a number of requirements which could govern individuals and families just as much as corporations. If I recall it, one of our amendments is that, where a grant of money is made and it is not used for the purpose for which it was intended, the ILC can take recovery action. That can be done just as much with a corporation as an individual.

If we have a Flash Harry and his mates, they can take the money and run just as easily whether it is in their own names or a corporation. I have seen instances in Western Australia where groups which were supposed to have been the beneficiaries of such corporations are fighting with them because the directors of the corporation are doing things which those groups do not want done. They say they are being left out in the cold. Senator Evans should not think for one minute that corporations will make it one happy family, because there are living examples in Australia today where this mechanism is not providing the panacea that he thinks it does.

With respect to clause 191S—and I touch on that merely because Senator Evans has raised it—it is a restriction on the right to dispose of property. That clause effectively makes the Indigenous Land Corporation a landlord. It keeps the land virtually under the control of the Indigenous Land Corporation in perpetuity. That is not what I would suggest the preamble to the Native Title Act suggested when it set up and touched on this land fund. The Indigenous Land Corporation could well become one massive body which, in time, would control a good deal of land without the autonomy of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander recipients.

It is the coalition's view that if we make a grant, we make a grant and that is what it should be, and we should not have these ongoing strings attached. One of our amendments is that when the ILC makes a grant it does not retain an interest in the land granted, because then it becomes like a landlord—it can tell those people what it wants to do with the land and it can control them. That gives more than an implied power. It does not say that in the bill, but it does have the effect in clause 191S of an ongoing control by the Indigenous Land Corporation.

I take it from Senator Evans's remarks that he is not in favour of a complete divesting of any interest to the recipients. If I have misunderstood him, will he please correct me. If he is saying that the recipients should receive the land to have and to hold and to alienate as they wish, then will he please make that clear. I understood him to be saying that clause 191S was a means of restricting this subsequent divesting, and that that is what he had against Aboriginal persons being married to non-Aboriginal persons. He objected to the fact that those persons could then bequeath their land to their spouse. I understood that that was what he had a problem with, because he was thinking that the land was not then reaching the people it was intended to benefit. This is a basic point in relation to this piece of legislation: we either give land or we do not. If we retain strings by which we can control the people concerned, then we are not living by—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are retaining strings yourself; you've still got the consent to disposal thing there.

—There are aspects which we will deal with later in the debate touching on our amendments which are freer than what the government is proposing. There are still aspects of accountability—and so there should be—for guarantees, loans and things of that sort. But we are talking about a straight grant of land. I do not believe we can call it a grant when, on the one hand, the government says that it is giving it to people and, on the other hand, says that they cannot get rid of it without coming back to the government first.
—But you have kept that.

—I put it to Senator Evans that, when he said that a grant can be made on such conditions as the ILC determines, he is giving the ILC carte blanche in fettering the grant. Our amendments propose that, when the grant is made, only specific aspects can be dealt with. We would take away the discretion from the ILC because we do not want the ILC to have such power and control.

PARA.TAB: It is a question of balance. We have to get the balance between giving the benefit to the people concerned and having some accountability at the end in the Indigenous Land Corporation, but not forwarding too much power to that corporation so that, in effect, it becomes a mini-government or a mini-council or body which can control Aboriginal affairs in a de facto sense. That is what we are against.

We believe that by granting land to individuals we are broadening the scope of assistance that we can give to Aboriginal people. I know Aboriginals in Western Australia who do not want to be incorporated, who are quite happy to operate as a family or a clan and who would miss out with this regime. They would miss out on any assistance from this sort of legislation.

Let us remember that corporations will not give any added protection. They have not worked that well thus far. As I said, they are still being investigated. If I could lay my hands on the report, I would give honourable senators the number. Take it from me, the registrar is looking into a fair number of corporations due to complaints made by members of the Aboriginal groups as to how those corporations are being run. I am not saying that corporations are a bad thing on their own; I am just saying that they are not the complete answer; they are only part of it. We have to extend it and allow Aboriginal trusts, Aboriginal individuals and Aboriginal groups to be recipients of the benefit of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principles that Senator Gareth Evans referred to—the three positive principles underlying the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill in the form the government has presented it and the two negative principles—are worthy of just skimming through prior to what I intend to do, which is to withdraw amendments F1 to F8, which we have been addressing, and to accept the opposition's considerations of amendments Nos 4 to 45.

PARA.TAB: One of the principles that Senator Evans stated was the importance of group ownership within the Aboriginal community, and I do not think anybody disputes that. However, what we might dispute is the equivalence of the importance of communal ownership with corporations and the way in which non-Aboriginal law defines corporations. It is a big leap from communal ownership to incorporated bodies. That is the first response to Senator Evans's importance of group ownership within Aboriginal communities.

The second point he raised was that he saw the corporatons as a way of vesting in the future, and a way of Aboriginal communities having a corporation structure which protects their land into the future. We have no opposition to that principle. The only opposition we have is to the government making a requirement of it and restricting the operation of this land fund to that principle, and that principle alone, as a way of enshrining and protecting communal ownership.

The third point that Senator Evans raised was the increase in accountability that is provided by this restriction. I ask: accountability to whom? It is quite clear in this bill that the main restrictions on the ways in which the fund can operate are all directed towards the recipients of the money, grants or land and that the freedom and openness is given to the government appointed body, the board. It has almost total freedom—so much freedom that the government does not even want it to have aims, objects and principles by which its enactment of the legislation can be reviewed and monitored. Yet, on the other hand, we have this restrictiveness which is supposed to increase accountability. Our feeling is that it does not increase accountability to the Aboriginal community; it increases accountability to the government and to non-Aboriginal bureaucracies.

I am tempted to mention a joke in this regard. I will mention only the first third of the joke and not go to the punch line; but I think it vividly illustrates our concerns. It is a very sad reflection that this joke can often be reflected in similar ways in day-to-day life—and I think it is in this legislation. It is about an Aboriginal person who goes to his local store and obtains a bunch of groceries. As he is leaving, the shop owner notes that he has a tin of dog food. The shop owner says, `Where's your dog?' He says, `I've come for miles. My land's way over there and I haven't brought my dog.' The shop owner says, `We can't give you this dog food until you show us your dog.' He says, `Break it down. We can't bring our dog in every time we want to buy dog food.' The shop owner says, `Oh yes, but we know sometimes you people eat this food.' So, dutifully, the Aboriginal person brings his dog and then gets given his can of dog food. The same thing gets repeated for cat food and for toilet paper. I will leave the committee to imagine the main part of the joke.

But the humour covers something very serious, which is paternalism and the capacity for a government to give with one hand and take back in a boomerang action if its own requirements are not fulfilled. So I do not see the three positive points that Senator Evans raised as positive; I see them as questionable and, in some cases, paternalistic.

Senator Evans made some negative points about changing to the opposition's suggestions to preserve the land base. For whom is the land base being preserved? Aboriginal people do not actually have it at the moment. If the government is preventing them from getting it in order to preserve an Aboriginal estate, by whom is that estate owned? The second point that was raised points out very clearly who owns it—the ILC, which we are just setting up.

In commenting on section 191S, Senator Evans said, `This unfortunate situation where an Aboriginal person may want to bequeath his inheritance to a non-Aboriginal person might force the ILC to withhold its consent to the disposal of the land to the legitimate person who has inherited it.' I think that is outrageous but I do think it is inherent in the act, and we will deal with that matter later on no doubt.

The next point that Senator Evans raised was the divisive potential for the situation of different groups that might be involved. I would point out that one cannot automatically create division where it does not exist. As Senator Ellison pointed out quite clearly, just having a legal entity like a corporation does not make one happy family; it still leaves the problems that may exist. Let me give an example of justice not always being served by having a restriction to a corporation's structure. I refer to a family by the name of Dan in Nevada. Only that family was the legitimate unit which had a particular claim.

So for three reasons we support the opposition amendments. Even though we are withdrawing our amendments, which are identical, we believe that the first principle we are supporting is that of justice—that justice may not be served to all people if it is restricted in this particular way in terms of allocation of funds or land. The second principle is flexibility. We are not specifying that the ILC has to go beyond the structure. We are saying that it has a legitimate right to make the best decision possible for a particular area of land and the particular unit that will be best served within the Aboriginal community, whether that is a person, a family, a family trust, or a corporation.

The third and most important principle in respect of which we support these amendments is that of self-determination and a rescinding of the paternalistic principles underlying this constraint. I seek leave to withdraw amendments F1 to F8.
Amendments—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to revisit a little bit of what has been said because we have heard people in this debate waxing lyrically about the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people. Nobody here is able to speak on behalf of all Aboriginal people and I think we are all being a little slippery.
—You haven't been doing too badly.

—Can I finish? We are being a bit slippery about who is speaking for whom and I would like us to be a bit more honest about this. I would ask Senator Ellison and Senator Chamarette to tell me please why they dismiss the views of some Aboriginal people, namely ATSIC, the Northern Land Council, the Central Land Council, the Kimberley Land Council, and the Carpentaria Land Council, which prefer incorporated structures. Why would they say that it is paternalistic or opposing self-determination to insist on an incorporated structure when these groups of Aboriginal people themselves do not see it that way? Why are they wrong—
—Others happen to disagree with them; they actually dare to disagree.

—But let us be honest about who is speaking for whom and why some could be right and some could be wrong; let us be honest about the justification those opposite are using for dismissing their views. I just want to hear it, that is all.

PARA.TAB: There are some problems in this. Think about the meeting that was held in Melbourne this week between Aboriginal groups who were trying to come to a position on the amendment the Senate passed to do with the most severely dispossessed. They could not get agreement on the way through that and so they agreed to disagree. So, here we are, a bunch of non-indigenous Australians standing up in this parliament, presuming to choose between the views of some Aboriginal groups as being less paternalistic than others.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not choosing; we are giving them a choice.
—I think we are dismissing the views of some Aboriginal people who are saying that an incorporated structure is not paternalistic and works for them and they prefer it.
—We would not be dismissing them. We would be taking out any reference to corporate structures and making it only individuals.
—So you do not dismiss what they are saying.
—We are broadening the base. What are you talking about?
—How do opposition senators dismiss their view that they have problems with grants to individuals?
—Because not all wisdom resides with any one group.
—No, it does not. But what does one say to them? Why are they wrong?
—You say to them that there is a discretion in the ILC to accommodate their wishes if that happens to be the preference of that area, just as in another area they might have a different view.
—Under the opposition's amendment is it possible for individuals to apply and reapply and reapply?
—There is always a discretion there, so you will not find the ILC willingly allowing people to double dip.
—How does the honourable senator know that?
—I will respond to that.
—I would ask the honourable senator to respond.

—An amendment, which has not been circulated yet, deals with the question of double dipping, if that is what Senator Kernot is referring to. That deals with a situation where someone can apply for a grant of land and then come back again under the guise of a corporation and apply again in relation to the same piece of land. For instance, a person gets a piece of land, divests himself of it and then comes back and tries to apply again. Double dipping I think is what Senator Kernot is referring to, and that is what we are foreshadowing. But the wording has not yet been settled.

—I would like to make my response to Senator Kernot. She is incorrectly implying that we are failing to give regard to the Aboriginal groups which have said that the corporations structure is a very appropriate one for them. That is fine. They are entitled to speak for that, and nothing in these amendments excludes it. What we are refusing is their request to restrict it to this method for somebody else apart from those who have also spoken to us and asked that such a restriction not be included in this legislation. We believe that it is one of these areas where flexibility should be given to the ILC and the management of the fund and that the ILC should not be given a tied turkey to begin with. It should be given the flexibility. If it does not choose to exercise that range of responses, that is fine.

PARA.TAB: That is all that the different Aboriginal groups that have approached us have been asking. There is an unwillingness that the restriction be placed upon the allocation of the money or access to the land acquisition fund. What we are opposing by these amendments is a restriction that is in the legislation which we believe to be inappropriate. We are not excluding any of the people who voluntarily nominate to accept the corporations structure and all the benefits that may be derived from that. We simply say to get a consensus position where all the groups are happy we have to look at supporting the wide variety of responses.

Rather than not listening, we are listening to everybody. So we are not `not listening', to anybody. In fact, if the truth be known, the people the Democrats are not listening to are the ones who say, `We don't want it restricted purely in the way in which it is in this legislation. We would like to be able to argue amongst ourselves about the validity of the different measures in which we can approach the land fund.' It may well be that individuals will never get, as has been pointed out in the debate earlier, a grant through this land acquisition fund. They may in themselves realise that they have a better chance if they come with a family, a community or a structure of a corporation. But that then is essentially up to them and it is in their hands. That is the basis on which we support it.

TALK.START.PARA: I would like briefly to add to that point by asking rhetorically what Senator Chamarette would say to a group of Aboriginal people who came along and said, `We have seen the abuses that can occur with corporate structures, the disempowerment that flows from being a minority shareholder, the abuses of power that can occur when you separate ownership from control and we therefore prefer direct ownership so that we are in control of our own destinies, we are responsible for the way in which we handle the land and we have the ultimate title.' Why does Senator Kernot say that the ILC or anyone else should simply tell them that they have it wrong and they have to accept a structure in which they do not have confidence.
—I do not say that. I would ask: what is the purpose of the bill and where is the accountability to make sure that we do not deplete the land base? That is what I would say and that is the answer.

—I want to rebut a couple of the arguments put by Senator Gareth Evans. I wanted to talk again about this business about trying to help more people. He reiterated his argument that corporation by its very nature will ensure that more people get assisted because more people can be incorporated. I still do not understand his argument. The reality is that under this system we have three, four or more potential different ways of owning land. It is quite possible that we would have a corporation with 10 or 15 indigenous people in it. We might have a trust with 100 people in it. Quite frankly, under the system that we are proposing, with the support of the Greens, it is arithmetically, using the minister's own logic, possible to assist more Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

PARA.TAB: I think the argument in relation to whether we need to mandate that it must be a body corporate that holds the land as opposed to creating a flexibility we have has a logic that is just entirely inescapable. I just cannot see why the Democrats would seek to impose one structure upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people when we are offering a choice. It may be quite appropriate for the Kimberley Land Council, the Northern Land Council, ATSIC and so forth to go to the ILC and put very strong arguments why a person, a trust or a family should not be granted the land. But the thing is the government is trying to say—I do not know whether it is being swayed by the logic at all—`You must have a corporate structure and nothing else.' All we are doing is saying that there should be a choice. I cannot see how anyone could possibly suggest that we have any other sort of agenda. Senator Evans has said we have come here to make it unworkable. I cannot see how he can possibly—

TALK.START.PARA: —He usually says that when he is losing the argument.

—As I said by way of interjection at the time, he certainly does not need our help when it comes to creating unworkable legislation. He does very well without any assistance whatsoever. He did very well leading up to Christmas last year, and he did very well creating a totally unworkable land administration system under the Native Title Act without any assistance from us whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: That brings me to the point which I found one of the most disgraceful things that I have heard Senator Evans say when he was using the argument about the Aboriginal man marrying a non-Aboriginal woman and what would happen if the man were to pass away and pass it on to his non-Aboriginal wife. When I suggested by way of interjection that they may have children and the children may inherit the land, he said, `Just for the sake of the argument, pretend they don't have any children.' That is a pretty good argument to base it on! I want to tell Senator Evans what a nasty argument that is to use, as what he is really saying is that under the government's scheme people would have to be very careful about who they married.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't divert the argument. You know what it is about; it is about dilution of a policy base.

—No, it is not because we are talking about expanding the policy base and the government is talking about constricting it because the people that the government negotiates with are generally the big politically organised Aboriginal groups. Mr Dillon tabled for us during an inquiry of the Finance and Public Administration Committee a list of who the government had so-called consulted with. We saw exactly who they were. It is on the public record.

PARA.TAB: I refer anyone here who wants to see who the government talks to when it talks about Aboriginal affairs to this Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearing where Mr Dillon very kindly, with the minister's agreement, I presume, tabled a list of all of those people who have been consulted about this bill. They are, almost without exception, the politically organised Aboriginal groups. There is nothing wrong with that sort of consultation, but the government should not say that it has consulted all over the place when it has basically consulted with those who agree with its ideas in the first place.

May I just say how obscene the prospect is of what Senator Evans was saying. He is saying that where an Aboriginal man who had been granted land dies, having decided to bequeath that land to his wife and possibly his children, the ILC may decide, using the powers under 191S, that it would not allow that transfer to take place. This brings us back to that central issue of the perpetual control that the ILC has under the government's scheme. We will get to this at a later stage in the debate.

The reality is on the evidence given by Mr Dillon to the Finance and Public Administration Committee—and it was highlighted by Senator Chamarette, who asked a question of Mr Dillon. When asked about the assets of the ILC, he referred to the investments in the trust but then went on to say, `We regard that the ILC will have more assets than this.' He specifically said, `I think the analysis presented ignores the overall structure.' He went on to say, `We actually have a much larger asset than the asset in the fund. We also have the land that the ILC purchases.' So it is regarded, maybe at least in the mind of one of the people responsible for drafting the bill, that the asset of the land that the ILC purchases resides in the fund and resides in the ILC.

We have a very fundamental philosophical difference here. The coalition and the Greens very much support vesting the land in the hands of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for their benefit. The government sees that the ILC needs to maintain this link with the land in perpetuity, and that link is created through section 191S. But Senator Evans has raised that spectre and it needed to be rebutted. That is the fundamental difference between our approach and the government's approach. I think we all understand where that difference is, but that is where it lies.

We believe that one can still maintain accountability, can still maintain the objects of the act and maintain the very important principles of assisting dispossessed Aboriginals without maintaining the paternalistic control that the government's bill in its current form perpetuates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that we are not dealing directly with section 191S at the moment, but that is an essential part of the legislation. I deal with section 191S(2) which talks of disposals and charges prohibited. I ask this question because it is relevant to section 191D that we are dealing with at the moment. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The body corporate must not, without the consent of the Indigenous Land Corporation:
(a)dispose of the interest; or
(b)give a charge with respect to an asset of the body corporate which consists of, or includes, the interest.
Does the government rely on section 51(xx) as the head of power in respect of that clause?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we do not rely on section 51(xx) to sustain this. The whole legislation is really premised on the Aboriginal power. One may get some supporting nourishment from the corporations power as well in this context, but that is not the reason why it is drafted this way. The reason why it is drafted this way is to preserve the principle of communal title rather than individual title. The opposition amendment does in fact deal with section 191S to the extent that it deletes the words `body corporate' and substitutes the word `person' through these particular provisions in section 191S all the way through.

PARA.TAB: There is a further amendment to section 191S which is later proposed, not just amendment 25, which will have the effect of removing the capacity of the corporation to withhold consent except in circumstances where it does have an interest. But we are not addressing that. On the particular question of whether it is a person or a body corporate, there is no technical problem about deleting `body corporate' and substituting `person'. I think the legislation would still be constitutionally viable. The problem is a policy problem.

While I am on my feet, I will quickly reply to Senator Campbell's latest use of the word `obscenity'? We have had two in a row in the space of an hour or so's debate this evening, both of them equally unjustified. The point that I am making, if I can put it a different way, is that we have to have a very good reason before we spend taxpayers' money on enabling people to get dollops of land for free.

One very good policy reason for spending taxpayers' money to enable people to buy land for free to them is because they are Aboriginal and because of the sense of injustice that we feel towards Aboriginal people. But if it only takes a skip in time for that particular land purchased for Aboriginal people to pass on to non-Aboriginal people, through the mechanism of succession, as I have described it, then it is pretty much a windfall benefit at the expense of the taxpayers for someone who might be thoroughly deserving in individual terms, and I am not in any way casting aspersions on that. Just assume the situation—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an assumption of gold digging.

—No, it is not an assumption of anything of the kind. It is an assumption of the desirability of maintaining in the hands of Aboriginal people the land that we are buying out of taxpayers' funds for Aboriginal people. It is as simple and straightforward as that.

—Quite rightly, Senator Evans regards it as very offensive to talk in terms of degrees of aboriginality. But it just happens when we get to someone who is not an Aboriginal person, Senator Evans assumes, in effect, that they have no attachment with the Aboriginal community, that they have just gone in there for the sake of the marriage, that once they inherit the land, they will be up and off. I regard that as quite offensive. I think it implies that they really have no attachment to the community, to their spouse, to the people that they live with. One cannot get much closer to people than to marry them. To somehow think that because somebody then inherits the land or owns it means that they will turn their back on everything that ever brought them to that married state, seems to me to be very offensive.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I would have thought Senator Evans would not be quite as heartless as that in trying to draw this strict line. He is effectively saying to Aboriginal people, `Marry outside your community at your peril, because you, and only you, will be unable to pass on land to your spouse'. Where is the fairness in that? I would have thought, just as it ought to go both ways, that the non-Aboriginal person ought to be able to bequeath land to the Aboriginal person, why should it not work in the opposite direction? After all, one is trying to achieve a cohesive structure, not draw artificial and divisive lines.

I would have thought it is a classic example of not thinking this through because the government is wedded at all costs to this central power structure. It really does not want to break down the power and allow people to have control over their own lives, control over who they marry, control over who they bequeath land to.
