Senator Evans's obsession is with maintaining this land base irrespective of who benefits, irrespective of which is the local community, irrespective of the fact that the spouse might be actually very happy indeed for that to happen. Senator Evans says, `No, I am sorry. The greater national good requires me to tell you that you can't do it because we have got this grand commitment to a land base'. If that is not putting the individual last, I do not know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Alston does not like the case of the wife, and that was just the clearest and most obvious case I could think of, try the case of the bankrupt, the individual who is given an entitlement of land under this legislation for his own use and benefit. Let us assume he is not married—forget about all those complications—he goes broke and the creditors want a piece of that particular land. Under the normal law applicable to these situations—and down the line the opposition is going to remove the power of the ILC to withhold consent to that—the land again would be divested away from the Aboriginal person and to, arguably, a white creditor.
—What happens if the corporation goes broke?

—We are retaining a power for non-disposal. I am saying that in the situation posed by those opposite, they want to vest absolutely; they do not want to retain a residual right of non-consent. That is a right which we are going to retain under all circumstances. It will have legal force and effect and be enough to override those otherwise applicable features of the general law because we want to maintain the new Aboriginal land base that we are incrementally increasing. Of course we are being discriminatory—affirmatively discriminatory—because we are spending large amounts of taxpayers' money in order to redress an age-old wrong. We want to discriminate in favour of Aboriginal people. We do not want this particular land base, once created, bit by bit to be diluted. There are all sorts of ways in which it will be diluted if those opposite enable it to go out the door in that particular direction. That is the point that is being made. Do not let us have any more of this nonsense and this reference to obscenity and taking high moral grounds. They are schoolboy debating tactics. There is an important policy issue involved here.
—I wish to ask the minister whether a corporation can go broke? I know that some do. Is it not the same result if it is mortgaged out to a bank?

—Technically, of course, corporations can go broke; I am perfectly aware of that. But if the asset cannot be disposed of because of an overriding requirement that it cannot be disposed of except with the consent of the ILC, that is, I guess, stiff luck so far as the creditor is concerned.

PARA.TAB: In the real world it would not work like that because there would be a continuing credit facility, presumably made available through the ILC. There would be further loans being made and stiff management regimes being imposed because of the capacity of the ILC to do just that.

Those opposite are removing most of those conditions down the line a bit because they want to divest the ILC of that continuing role. We want to preserve a continuing role in relation to the ILC and the land base because we want to preserve this for future generations. The legal framework that we are creating in this bill—before the opposition dilutes it to unrecognisability—will enable that to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I heard the minister correctly, he said that corporations have different rules by which they cannot let land go. But that means that no financier who did his homework would lend money on that basis. Is that correct? That is an observation that I make: I doubt whether finance could be obtained.

—One of the reasons there is a power of guarantee in the legislation is to cover those sorts of situations. Where there is inalienable title obviously there are prima facie problems about mortgaging it and getting creditors participating in the financing of it. Accordingly, there needs to be a provision for guarantee arrangements. That is why the legislation is full of all those complex provisions dealing with just that. Senator Panizza has lost the plot somewhere. Of course all that other stuff is needed because of the very practical commercial points that Senator Panizza, with his very practical and commercial brain, has picked up. That is why the legislation is as it is.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Ellison's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (50)Clause 5, page 43, after the proposed definition of "Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation", insert the following definition:
"`Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust' means a trust:

PARA.TAB: (a)in which a majority of the beneficial interests are held by:

TAB.TAB: (i)Aboriginal persons; or
(ii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iii)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(iv)a combination of those persons; or

PARA.TAB: (b)in which some of the beneficial interests are held by persons referred to in paragraph (a) and where details of the ownership of the other beneficial interests have been provided to the Indigenous Land Corporation;".

SPEECH.PARA: We have already debated this amendment. Now that throughout the bill as amended we have reference to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts, there needs to be a definition of a trust. We seek to define that in two ways. The first is a broad definition in (a), where the beneficial interests are held by Aboriginal persons, Torres Strait Islanders and so forth. In (b) the potential is created for beneficial interests where the majority ownership may not be Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander ownership. It specifically ensures that the details of that ownership are made known to the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned this briefly in the previous debate. The crucial effect of subclause (b) is that if there is an instance where a corporate entity needs to be established to either purchase or develop land, there be no severe restriction such that there needs to be a 50 per cent Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander ownership. In other words, it is envisaging the possibility that there may be circumstances where it would be of assistance to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people to enter into arrangements that do not reflect majority ownership in the initial stages. They are the fundamentals: firstly, it establishes a broad definition of trusts and, secondly, it envisages what would happen if there were not majority ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —For reasons similar to those I have previously indicated, if we are to have a definition of `trust' we would much prefer one in which all the beneficiaries are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people To allow for up to 49 per cent non-Aboriginal participation creates yet again the potential to in effect dilute the land base that has been laboriously created by this fund. I think the argument there is self-evident.

PARA.TAB: On the basis of what they have been telling us for some weeks now, we had thought that the Greens shared that particular perspective. I am now advised by the Greens that, for reasons that shall forever remain mysterious, they have changed their position. I had occasion to point out to Senator Chamarette that if they keep on doing these things they will lend themselves yet again to parody. She seems to have been unmoved by that. Having long ago embraced parody as a way of life in the conduct of their particular legislative business, there seems to be no further argument that can be advanced to stop them doing this sort of turning on a sixpence number all over again in the future.

Nonetheless, I hope that Senator Harradine, who is maintaining his traditional silence—so far, anyway—on this particular clause, as on the last, may be persuaded that it would be desirable to have trust arrangements created on a unanimity of Aboriginality basis, whatever other options might be available under the legislation. I indicate the government's opposition to this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what Senator Gareth Evans meant by `maintaining his traditional silence'. On only two occasions have I had the deciding vote on this matter. On the first occasion, I spoke. On the second, which was only a moment ago, I did not think it worth while to speak because all the arguments advanced in favour of the raft of amendments were so impeccably favourable and logical, while all those advanced in opposition to it made no sense at all, except to an Uncle Tom.

PARA.TAB: We should not be in that situation. We should not allow a government or a government established body to be in the position of being an Uncle Tom. Briefly, that is the point.

On this particular question, I believe that Senator Campbell needs to detail more fully the sort of situation wherein part (b) would need to come into effect. I examined this a little bit beforehand and I would be interested to hear his explanation. The proposal says:
(a)in which a majority of the beneficial interests are held by:

TAB.TAB: (i)Aboriginal persons; or
(ii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iii)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(iv)a combination of those persons; or

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand that. However, I would need to hear a bit more argument before I could vote for the amendment because I was inclined to support amendment F9 foreshadowed by the Greens. I will wait to hear what Senator Chamarette has to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond and then the opposition might confirm whether I have understood its amendment correctly. I must say that Senator Gareth Evans is always so good whenever he is parodying anything. While he is distressed by what he sees as the Greens' capacity to turn on a sixpence, I have to say that I have talked myself into supporting opposition amendment No. 50. The reason for that, apart from advice received from a number of sources, is that I want to maintain a consistent line. If this raft of amendments is not simply to tie down the ILC but to allow it flexibility and the maxi

SPEECH.PARA: mum benefits of that flexibility, and not to be paternalistic, I would be in danger of a slight degree of paternalism myself if I voted against opposition amendment No. 50.

PARA.TAB: My understanding of the difference between that amendment and the foreshadowed Greens' amendment F9—which, I might add, I will withdraw if the opposition amendment succeeds—is that the opposition amendment allows a majority of beneficial interests to be held within an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Our amendment F9 assumed a 100 per cent membership.

The opposition amendment assumes that Aboriginal people can go into this option with their eyes open. If they are already in a trust structure, it may be an unreasonable restraint and disadvantageous to demand 100 per cent Aboriginal membership. Providing for a majority of Aboriginal membership could allow for joint ventures—for example, in eco-tourism—for which a non-Aboriginal member with a minority interest in a trust might be willing to provide capital.

This amendment will increase the options available to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts to do things which, without that freedom, they might not be able to do at all. On the grounds that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should have the freedom to make mistakes and to exercise options which, in the long term, might benefit them, and on the same basis that we supported the previous opposition amendments, the Greens will be supporting opposition amendment No. 50. To refute some comments once made to me by the Clerk of the Senate, I have been swayed by the force of the arguments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an extraordinary thing for one colleague to complain about another's silence in this place! I would have thought it would be the opposite. I would like to ask a question of the proposer of this motion, Senator Campbell. Does part (b) of amendment No. 50 envisage that those in category (a) must be in a majority? Looking at it, it says—
—I agree; it doesn't say so.
—It does say so.
—I cannot see it. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: "`Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust' means a trust:

PARA.TAB: (a)in which a majority of the beneficial interests are held by:

TAB.TAB: (i)Aboriginal persons; or
(ii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iii)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(iv)a combination of those persons. . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is fair enough; the majority of them are Aboriginal persons. Then it goes on:

PARA.TAB: (b)in which some of the beneficial interests are held by persons referred to in paragraph (a) and where details of the ownership of the other beneficial interests have been provided to the Indigenous Land Corporation;".

SPEECH.PARA: As I read it, that does not require the majority of those holding beneficial interests to be Aboriginals, Torres Strait Islanders or persons or corporations covered by (iii) or (iv).

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Campbell is addressing that, could he also elaborate on decision making processes? I think we have seen a lot of examples where 49 per cent looks pretty safe, but what does he have in mind in terms of structure for the decision making processes here?

—While Senator Campbell is pondering that, could he also ponder the constitutional implications of having a clause drafted in this way, yet still purporting to be, as this no doubt is, dependent on the Aboriginal affairs power in the constitution. I am minded to think of this point because of Senator Harradine's earlier reference to a constitutional issue. I do not think it was a problem in the earlier case but it does seem to me to be a problem here. It seems to me that Senator Harradine's reading of proposed subclause (b) is dead right—that on its terms it does not in any way require a majority interest. I am indebted to Senator Harradine for drawing attention to proposed subclause (b) because I must confess that I had not really focused on it—
—Grasping at straws.

—No, it is a very important point. I thought the basic choice was between a majority provision and a unanimity provision. But (b) opens up a different set of issues altogether. I say in response to Senator Chamarette—she is talking to the brains trust; I suppose she is not listening but maybe they will be listening—that if the problem is to generate some capital for a joint venture or something of that kind, that can easily be resolved by the land itself, which is what this bill is all about, being vested in the trust comprised wholly of Aboriginal people, but that trust in turn being perfectly capable of entering into a joint venture for some kind of management purpose, whether it is eco-tourism or whatever, with some other body and with capital being raised in that way. It was anticipated that that was the way things would proceed. One would not need to have that capital injected in as part of the trust process itself.
—Which brains trust told you to say this?

—It was the brains trust on the other end of the telephone, I am advised. So I do think there are a number of things that need to be answered, quite apart from the basic policy issue, about the way in which this provision is drafted.

—I am willing to concede that proposed subclause (b) of the amendment is not clear enough and it needs to be made clearer. What proposed subclause (b) seeks to do, of course, is to ensure that, where there are other people who are not indigenous land holders, who are not Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, holding a beneficial interest in the trust—and as Senator Chamarette said, it is too restrictive to say that 100 per cent must be Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders—the details of the other beneficial interests are provided to the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: To make it clearer, with the leave of the committee I think the motion should be amended. I am not sure whether Senator Alston has a proper set of words; I will leave it to him since I cannot draft the wording while I am on my feet. To answer Senator Harradine's specific question, that is the intent of it. I think it could be amended by taking out the words `some of'. Senator Alston might have an appropriate set of words. We might amend that to ensure that its effect is absolutely crystal clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of an abundance of caution, I think we ought to get this properly drafted. The intention is to retain (a) but then say that, in respect of the non-majority interests, details of those have been provided to the ILC. So it may be that all we need to do is say (a) `and' (b)—not `or'—where details of the ownership have been provided. So we would leave out all words prior to `where'. That seems to me to give effect to what we have in mind. As I say, it may be best if we stand this provision down in order to clarify that that wording does the trick. Otherwise, I think we concede Senator Harradine's point. It was never the intention to have a majority on the one hand but then, by a back door, a minority. We always intended that where there was less than total Aboriginal ownership, the identity of the non-Aboriginal holding ought to be made known to the ILC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to this matter, I draw the attention of the committee to our proposed amendment No. 51. That relates to proposed new subsection 4B which appears at page 45 of the bill—that is, the definition of indigenous-held land. The government has said that we cannot have land management for indigenous-held land unless it fits the description contained in 4B(1). The government says that an interest in the land is sufficient if it is not less than 50 per cent. So what the government has done in its own bill is to bring in this concept of a majority, because in defining indigenous-held land it says that an interest is an interest as long as it does not consist of less than 50 per cent. You can only contribute, under that section which deals with funding for land management activities, where it is indigenous-held land. If we look at the definition of indigenous-held land, we find that 4B(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this Act, land is indigenous-held land if, and only if:

PARA.TAB: (a)an interest in the land is held by an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(b)an interest in the land is held by an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander.

SPEECH.PARA: So far, so good. If we look at the `interest' section, we find that it states that, for the purposes of subsection (1), an interest in land is to be ignored if it is less than 50 per cent. So the government itself has brought in this notion of a majority, of a holding of more than 50 per cent. It has brought that in under the definition of indigenous-held land. I submit that the government did not have the definition of a trust because trusts were not envisaged. It only talks about corporations. But with regard to that question of not less than 50 per cent, if we accept the trust situation, it should flow through that the interest in the trust should be not less than 50 per cent. What I am saying is that if there is going to be a clean line of logic, to use the expression by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the government should translate it into the definition of a trust as well, because it is certainly doing that in its definition of indigenous-held land, when it talks about not less than 50 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to think there were the beginnings of a semblance of a clean line of logic there, but it was pretty frayed and grubby, I have to say to Senator Ellison.
—Whenever you are losing the argument, you resort to ad hominem attacks.

—No, I would like to be kind but I cannot be, because he is talking nonsense. There is a difference, in the announced scheme in the legislation—and there always has been, from day one—between spending taxpayers' money for acquisition of land and spending it for management of land. With regard to the acquisition of land, it is proposed to apply a rigorous principle of the kind we are here describing. If we are going to be spending $45 million a year on land acquisition, we want to be pretty sure that we are doing it for the purpose of building and maintaining an Aboriginal land base.

PARA.TAB: There are, however, other ways in which Aboriginal people can acquire land, not only under the Native Title Act but through the ordinary operation of the general law. There are circumstances in which it is envisaged that the ILC might want to devote some proportion—presumably not very much—of the fund to assist in the development, basically, of Aboriginal enterprise which is land related. In that context, moneys are made available for management purposes to those bodies of land which are described as indigenous and defined in terms of the majority principle. But it is stretching a pretty long bow to argue in turn that that provision, which is solely to do with management funding, should relate back to these very different acquisition principles.

With regard to Senator Alston's drafting exercise, I suppose it is not good enough to argue against something on the ground of inelegance. It is going to look like a thing of shreds and patches by the time we are finished with it, anyway, if you lot continue your present disposition. Certainly, it deals with the particular problem in that bit of drafting that Senator Harradine identified—it does take out the possibility of construing it as available to a minority Aboriginal interest. I concede that.

It is a bit odd, however, to build it in as part of the definition, not only a definition of the status of the ownership but also of who has notified what to whom. It is a bit odd to drag that in as part of the definition of the concept. The draftsmen might want to revisit that in the draftsmen's amendments, if the bill should ever get to the stage of a viable third reading. I think it can go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! Another threat.

—No, I am just being frank and honest about the prospect of the bill proceeding if it continues to be denuded of workability. If the opposition responded to a particular concern by drafting an amendment which meets that concern, I am prepared to acknowledge that it meets the concern and move on. But I will not like it any better in terms of its policy substance.

—I wish to clarify one aspect before we go any further. I understood Senator Gareth Evans to say, `In land acquisition, the interest must be 100 per cent. But when it comes to land management—that is, the follow-up with funding to manage the land—you only need to have an interest of not less than 50 per cent.' I think that the logic in that case is more than flawed. It is a fundamental error to say, `We will give you land only if it is 100 per cent yours. But when we give you money for the maintenance of that land, we don't mind if the interest is not less than 50 per cent.' I do not see that it flows on from that. We say that it should count both ways if it is to have any logic—either 100 per cent interest in acquisition and maintenance or not less than 50 per cent.
—Unless it's already owned.

—The fact is that, if it is already owned, why give it to one group for the maintenance when there is not less than a 50 per cent interest? Another group who is dispossessed could come along and say, `These people already had that land, but they only had 51 per cent. We are working in conjunction with another outside group as a joint venture. We have 75 per cent and we want to acquire this land for eco-tourism, but it can't be granted to us because 100 per cent has to apply.' There is an uneven playing field as far as that goes. It tends to favour those who already have the land. This bill was all about favouring those who did not have the land.

—I seek leave to amend opposition amendment No. 50. After the word `persons' in paragraph (a), the opposition would delete the word `or' and replace it with the word `and'. We would then delete `in which some of the beneficial interests are held by persons referred to in paragraph (a) and'. Paragraph (b) of the new amendment would therefore state, `where details of the ownership of the other beneficial interests have been provided to the Indigenous Land Corporation.'

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the intention of paragraph (b) is absolutely crystal clear. It is a genuine concern that has been raised. I will rebut again what Senator Gareth Evans continues to say about the unworkability of our amendments. Honourable senators who are being objective about this know clearly the intention of the opposition and the effect of the opposition's amendments. The amendments we have discussed this afternoon do not make the legislation unworkable; they make it equitable and just and provide a bit more flexibility.
—He knows that in his heart of hearts.

—Senator Evans does know that. That is why we have had constructive discussions on a number of amendments. We have found that there has been a total consensus in the wording of some of the amendments which we will deal with in the next few hours or days. We have come up with a better wording than that contained in the government's bill, and we have had a broad agreement as to the rewording.

PARA.TAB: All honourable senators are being constructive. It may not suit Senator Evans to say so publicly. The government's actions in continuing to tell the coalition that it is trying to destroy the bill and make it unworkable will not speed up the passage of this legislation, no matter what form it ends up taking. Destroying the bill is not our intention, and Senator Evans knows that to be the case.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5A.Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 191D(2), lines 32 to 34, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:
" `(2) The Indigenous Land Corporation may make a grant of money on terms and conditions that must relate to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the purposes for which the money may be spent; or
(b)the period within which the money is to be spent; or
(c)the acquittal of money spent; or
(d)the giving of information in relation to the grant.

SPEECH.PARA: If the grant becomes repayable because of a breach of such a term or condition, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take all reasonable steps to recover the repayment.
" `(2A) A guarantee is subject to such terms and conditions as the Indigenous Land Corporation determines.".
57.Clause 3, page 4, proposed subsection 191E(2), lines 37 to 39, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:
" `(2) The Indigenous Land Corporation may make a grant of money on terms and conditions that must relate to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the purposes for which the money may be spent; or
(b)the period within which the money is to be spent; or
(c)the acquittal of money spent; or
(d)the giving of information in relation to the grant.

SPEECH.PARA: If the grant becomes repayable because of a breach of such a term or condition, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take all reasonable steps to recover the repayment.
`(2A) The Indigenous Land Corporation may make a loan of money on terms and conditions that must relate to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the purposes for which the money may be spent; or
(b)the period within which the money is to be spent; or
(c)the acquittal of money spent; or
(d)the giving of information relating to the loan; or
(e)the repayment of the loan; or
(f)the payment of interest (including interest on interest); or
(g)if the loan is secured—the loan security.

SPEECH.PARA: `(2B) A guarantee is subject to such terms and conditions as the Indigenous Land Corporation determines.".

Amendment No. 5A , which was circulated today, refers to `grants—terms and conditions'. Amendment No. 57 has also been circulated. That, too, has a paragraph headed `Grants—terms and conditions'. These are amendments to subclauses 191D(2) and 191E (2). Clause 191D deals with the land acquisition functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation, and clause 191E deals with the land management functions. Thus, one clause deals with acquisition and the other deals with management—two matters we have just been debating. I will deal with the amendments sequentially. Amendment No. 5A states:

PARA.TAB: The Indigenous Land Corporation may make a grant of money on terms and conditions that must relate to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the purposes for which the money may be spent; or
(b)the period within which the money is to be spent; or
(c)the acquittal of money spent; or
(d)the giving of information in relation to the grant.

SPEECH.PARA: If the grant becomes repayable because of a breach of such a term or condition, the Indigenous Land Corporation must take all reasonable steps to recover the repayment.
Guarantees are dealt with in paragraph 2A. It states:
A guarantee is subject to such terms and conditions as the Indigenous Land Corporation determines.
The language is mirrored in the opposition amendment No. 57. That deals with questions of loans. Amendment No. 57 states:
The Indigenous Land Corporation may make a loan of money on terms and conditions that must relate to ..
The amendment then sets out the following:

TAB.TAB: (a)the purposes for which the money may be spent; or
(b)the period within which the money is to be spent; or
(c)the acquittal of money spent; or
(d)the giving of information relating to the loan; or
(e)the repayment of the loan; or
(f)the payment of interest (including interest on interest); or
(g)if the loan is secured—the loan security.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some overlapping in the clauses because of subclause 2—2A and 2B. I will talk about that in general terms. It was felt that there had to be some sort of accountability; that is, the Indigenous Land Corporation had to have some control over the grants that were made. We have said previously that a grant should be made to a person to have and to hold.

PARA.TAB: However, when there is a loan, conditions obviously have to apply to it. Loans have to be made on a commercial basis, so that the purpose for which the money is to be spent, the method of repayment, et cetera can be spelt out. Of course, interest could apply and there could be security—for instance, some sort of encumbrance lodged in relation to the land. With respect to a guarantee, we cannot be as specific with that as we can with a loan. It was thought that it was best to leave the guarantee on such terms and conditions as the Indigenous Land Corporation determined. I think that is self-evident.

With respect to a grant of money, we have to look to the purposes for which the money is granted. That money should be used for the purpose for which it is given. Obviously, there are aspects to the giving of information. The Indigenous Land Corporation could not oversee these provisions without having the relevant information before it. That is why there is this provision for the imposing of a condition upon the recipient to provide information. After all, the first stepping stone to accountability is that there be some power for the process to be scrutinised.

So the coalition is proposing that there be adequate accountability, that an overseeing of the grants, loans or guarantees be made, but that it not be onerous to the extent that the Indigenous Land Corporation can fetter the recipients unduly. I notice that the Greens' amendments might have a similar flavour. However, they are not perhaps in the same form as those of the coalition. This is an absolutely essential point because, if the Indigenous Land Corporation is to act in the best interests of both the beneficiaries of this legislation and the Australian taxpayer, it must have the ability to impose certain conditions.

But, at the same time, we do not want that corporation becoming a sort of monolithic alternative government with no avenue of appeal, which can hamstring the recipients in such a way that it becomes a burden or is indeed used as a political tool. That is a fear that the coalition has in relation to the Indigenous Land Corporation: if we have a corporation which is all powerful and omnipresent, it has the ability to lose sight of the original reason for the setting up of this land fund. Of course, the people who will suffer, the people who will lose out, are the intended beneficiaries of the legislation.

I am not saying that the Indigenous Land Corporation will go that way, but legislation is about checks and balances. Good legislation sets out to do what the intention says it should do. It should be effective and workable. I believe that it is. It provides a balance which is fair to the recipients but at the same time affords some control to the Indigenous Land Corporation. A fundamental aspect of the bill is that the Indigenous Land Corporation has these powers. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that these amendments have been the subject of some discussion—constructive discussion on this occasion—with the opposition, and the government is prepared to accept them for essentially the reasons that were spelt out by Senator Ellison which I do not need to repeat.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette wanted me to make clear the government's position on her own rival amendment H1, which I think covers some of the same territory as opposition amendment 57. The basic problem with H1 is not so much as it refers to guarantees and loans because there the reference is to terms and conditions—albeit not as fully expressed as in the opposition amendment, but the essence of it is there. The difficulty is that part of Green amendment H1 which talks about grants of money as distinct from loans or guarantees. There, it simply imposes one condition only: that the grant be used solely for the purposes for which it is granted. That is an entirely reasonable and legitimate condition, but there may well sensibly be other conditions as well in that the terms and conditions are associated with any default provision in the event of non-payment of remaining amounts and so on. Under those circumstances, the draft proposed by the opposition after discussion with the government is the way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for clarifying that and indicate that the Greens are quite happy to support amendments 5A and 57 that the opposition has presented.

—Seeing as everyone has worked constructively on this, the Australian Democrats will, too. I put on the record that we all agree on the notion and the principle of accountability. I guess we are all trying to find our own version of this balance that Senator Ellison keeps talking about. I could not help but observe that, on the matter of grants to individuals, we erred on the side of flexibility and, on the matter of the land corporation, it seems to me that we are erring on the side of prescription. I just make that observation.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to note, too, that ATSIC has a similar system with its land acquisition and management schemes and that land-holders are expected to enter into purpose agreements. This is a way of ensuring that the rights and responsibilities of both parties—which is what Senator Ellison keeps talking about, and I understand that—are acknowledged and respected. I just do not share the world view that all big corporations have some sort of evil intention to defraud individuals or take away some of the rights of individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't put up straw women: we don't, either.

—I do not know about that. Senator Ellison made a few remarks slightly along this line. I just want to put that on the record. I do not want to see, and I do not envisage, a situation where the ILC will prescribe unnecessary or inappropriate conditions on land-holders. In many respects I thought the current wording of the bill said that and did that. But we have all come to the view that this will give us a better balance of the powers of the ILC with a greater degree of flexibility. That is fine. I have some faith in the ILC and in its membership.That is the point I want to make.
—And in the opposition.

—I will go so far as to say I have some faith in the opposition on this amendment. We will all watch very carefully to see how it works in practice. I guess that goes for other amendments as well. In seeking to prescribe in this way, we have gone a little further than the principle of the flexibility that we applied to the individuals.
—I want to respond briefly to Senator Kernot's view that we have changed our principles when it comes to these amendments. In fact, the opposite is the case.
—It's the balance.

—The balance is very much in favour of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Under the act the words are, when there is a grant or a guarantee, that the terms of conditions will be solely determined by the ILC. What we are saying here is that we want to ensure that, when the ILC imposes terms and conditions, they are quite specific and that they relate only to the grant, the guarantee or the loan.

PARA.TAB: In subclause (d), for example, where we talk about the terms and conditions in the giving of information, words were added this morning by the coalition to say that this is in relation to the grant or in relation to the loan. So we are erring, as we have throughout this debate, to ensure that the ILC does not have this over-reaching power which the bill as it stands would have—a bill the Australian Democrats supported only a few weeks ago with no amendments. Basically, a few weeks ago the Australian Democrats said they would not entertain any of the coalition amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't have these amendments in the House of Representatives.

—No; we had amendments very similar to these. Through the constructive process of negotiation and discussion, we now have a set of words we all agree on. I wanted to respond to only one point, and that is that it does not err in any way differently to the way the rest of our amendments err. It errs in favour of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders determining their own future without having the ILC looking over their shoulder every day and determining what they should or should not do.

PARA.TAB: It very much limits the terms and conditions to the purposes that either the money or the guarantee is granted for and restricts it to that. As a result, in the future no-one in the ILC can seek to impose conditions upon Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders that do not relate to those things. I think we are genuinely seeking to err in favour of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait land-holders and not the ILC, which is the bureaucracy based here in Canberra. That is the intention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the same point because I think it has wider application, and therefore it is important that we understand why we are going down this path. It is very dangerous to allow anyone an unfettered discretion and assume that somehow he will always act in good faith or he will not act in good faith. We need a regime with rules and guidelines attached that give a sense of direction to the corporation, and also enable people to audit whether it is adhering to its rules and regulations.

PARA.TAB: If we simply give it unlimited discretion there is always the temptation to go a bit further and perhaps not take proper account of those rules that are in the organisation's best interests. As we know, there can be a political backlash because people, acting with the best of intentions, simply got out of control—their enthusiasm ran away with them, they went for the big hit and it backfired. We are much safer never to think in terms of, `Do I trust this organisation or not?' We ought to proceed on the basis that any organisation needs rules and guidance. It also provides a benchmark against which it can protect itself by being able to say that it followed the rules.

I hope that in future it will not be suggested that somehow an amendment is suggesting a lack of faith on the part of those who might be running the corporation, because they change over time; any more than it would be sensible for us to say that we do not trust the government. We may well take that view because of the repeated actions of certain individuals, but we should not generalise to that point. I hope that later on those opposite will understand why we have moved such a provision.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 191D (3), line 38, omit "have regard to the desirability of", substitute "give priority to".
(11)Clause 3, page 5, proposed subsection 191E (3), line 4, omit "have regard to the desirability of", substitute "give priority to".
(12)Clause 3, page 6, proposed subsection 191F (2), lines 15 and 16, omit "have regard to the desirability of", substitute "give priority to".

These three amendments are quite simple and cover much the same ground by replacing the words `have regard to the desirability of' with the words `give priority to'. I am looking at clauses 191D(3), 191E(3) and 191F(2). Clause 191D requires that `for the purpose of the performance of the Indigenous Land Corporation's land acquisition functions the Indigenous Land Corporation must have regard to the desirability of the following'. That clause requires the ILC to have regard to the desirability of fulfilling its functions. This requirement is echoed in the other sections I have mentioned.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is saying that that should be strengthened to saying `give priority to'. It is turning it up a couple of notches, so to speak, to say that the goals and the purposes for the carrying out of the ILC's functions are not just desirable, but are a priority—that the ILC must give priority to these goals and tenets of its function. It is really a question of wording, I suppose, but the coalition believes that it needs attention because `having regard to the desirability' of something rests on the balance of probabilities. It is thought that that is not a sufficient standard. `Giving priority' requires somewhat more attention. That is really the thrust of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other half is that `must' is a lot stronger than `have regard to'.

—When one has regard to something, one can regard it but dismiss it. In common parlance, regarding something is similar to considering it. However, giving it priority is quite another thing. It tightens the function of the ILC in favour of the recipient. It is something which is tightening the wing nuts on the exercise of the ILC's functions.

—It might be tightening the wing nuts, but it is making it a little likely that the limits of one's linguistic talents will snap in the process. It is a linguistic drafting point that I would make in reply to Senator Ellison rather than a substantive one. If all the opposition wants to do is give an extra rhetorical gloss to those particular clauses, that is one thing; and we are quite comfortable with the terms of it.

PARA.TAB: But let me draw to Senator Alston's lawyer-like mind the notion that it is meaningless to impose a requirement to give priority to matters where, firstly, the order of priority is not specified in any way and, secondly, there is no reference to matters which do not attract priority, either explicitly or implicitly. It is a meaningless proposition, basically, to talk in terms of priority. The opposition is using the word `priority' because it has a sort of oomph feel or look about it; it looks a bit more than desirable for something to be priority. But in the process it is just perverting language. We only give priority to X over Y or Z; we only give priority to A over B or C or D. We do not give priority to A where A is just sitting there lonely as a cloud and not going anywhere in particular but asking to be given attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you arguing that you can't say these are priorities without saying what is not a priority?

—If there are some implicit things which clearly are not priorities, maybe. But it is not clear in the circumstances of this particular case what the implicit list may be. If the opposition is giving priority to internecine fighting, it is clear implicitly that it is doing that at the expense of giving it to policy development. We all understand that.

PARA.TAB: If the opposition is saying that it gives priority to something in the abstract without anything to compare it with, express or implied, it is all a bit dopey, with the utmost respect. It is not as if it does much damage because at the end of the day it would clearly be difficult to impugn any decision made because it would always be possible to point to another factor which was accorded a lower priority to that which was actually specified. It is not really an impugnable proposition, but it is an empty proposition. On balance, when we are trying to draft legislation, it is better not to put silly things into it. With the utmost respect, that is a silly thing to be putting into this legislation. I would suggest that on second, wiser thoughts, this amendment not be pursued. But if there is a majority for silly things like silly walks or whatever in this place, we are not going to pursue this one to the grave or test it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the minister would give priority to his functions as minister rather than just having regard to them. I am sure that he would have more than passing regard for his functions and the desirability of maintaining his functions as a minister. I am sure he would give priority to them.

—Could I ask rhetorically: on the minister's preferred wording, what would he not have regard to the desirability of? In other words, it suffers from the same vice—if there is such a vice—of not specifying the alternative. The minister chooses not to, for his purposes of `having regard to the desirability of'. What is wrong with the opposition simply giving priority in the same way? The answer is that, whenever we come to assess these matters and we have a proposal before us that does not fit within that requirement, we will say, `That is not the priority'.

—Having regard to the desirability of something is a stand-alone proposition, and having regard to priority is not inherently a stand-alone proposition unless there is something which is clearly taken into account at the same time.
—I wish to indicate support for the opposition's amendments by the Greens.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very close and longstanding friend of mine and, indeed, of many in this parliament, a wonderful professional colleague and a very great Australian, Dr Peter Wilenski AC, last Thursday morning, 3 November, died at the unhappily young age of 55 after a long and very courageous battle with cancer. It is with enormous personal sadness that I take this parliamentary opportunity to express my own and the government's sincerest condolences and deepest sympathy to his wife Jill, to his children Michael and Katy and, indeed, to other members of his family in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I will have the opportunity to speak at Peter Wilenski's funeral in Sydney tomorrow and perhaps also at the memorial service which is planned for Canberra on 22 November. But let me take this opportunity to place on the parliamentary record at least some of the things that I said in the statement that I released as Minister for Foreign Affairs the day Peter Wilenski died.

Peter Wilenski made a phenomenal contribution to the public life of Australia and internationally during his quite exceptional public service career—a contribution duly recognised with an award in the Order of Australia in 1987 and his further well deserved elevation to Companion in the Order earlier this year.

His most recent contributions were as permanent representative and ambassador to the United Nations from 1989-92 and as Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in 1992-93. He made a major impact in New York—rare for any ambassador not of the permanent five—because he combined, in an unparalleled way, a vigorous and deeply perceptive intellectual engagement, with an extraordinary talent for organisational reform and a deep commitment to the cause of social justice internationally. His painstaking work in putting together the so-called Wilenski group—a regionally mixed group of ambassadors who met over a six-month period to put together a package of measures on reform of the UN top structure—still stands as the major point of reference for UN secretariat reform.

Indeed, such was his contribution to the United Nations that the Secretary-General—in what I think must be a most unusual gesture—sent me a cable of condolence just a couple of days ago which I would like to read into the record. He said:
I was profoundly saddened to learn of the death of Dr Peter Wilenski and would like to add my own voice to all those who are mourning his passing.

Dr Wilenski was a diplomat and scholar of the highest calibre. While representing his country at the United Nations, he also served the international community with integrity and distinction, advancing the debate about the role and future of the world organisation. Although I arrived in New York only a few months before his return to Australia, I soon came to appreciate his legacy in promoting the goals of the United Nations.
Dr Wilenski will be greatly missed by his many friends in New York, both in the secretariat and in the permanent missions to the United Nations.
I extend my condolences to the government and people of Australia on the loss of a fine statesman and a man of great compassion and humanity.

SPEECH.PARA: It is signed by Boutros Boutros-Ghali. In New York, Peter Wilenski was in the very front line of the changes wrought in the international landscape with the end of the Cold War. It was thus not surprising that he brought back to his administration of my department an awareness of the need to adjust to change. He was acutely conscious of the importance of ideas and encouraged officers to develop a profound understanding of the issues on which they worked in order to make sure their contribution to Australia's future would always be far more than just ensuring that the processes of government worked well.

PARA.TAB: Although he had a very lively, extensive and extended career in student politics—where I first met him—Peter Wilenski first really came to public prominence as Gough Whitlam's principal private secretary from 1972-74. He then set about rebuilding the foundations of Australia's public administration—first of all as special adviser to the Coombs Royal Commission on government administration in 1974; then as foundation professor of the Australian Graduate School of Management from 1977-81; as adviser to the New South Wales and Tasmanian Labor governments; and, most importantly of all, after a brief period as secretary to the department of education and youth affairs, as Chairman of the Public Service Board under the Hawke Labor government from 1983-87. In this last position, he set about achieving fundamental reform of the Public Service—substantially changing its culture, inculcating the values of responsiveness and equity and attuning it to the needs of a new style of government.

When I became minister of the newly amalgamated department of transport and communications, I could think of no-one better equipped than Peter Wilenski to weld together in this new department the kind of new performance culture that we were striving for, and no-one better equipped to guide the bold new policy courses we were charting in government business enterprise reform. Peter Wilenski performed brilliantly as secretary to that department working with me in 1987-88.

In the many phases of his career there were some powerful common themes. I cannot think of anyone in the history of Australian public service who has done more than Peter Wilenski to bring the concepts and language of social justice, responsiveness, access and equity into the common lexicon of public administration. The quality of his intellectual contribution can be measured in the huge changes he initiated, many of which have been fully integrated into Australian life—their origins forgotten now by many, but no less a monument for that.

In particular, his work in initiating a significant and continuing improvement in the degree of equal opportunity for women will remain a source of courage, support and inspiration to all who believe in the dignity and worth of all human beings. I have heard him described as the first real feminist in the country. I cannot say whether that is strictly accurate but, equally, I cannot think of anyone who would be more deserving of that title of the first male feminist.

Peter Wilenski's commitment in all these respects perhaps stemmed from his eclectic but very profound academic background—coupled with his unusual childhood in a Polish Jewish immigrant family, all of which seemed to combine to give him a fresh and quite trenchant view of perhaps the clever outsider and may well have contributed also to his rather enchantingly dry sense of humour. All the time he drew together themes and issues, making innovative connections between disciplines. That was a characteristic which was reflected in every aspect of his life's work.

I know how deeply Peter's loss will be felt by his family—particularly his wife Jill Hager, with whom he had such a wonderful relationship—and his friends. My heart goes out particularly—as I think all our hearts do—to his two little children who came into his life only very recently. At the time he became secretary to my department, with all its challenges, his son Michael was only two years old and his daughter Katy was just a baby. The broken nights must have kept Peter exhausted—I know they did—but, equally, I know that he approached their early childhood with all the same intellectual curiosity and interest, to the extent of testing their IQs at fairly regular intervals, that characterised his approach to all other important issues in his life.

He looked for ways that he and others with family responsibilities might adjust their lives to be able still to make a full professional contribution without sacrificing the interests and needs, not to mention the joy, that comes with children. It is a source of very great sadness that Michael and Katy will not have the pleasure of a life together with such a father.

Peter Wilenski was a remarkable combination of compassion, intellect, vision, energy and effectiveness. He was a very fine public servant, a very great friend to have, a delightful human being and, as I said at the outset, a very great Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition and other honourable senators for their courtesy in allowing me to speak out of sequence. I would like to join with Senator Gareth Evans in the remarks which he has made. He has eloquently made a comprehensive statement about the life and times of Peter Wilenski and it has been supported by remarks from all sides of the parliament in the House of Representatives. I will not abuse the privilege that the Senate has given me to speak somewhat out of sequence by speaking for long, although there is an inordinate amount that could be said.

PARA.TAB: Peter Wilenski was to me, as he was to so many others in the parliament, a good friend and I, like so many others, regarded him as one of the great Australians that I have known in my life. He was, above all things, committed to public service in the broadest sense and to the possibility that the government and the Public Service could play a role in improving the lives of people all round the world, people in need and, of course, because of his role here, particularly Australians.

He is most remarked for his great contribution to the reform of public administration, to the process of public administration. He was involved in that process for a very long time in very many of the ways in which Senator Evans referred, which I will not repeat but which are properly recorded. I recall when he was appointed at the age of 35 to be secretary of the then Department of Labour and Immigration. It was regarded then as a very controversial appointment. In hindsight, people would regard it as the start of a great Public Service career, but in the context of the turbulent times of 1975 it was regarded as a controversial appointment. Dr Wilenski made a substantial contribution to the department's administration and its culture. He may have shocked some of the people by, as I am advised, turning up in his denim jacket to work as secretary of the department, but in more substantial ways, as well as symbolic ways, he made a contribution.

In terms of his contribution to public process which has been emphasised, I just want to say briefly that it was always about purpose, not about process—about policy, about ideas, about a willingness to challenge the orthodoxy. I think the more profound contribution that he made was to pursue process with a purpose, and not merely the very demonstrable and substantial reforms that he made.

In these brief comments, I wish to comment on the splendid diversity of his interests and contribution. He started with a career in medicine. He was, as others have said, substantially involved in great issues of foreign policy and public administration; but he also made a very substantial contribution to the arts in Australia, most recently on the council of the National Gallery of Australia. He was a person of breadth and depth. Those talents are rare, and he will be greatly missed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the expressions of regret at the passing of Peter Wilenski, as would my colleagues on this side of the chamber. I had considerable dealings with Peter Wilenski in recent years both in his position as permanent representative of Australia's mission at the United Nations in New York and then as the departmental head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

PARA.TAB: In my dealings with him, I found Peter Wilenski always courteous, constructive and helpful. There is no doubt about his fine intellect—it was obvious after even the shortest discussion on any subject—and there is no doubt about his efforts as a reformer both in domestic public affairs and also internationally. I remember his efforts at reform of the United Nations in New York. It is a pity in many ways that some of his initiatives were not more enthusiastically adopted by the powers that be.

He was a man who in recent times was obviously fighting a terminal illness with great courage. The fact that he battled on so long with the duties of public affairs was not only a credit to him but demonstrated his commitment to the betterment of the state and of the community as a whole. We send our condolences to his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my normal adjournment topic that I was hoping to speak to, I want to add my words to those that have been expressed about the sad death of Peter Wilenski. I too extend my condolences and acknowledge the depth of respect I felt for him and the contribution he made in the area of social justice. I extend concern to his family.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I am talking about another death, and that is the death of our forests. As we sit here this evening, conservationists from around the country have set up a forest tent embassy outside this building to draw attention to the urgent need to protect ancient giant trees, rare and endangered species and fragile forest ecosystems from the continuing destruction for woodchips.

We should be extremely grateful to these people who have worked long and hard to communicate their concern for the future of our forests to those who have the power to protect them. The time has come for this government and governments around Australia to act on this concern and the overwhelming concern in the wider community. Ignorance cannot be used as an excuse any longer. We will be judged by future generations if we, in full knowledge of the ecological price of current forest practices, continue to allow the destruction to continue. Governments of all political persuasions must take their conservation obligations seriously and now put in place the measures necessary to protect our irreplaceable forest heritage.

When I speak of forest conservation, I do not just mean the protection of trees. A forest is made up of complex interconnected life forms and processes. In turn, these forest ecosystems are an integral part of wider complex ecosystems. It is vital that we recognise that this complexity is what is irretrievably lost when we clearfell areas of forest. Trees can be regrown, as many people in the forest industry remind us, but clearfelled forest is lost for ever.

We also see that that complex ecosystem is intimately interconnected with the wellbeing of people in this country in rainfall patterns, salinity patterns, and many other areas of interaction of which we are not at present aware. This government can no longer play with words in regard to forest protection. As is often the case, government action has simply not matched its rhetoric on forest conservation.

When Australia signed the convention on biodiversity at Rio in June 1992, we recognised that all species have an intrinsic right to exist independently of their value to humanity. We also acknowledged the need to ensure that the use of our environment did not lead to the long-term decline of biodiversity. This is reflected to some extent in the Endangered Species Protection Act of 1992. The objective of this act is to promote the recovery of species that are endangered or vulnerable and to prevent other species from becoming endangered on Commonwealth land or as a result of Commonwealth activities.

Lip-service was paid to these concerns by imposing conditions on woodchip export licences, such that exporters were required to ensure that their activities did not threaten with extinction or impede the recovery of species listed federally as endangered. However, the federal government does not monitor compliance with these conditions and relies on state agencies. There is also considerable doubt as to whether these agencies themselves actually monitor to ensure compliance with the conditions, and certainly no formal reporting mechanism exists to inform the Commonwealth of this. Further, this protection, such as it is, only applies to species actually listed on the federal endangered schedule. Species not on this schedule but listed as endangered by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, or species that are on Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management's reserve list, are not protected by this process. Nor is this protection extended by those acts to species only listed federally as vulnerable.

In Western Australia, pre-logging surveys of flora and fauna are not routinely conducted. It is widely acknowledged, including by the federal government, that less is known of the biodiversity of Western Australia's south-west forests than of forests elsewhere in Australia. We do know that there is only one per cent of forest left in Western Australia in contrast to the two per cent of the state that was a unique forest system 200 years ago at the time of European settlement. Despite this, the federal government has issued woodchip export licences for these very forests. How can the government know whether species will be threatened with extinction when it does not know whether endangered species are present?

Under the Endangered Species Protection Act any Commonwealth decision, action or approval that is critical to the survival or recovery of endangered species should trigger the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act of 1974. Given this, each woodchip export licence renewal or increase in licensed tonnage should, in reality, either be subject to environmental impact assessment or, at the very least, result in the reappraisal of the original impact assessment conducted when in-principle approval for woodchipping was given to relevant timber companies.

Whether or not one acknowledges that forests have a value separate from their value to people, it is still hard to argue the ethics of felling trees that were here hundreds of years before Europeans first invaded this country or of destroying forest ecosystems that have evolved over hundreds of thousands of years. At the native forest network conference held in Melbourne recently indigenous people spoke of their spiritual and cultural connections with the forests. Ian Hunter of the Yarra Yarra people of the Wurundjuri said that when forests are felled the spirit of the forests goes into the ground and they do not know how to draw the spirit back out of the land. Robert Thorpe of Gunai nation said that there was a strong spiritual link between indigenous people and the land and the animals and that when one dies the other dies. In clear felling forests, we are continuing the dispossession of Aboriginal people begun over 200 years ago. According to Elizabeth Hoffman of the Yorta Yorta people and Betty King of the Kerrup Jmara tribe, we need to listen to and learn from Aboriginal people if we are to heal this land.

The convention on biological diversity, the intergovernmental agreement on the environment and the national forest policy statement—the government's so-called blueprint for forest conservation—all stressed the need to follow the precautionary principle in relation to environmental protection. In brief, this principle states that lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing measures to avoid or minimise threats of serious or irreversible environmental damage. The government seems to be taking precautions with everything but environmental protection. There are alternative sources of wood products and pulp for paper. Plantations and agroforestry are already supplying much of Australia's domestic needs and studies show that there is enough plantation timber to begin the transition now.

I think the government has a responsibility to make clear to industry a change in political will that reverses the previous position that logging of our high conservation value forests and our old-growth forests is acceptable at a price. It should be at no price, and I think the testimony of the people at the forest embassy is to be commended, encouraged and heeded by this federal government, as with all other governments around Australia at this point in history.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 7 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) On what grounds did the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) conclude that the following acquisitions by foreign companies of financial interests in Australian television companies were consistent with 57(1) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, which prohibits a foreign person from being `in a position to exercise control of a TV licence': (a) the purchase by CanWest Global Communications of a 57.5 per cent financial interest in the Ten Network in the form of subordinated debentures, some of which can be converted to shares; (b) the purchase by Century Communications Corporation of a 95 per cent interest in UCOM Pay-TV Pty Ltd, holder of satellite television licence A, most of which is a non-voting shareholding instrument and deferred debt; and (c) the purchase by Lenfest Communications Inc. of a 63 per cent stake in New World Communications, holder of satellite pay television licence B, mostly in the form of debentures, which may fall to 29 per cent as further capital is raised.

(2) Is it a fact that all three deals were designed to provide the foreign companies involved effective control of the television companies in which they acquired interests, while keeping their shareholdings under the 15 per cent limit set by section 57(2) of the Act; if not, why did the companies keep their shareholding levels so far below their financial interests.
(3) Is the Minister aware that the term `to CanWest' is now used by media lawyers to describe company structures which deliver control while avoiding Australia's foreign ownership restrictions.
(4) For each of the acquisitions referred to in (1), was Foreign Investment Review Board advice sought by or given to the ABA; if so, what was that advice.
(5) What action does the Minister propose to prohibit CanWest-type deals in future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) CanWest Global Communications Corporation has a direct shareholding of 15% in The Ten Group Ltd.(`TEN'). This shareholding confers a 15% voting interest by CanWest in TEN. When this is added to the subordinated debenture arrangement, CanWest has a total economic interest of 57.5% in Ten.

As indicated by the Australian Broadcasting Authority's (ABA's) Chairman, Brian Johns, to the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership of Print Media on 11 February 1994, the ABA's view is that these arrangements comply with the foreign ownership terms of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (BSA).

Brian Johns also indicated to the Committee that the issue could not be looked at in isolation and needed to be considered in the context of the wider control provisions of the BSA. Those provisions require the ABA to determine the proportions of so-called `deemed' and `actual' control. In terms of actual control the ABA considers other factors such as the composition, expertise and experience level of the company's board of directors, whether anyone has the right to veto decisions by the board, programming arrangements, management arrangements, and so on.
The ABA, in accordance with the BSA, exercises a continuous interest in, and monitoring of, this situation.

(b) & (c) Subsection 57(1) of the BSA prohibits foreign persons from being in a position to exercise control of commercial television broadcasting licences. Subsection 57(1) does not apply to subscription television broadcasting licences allocated under section 93 of the Act. Section 109 deals with foreign ownership limits for subscription television broadcasting licences. It provides that a foreign person must not have company interests of more than 20% in a subscription television broadcasting licence. Further, it provides that a foreign person must not have company interests in a subscription television broadcasting licence that, when added to the company interests in that licence held by other foreign persons, exceed 35%.

An important difference between subsection 57(1) and section 109 is that while the former is concerned with control by a foreign person, the latter is concerned with the company interests held by foreign persons. Section 6 of the Act defines `company interests' as follows:

"`company interests', in relation to a person who has a shareholding interest, a voting interest, a dividend interest or a winding-up interest in a company, means the percentage of that interest or, if the person has 2 or more of those interests, whichever of those interests has the greater or greatest percentage".

The ABA, as part of the process of allocating satellite subscription broadcasting licences A and B, investigated the issue of company interests held by foreign persons in the subscription television broadcasting licences. The ABA was satisfied that the limits set down in section 109 were not exceeded. In allocating these licences the ABA expressed the view that it would continue to monitor the ownership structures of the licensee companies. The ABA publicly reported on its investigations in relation to the allocation of Licence A on 14 February 1994, and on Licence B on 17 December 1993. The ABA is closely monitoring the foreign ownership of these licences.
The provisions of section 109 provide scope for foreign participation necessary for the establishment of a viable pay TV industry.

(2) The ABA is continuing to monitor the CanWest investment in the TEN network. With regard to the subscription television broadcasting licensees, there is no proscription within the Act that prevents foreign persons controlling the licences. The only proscription relating to foreign persons are those set down in section 109 of the Act relating to company interests.
(3) Question (1) above makes it clear that the ABA's view is that Canwest has complied with the ownership and control requirements of the broadcasting legislation.

(4) The Chairman of the ABA, in evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership of Print Media on 11 February 1994, advised that the only liaison between the ABA and FIRB relating to television did concern CanWest.
FIRB wrote to the ABA seeking advice on whether CanWest exerts influence over Oltec (now The Ten Group Ltd) greater than its 14.9 per cent shareholding would suggest.

In its response, the ABA contrasted FIRB's approach with the requirements of the BSA. The BSA requires that foreign company interest limits and control are to be treated separately. In assessing a potential breach of the BSA, the ABA considers compliance with the foreign company interest limits, and, given CanWest's 14.9 per cent company interest, whether CanWest exercises actual control over TEN. The ABA indicated that the concept of "control" is a concept not admitting of degree, and that the ABA was satisfied that CanWest was not in control.

The ABA also indicated that it has no role in approving transactions involving commercial broadcasting licences before or after the event; rather, the ABA's role is an ongoing role of monitoring whether foreign persons are or come to be in a position to exercise control of a commercial television licence through transaction or otherwise.
(5) The Minister does not propose to take any action. See answers to questions (1) and (2) above. However, he will continue to ensure the ABA monitors the issue closely.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the rationale behind the production of a comic on sexual harassment.
(2) If the first payment was estimated at $10,000 to Streetwise Comics, Glebe, NSW, what is the total cost of this production, per issue.
(3) How many issues are estimated to be produced.
(4) What other costs are to be encountered in the production and distribution of this comic.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has advised me that:

(1) The Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1992 introduced significant reforms to the sexual harassment provisions in the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. The amendments, which became operative on 13 January 1993, redefine sexual harassment and expand the areas of public life where it is unlawful.

Section 28F(2) now makes it unlawful for an "adult" student (aged 16 years and over) to sexually harass another adult student or a member of staff of an educational institution. An "educational institution" is defined to mean a school, college, university or other institution at which education or training is provided.

In order to promote awareness of these new provisions, a national information campaign for students and education institutions was commenced in the 1993/94 financial year. The objectives of the campaign are to:
provide male and female students in all education sectors with clear, relevant and accessible information on their legal rights and responsibilities with regard to sexual harassment;
ensure that educational institutions are aware of their legal obligation to provide a learning environment free from sexual harassment.
As part of this national campaign, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner commissioned Streetwise Comics to produce a four page colour comic for high school students on sexual harassment.

The need to address sexual harassment in schools is supported by the findings of two recent reports—Listening to Girls, which was commissioned by the Australian Education Council and involved interviews with over 800 school girls around the country, and Sticks and Stones, Report of the Inquiry into Violence in Australian Schools. Both reports document the disturbing incidence of sexual and sex-based harassment experienced by many school girls as part of their day to day routine.

It was also considered appropriate to target sexual harassment in schools this year, as the National Action Plan for the Education of Girls makes the elimination of sex-based harassment a priority area for 1994.

Other projects of the National Information Campaign involving students and educational institutions which were also completed, or were nearing completion, at the end of the 1993/94 financial year include:
national distribution of sexual harassment posters and brochures to TAFE colleges and universities in February 1994 to coincide with student orientation activities;

development and piloting of a curriculum on sex discrimination and affirmative action issues for the hospitality industry. Approval will be sought to have the curriculum included in mainstream hospitality training courses;
production of a Students' Charter setting out the educational rights of students under the Sex Discrimination Act;
development of sexual harassment guidelines for educational institutions.
(2) Total costs for the development, production and distribution of the single issue comic on sexual harassment is $41,600. 100,000 copies of the comic were printed.
(3) This project involved the production of a single issue, one-off comic on sexual harassment in schools.
(4) Nil. Costs are outlined above.
