ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale and Purchase of Dangerous Goods

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 20 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice No. 1481 (Senate Hansard, 24 August 1994, page 290) regarding advertising of dangerous goods, what steps has the Government taken, or does it intend to take, in cooperation with States and Territories, to facilitate the introduction of national standards on the prohibition of dangerous goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth is committed to the development of national standards on the prohibition of dangerous goods. As the honourable senator is aware, the Commonwealth has been playing a leading role in having this issue addressed by the Australasian Police Minister's Council. State and Territory Ministers have already agreed to the expansion of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to include pistol crossbows, nunchakus, blowpipes, blowpipe darts and ballistic knives.

Ministers are currently considering the prohibition in all jurisdictions of the possession and sale of all the dangerous goods covered or to be covered by the Customs Regulations. They are also considering the prohibition in all jurisdictions of the importation, sale and possession of replica and imitation weapons, other than approved toys. These proposals are major steps towards agreed national standards on dangerous goods, and reflect a genuine commitment to protect the community from the importation and possible use of dangerous weapons.
The Commonwealth will continue to work with State and Territory Governments in developing agreed national standards.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the difficulties faced by Westwind, a Perth-based manufacturer of wind generators, which is forced to pay import duty of 11 or 12 per cent on the material for the blades on its wind generators as there is currently no suitable material available in Australia:

(1) Is the Minister prepared to remove imported duties on components and raw material used in the manufacture of energy efficient and renewable energy technology where no viable Australian alternative exists.
(2) Has any support been provided by the Government in relation to wind generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Provision already exists under the Tariff Concession System administered by the Australian Customs Service for the removal of import duty on goods for which substitutable goods are not produced in Australia in the ordinary course of business.

Alternatively, if there are any locally produced substitutable goods, a Tariff Concession Order to remove import duty will still be granted if there is unlikely to be a significant adverse effect on the market for locally produced substitutable goods.

These two provisions of the Tariff Concession System mean that where there is no viable Australian alternative, then components and raw materials used in the manufacturing of energy efficient and renewable energy equipment can be imported without paying duty.

For your further information, enquiries about the Tariff Concession System may be addressed to Mr Joe Eastmure, Director, Tariff Concessions, Australian Customs Service, Customs House, Constitution Avenue, Canberra ACT 2601 (Phone (06) 2756383 or Fax (06) 2756376.)

(2) The government is providing support to electricity generation from wind power through programs within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. The government also supports Wind Energy through its $1.5m support for the Perth International Centre for Applications of Solar Energy which is a joint program with the United Nations Industry Development Organisation (UNIDO).

The Renewable Energy Promotion Program aims to promote the use of renewable energy, especially for stand alone power systems in remote and rural areas of Australia. The Program has four main parts; improved training and accreditation for installers of renewable systems, mobile displays which visit a number of States, fixed displays, and publicity materials and pamphlets. $3m has been provided for this program over 3 years. Electricity generation from wind power is one of the technologies promoted by this program.

The Energy R&D Corporation (ERDC) provides support for wind energy technology along with other energy technologies. In 1993 ERDC invested $0.68m on wind energy technology development. In conjunction with the Electricity Supply Association of Australia (ESAA) the government, through ERDC, is promoting a national wind energy strategy. A 360 kW wind farm which has been operating in WA since 1987 was partly funded by the Commonwealth Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that there is currently an anomaly in the taxation system in relation to sales tax on the components of a solar hot water system such that some components are currently tax exempt whilst others attract a sales tax of 11 per cent:
(1) Does the Minister consider that this is an anomaly that needs to be redressed to encourage householder and commercial enterprises to shift to this renewable water heating technology.
(2) Is the Government considering redressing this anomaly; if not, why not.
(3) Is the removal of sales tax on all renewable energy technology being considered; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Sales tax is paid on the hot water tank of a solar hot water system. This is because the tank has been regarded as a device for storage of water rather than the collection of solar energy. Where a hot water system incorporates a solar collector as part of a single unit, there is a sales tax exemption for that part of the sales value of the complete unit which applies to the solar panel and other necessary equipment such as differential pumps. In most hot water systems the sales tax would only be around 5-6 per cent of the solar system cost. The government is aware of this anomaly.

(2) I have asked my department to look into this anomaly and I am currently in the process of writing to the Treasurer about it. I will be suggesting that the entire solar hot water system should be sales tax exempt.

(3) Solar energy equipment, which is defined as equipment used for collecting, absorbing or concentrating the sun's rays for the purpose of using them as a source of heat and photovoltaic cells, is currently sales tax exempt. Ancillary equipment used to assist solar energy equipment is also exempt. Where the main purpose of the equipment is not to use solar energy, such as a `solar' pool blanket (an insulating device) or a solar powered watch, the equipment is not tax exempt.

Where windmills and hydro systems are used to generate electricity for domestic consumption, they are normally sales tax exempt under the exemption for equipment used for generating electricity in residential premises. If the wind or hydro systems are used for commercial electricity production then they are sales tax exempt as they would be classified as manufacturing systems.

The government is not considering widening sales tax exemption for renewable energy equipment except, as noted in part 2 of my response to your question, for the tanks of solar hot water systems. This is because where the type of equipment is clearly for renewable energy production, it is in general already tax exempt. In the few cases where sales tax is paid, the sales tax is only a small percentage of the final price of the system. It would produce administrative problems for the taxation department to widen the exemption without leading to any significant reduction in the price of equipment to the public.
